PROCTEXT.PARA: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator C. R. Maunsell) took the chair at 2.15 p.m., and read prayers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MELZER

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the following petition from 36 citizens of Australia:

SPEECH.PARA: To the Honourable President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That the Ex-Servicemen's and Women's Pension Association is a body formed for the express purpose of obtaining a Service Pension for all Ex-Service Personnel at sixty years of age for men and fifty-five years of age for women regardless of where they served during the 1939-45 war.

Your petitioners therefore humble pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should give urgent consideration to a favourable decision to the granting of the Service Pension to all Ex-Service Personnel who served their Country in time of need and who did not serve overseas through no fault of their own. The Service Pension is presently only granted to Returned Ex-Service Personnel.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

The South Australian and Australian National Railways systems were intended to provide essential transport services to country, semi-isolated and isolated regions;

SPEECH.SPEAKER: GIETZELT

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the following petition from 492 citizens of Australia:

SPEECH.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate, in Parliament assembled. We, the undersigned citizens of the Commonwealth, do humbly pray that the Commonwealth Government:
1. Note that legislation establishing plant variety rights in other countries has had adverse effects, namely:

(a) Virtual monopoly control of seed production has passed into the hands of a few large international corporations seeking to profit from the exclusive rights over plant genetic materials created by such legislation.

(b) The varieties of seeds available have been restricted mainly to hybrids which will not reproduce truly and will not grow without the aid of artificial fertilizers and pesticides, thus maximising corporate profits without regard for the interests of growers and consumers.
(c) The genetic diversity of crops has been eroded, rendering them vulnerable to disease and other environmental threats.

2. Recognise that maintenance of the genetic diversity of plant varieties is crucial to the continued well-being of the Australian Nation, and take all necessary steps to promote such genetic diversity as a public resource and to prevent exclusive control over plant genetic materials from falling into private hands.

3. Defend the vital interests of Australian farmers and gardeners, independent Australian seed companies and their employees, and consumers of Australian farm and garden produce, by rejecting any proposal to legislate for the establishment of plant variety rights in Australia.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a question of the Minister representing the Treasurer. I refer to the recent spate of takeover bids by major United States oil companies for big mining enterprises, such as the successful $1.77 billion bid by Standard Oil of Ohio for the Kennecott Copper Corporation. Is the Minister aware that the value of these bids in the United States during the past few weeks has exceeded $8 billion, which approximates the current combined share market value of the BHP, MIM and CSR companies? Is the Minister concerned that these multinational oil companies must inevitably turn their attention to the takeover of mining and other companies outside the United States if they are to maintain their enormous levels of profit? Is the Government taking any precautionary action to ensure that Australian-owned companies are protected from this kind of takeover activity directed from abroad? In particular, will the Government undertake to enforce Australian foreign investment policies and guidelines far more stringently than has previously been the case and to strengthen them where necessary?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — The Government is aware of the recent takeover bids made by certain United States oil companies for various major mineral enterprises in that country. Should such mineral enterprises have operations in Australia with assets exceeding $3m, these takeover bids will fall within the off-shore provisions of the Foreign Takeovers Act. Whilst the off-shore provisions are intended for use only on rare occasions, such takeovers will be examined by the Foreign Investment Review Board to ensure that they will not be detrimental to Australia. Increasing interest has been shown over recent times by international oil majors in investing in Australia's natural resources, particularly our energy resources. The Government's foreign investment policy does not discriminate between types of investors, and individual investment proposals by international oil majors are carefully examined on their merits by the Foreign Investment Review Board under the policy and the Foreign Takeovers Act to ensure that they are not contrary to the national interest.

ANSWER.PARA: Specifically with regard to the mineral sector, where foreign ownership and control is already extensive, the Government expects to see significant Australian equity participation and/or significant economic benefits before approval for individual proposals is granted. Moreover, the policy incorporates certain guidelines for minimum levels of Australian equity and control in new natural resource projects. It is true to say that there is wide interest in investing in Australia and a wide variety of business organisations, including oil majors, are investing in Australia's resources. This diversity of participation promises to open up a wide variety of channels for Australian exports as well as introducing technical, managerial and financial resources. The Government recognises that too heavy a reliance for development on any one type of investor could carry disadvantages for Australia. I am sure that it is known to honourable senators that the Foreign Investment Review Board indicated in its 1980 report that whilst foreign oil companies own about 50 per cent of Australia's petroleum reserves they have not achieved significant levels of participation in other energy resources. The Board also noted that so far it has no clear-cut evidence to indicate that investment by foreign oil companies has been more or less desirable than investment by other foreign interests. These matters are subject to continuing monitoring and review by the Board. If there are other aspects in the case mentioned by Senator Chipp which he would like me to refer to the Treasurer, I will be happy to do that for him.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bonner Sen N.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Education. I preface my question by stating that I have received a number of letters from constituents alleging that in January's edition of the homosexual magazine Campaign it was reported that the Commonwealth Government had approved a grant of $5,000 to two homosexual teachers to produce a kit on homosexuality to be distributed on a trial basis in secondary schools this month, with a view to its introduction by 1982.

QUESTION.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Whilst I have not read and never will read that perversive publication, I feel I must raise this matter and ask the Minister: Is that report correct and, if so, why is the Government exposing school children to possible moral danger? Finally, if the report is true, I as a grandfather of 24 grandchildren, demand that the grant be withdrawn.

QUESTION.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it is interesting that all of the humour on this matter is coming from the Labor Party benches. It seems to me that this is a matter of serious consideration to the parents of millions of school children in Australia and therefore deserves serious consideration and reply. My understanding is that an approval for an amount of money for a special innovations grant was made by the Commonwealth Minister for Education without the identification that that grant was to be used for such a purpose. He approved it for a special innovation, not knowing that that was to be its purpose. Since then the Minister has made a statement on this matter. He has sought to see whether there are legal means of recalling the money and, of course, he has sought to see that in the future any requests for such grants should be so clearly delineated that this situation cannot occur again.

—My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. After the last election was the Cabinet Wages Committee abolished? I further ask the Minister: Was it abolished without consultation with the then Minister for Industrial Relations? If in fact it was a Cabinet decision to abolish the Committee, was the Minister present at the Cabinet meeting? Does the Minister agree with the allegation that the abolition of the Committee reduces the effective administration of the industrial relations portfolio?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not recall the events regarding the construction or the abolition of particular Cabinet committees before or after the election. I will certainly seek the information regarding the Cabinet Wages Committee and let Senator Button have this information. Therefore, I do not know whether there was consultation with the Minister or with Cabinet as a whole. Certainly, the structure of Cabinet committees is a matter for Cabinet discussion. I want to make it perfectly clear that Cabinet and the full Ministry have ample opportunity to discuss all aspects of Cabinet government, and they are encouraged to do so.

ANSWER.PARA: As to whether any such action would restrict the ability of either the Minister for Industrial Relations or the Cabinet to consider such matters, the answer is emphatically no. There is full discussion by the full Cabinet on industrial relations. Industrial relations has been regarded as one of the most significant functions and responsibilities of the Cabinet. It has been pursued in wide discussion very regularly-almost daily-in the Cabinet. Therefore, in fact, the Cabinet constitutes itself overall as a committee on industrial relations.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to ask a supplementary question. Do I understand the Minister to be saying that all major industrial relations decisions are made by the full Cabinet?

—If Senator Button understood that, he was not listening to my answer. I did not address myself to that at all. I said that at regular intervals, almost daily, industrial relations matters are considered by the full Cabinet. I cannot recollect whether from time to time Cabinet committees have looked at industrial relations matters but, in general terms, the full Cabinet directs itself to those matters.

—I direct a question to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport. Is it a fact that last week an offer was made to the Government by at least one international carrier to carry within Australia those passengers who were stranded by the air hostesses dispute-both those connecting with international flights and those travelling only within Australia? Is it a fact that the Government's reply was to refuse to consider the second request and to refer the airline, as to the first, to Qantas Airways Ltd in respect of any such passengers in need of assistance to enable them to travel? Is the Minister aware that Qantas did not acknowledge, reply to, or act upon an ensuing request to carry passengers on the same basis as it had already been allowed to do by the Government? Why did the Government not give any international airlines other than Qantas the ability to receive requests from stranded travellers, either direct or by referral from Ansett Airlines of Australia and Trans-Australia Airlines? Does the Minister agree that the effect of the Government's decision was to give Qantas an unfair advantage over its competitors in access to prospective international travellers and that this decision was not in the best interests of the public?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not aware of the approach or the circumstances that the honourable senator defines. However, the Government has made a decision to invite international airlines to carry domestic passengers over sections of the trunk routes in order to assist as many people as possible to fulfil travel arrangements. I have with me a Press statement issued by the office of the Minister for Transport on 27 April. It states:

ANSWER.PARA: The Government has requested international airlines serving Australia to consider carrying domestic passengers during the current flight attendants' dispute which has grounded TAA and Ansett aircraft.
The Minister for Transport, Mr Ralph Hunt, announced tonight that the Government made the request in the public interest.
He said the Government had asked international carriers, including Qantas, to give the following priorities:
(A) The carriage of domestic passengers for compassionate reasons, the carriage of Federal MP's and other VIP's;
(B) The facilitation of international travel by carrying international passengers on domestic journeys to or from connecting international flights;
(C) Domestic passengers enduring hardship such as those stranded away from home and having other compelling reasons to travel;
(D) The carriage of other domestic passengers.
Mr Hunt said the carriage of domestic passengers would only apply to the routes normally served by the international carriers concerned in normal scheduled services.
He said international carriers would only be able to carry domestic passengers holding tickets issued by TAA or Ansett. Domestic passengers should not approach international carriers direct.
If Senator Martin seeks any additional information I would be happy to obtain it for her.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to ask a supplementary question. I did not hear the last few words that the Minister uttered but I would point out to him that my question referred to arrangements in respect of last week. Will he undertake to provide the Parliament with an answer to the question that I detailed in relation to events of last week?
—Yes. I will refer the full text of the question to the Minister and seek a reply.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: UNITED AMERICAN AND AUSTRALASIAN FILM PRODUCTIONS PTY LTD

Is the Minister aware that this type of proposal, which involves an arrangement precluding assignments, is disadvantaging those who are trying to work within the Government's proposed framework of a 150 per cent deduction on film outlays and is causing concern to those who are interested in investing in the viability of the Australian film industry? Will the Minister look at this type of partnership investment venture and others that are circulating when drawing up the Government's film investment legislation to see that those who want to assist in genuine investment in the Australian film industry and who want to work within the Government's guidelines as outlined at the last election are protected?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I am not aware of the matters referred to by Senator Douglas McClelland. There was a lot of detail in his question with regard to United American and Australasian Film Productions Pty Ltd. ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: ANZAC DAY ADDRESS BY AUSTRALIAN DEFENCE REPRESENTATIVE

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister representing the Minister for Defence aware that a member of the Department of Defence, Mr Ivo Parker, Australian Defence representative at the Pine Gap base, used the occasion of an Anzac Day address to accuse of disloyalty local residents who are opposed to the facility? Is the Minister aware that the primary target for this attack was Mr Neil Bell, the member for MacDonnell in the Northern Territory Legislative Assembly? Does the Minister consider it appropriate for a public servant to behave in this way? As large numbers of Defence representatives are requested to speak at Anzac Day services, will the Minister ask that, in preparing addresses, remarks of a party political or divisive nature be avoided? Will the Minister inquire into this specific incident, which was obviously designed to utilise an Anzac Day service for crude political purposes? Will the Minister examine the suitability of an officer with such poor judgment holding a position of major responsibility which requires a level of judgment not displayed in this incident?

—I am unaware of the matters Senator Robertson has raised. I am sure that the Minister for Defence would be concerned about the matters raised, and I will refer them to him and ask him to investigate them. I am sure he will do so when his attention is drawn to them. It might be helpful if Senator Robertson would let me have details of any record of the matters that could also be drawn to the Minister's attention.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. I draw the Minister's attention to an Age report of 21 April 1981, a copy of which I have supplied to the Minister, relating to claims by Dr Andrew Swann, a world expert on legionnaires disease, that the organism which causes this severe form of pneumonia could still be in the air conditioning plant at Parliament House. Will the Minister comment on this article and, in particular, Dr Swann's suggestion that it is too early to claim that there is no possibility of the organism being found again in Parliament House? In the interests of the health and safety of members and officers of this Parliament, I ask the Minister: Have tests been carried out for legionnaires disease bacterium in other sections of the air conditioning plant servicing Parliament House? If so, what have been the results? What action will be taken to ensure that in future members and their staff are alerted to risks posed to their health within Parliament House as soon as they are discovered?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am grateful to Senator Missen for drawing my attention to the Age article. It enabled me to seek and to have available information. I am advised that samples taken in January and February of this year of water from the main cooling tower and the Prime Minister's standby tower contained legionella. Sampling continued: A sample of 2 April proved negative. A sample of 22 April will take a fortnight to analyse. Each fortnight cooling towers are physically cleaned and scrubbed. Each week they are given a slug dose of biocide. Each fortnight they are given a slug dose of slimocide, which is chlorine based. In addition, biocide is fed continuously into the cooling systems.

ANSWER.PARA: Dr Andrew Swann, an English expert, was reported in the Age of 21 April as saying that it was very difficult to eradicate the legionella organism and that it was too soon to say that it would not be found in Parliament House again. The procedures being adopted at Parliament House are similar to those he said were adopted successfully at a London hospital. One difference is that the hospital infection was in a pipe water supply whereas in Parliament House the disease was located in cooling towers where chlorine is less important as an eradication agent. Following Press reports on 3 April, the Department of Health and the Joint House Department issued a statement which said people working in Parliament House are no more at risk in contracting legionnaires disease than other members of the public.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a question of the Minister representing the Minister for Transport. Will the Australian National Railways carry out government policy and give concessional rail travel to people on sickness benefit who qualify in accordance with the 1980 Budget decision and amendments to the Social Services Act made in November last year? As the reason given by the head office of the ANR for not carrying out government policy and social security law is that it has not yet been notified, will the Minister for Transport inform his Department of the amendments to the Act and the Budget undertaking, grant concessions and make refunds to those on sickness benefit who qualify under law for the concession for full fares they have paid since the 1980 Budget?
—I will bring the question to the attention of the Minister for Transport in another place and ask him to give it consideration.

—Can the Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations inform the chamber what action an individual or a group of people can take against a union indulging in strike action which results in harm to the business of that individual or group? I refer specifi- cally to the present air strike, which has caused massive loss to numerous small and large industries in my State. I remind the Minister that the present ludicrous strike interferes with free trade between States.

—I will refer that question to the Minister for Industrial Relations. I think all honourable senators would be aware that the Government has legislated with respect to rights of action in secondary boycotts and matters of that nature but that is obviously not what arises in this case. As to whether there are any civil rights which individual organisations or businesses might have with respect to an interference with their businesses, that is a matter on which they should seek private legal advice.

—My question is addressed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I preface it by referring to a Press conference held by him on 2 February of this year which coincided with the release of the report of the National Energy Advisory Committee on alternative liquid fuels. I ask: Did the Advisory Committee say in its report that the prospect of commercial viability of the Rundle project in the medium term was only moderate to good, yet a printed Press release, which I understand was given by the Minister to members of the Press at that conference, simply stated that the prospects were good? Is there any significance behind the change in the description of the viability from 'moderate to good' to 'good'.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have responded to a question similar to that in this place before. It is true that at a Press conference I distributed a report from the Committee. It did say that the prospects for Rundle were moderate to good. It is true that the word 'good' appeared in part of a Press statement tabled by me. I have indicated that my Department prepared the attachment which was meant to be identical to the statement by the National Energy Advisory Committee. The error was made at a departmental level. I apologise that the error was made. The situation was not intentional and no significance at all should be placed on it. I think I have already indicated that a number of--
—Talking up the shares.

—Once again, the words 'talking up the shares' have been used. I want that interjection to be noted. I want to make clear what happened to the shares. In a moment I shall seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard a table showing the movement of the shares in Rundle from 31 October 1980, through February to April this year. Let me say these things: It is alleged that I talked up the shares at that time. It is alleged that--
—Tell us about the 3,000,000 sold on 20 February.

—Mr Deputy President, of course, Senator Walsh does not want to know. The table shows that shares in Central Pacific Minerals NL were worth $11 on 31 October last year. They had dropped to $5.80 before I went to Rundle. Was I talking up shares? Their value had halved. Two days after I went to Rundle their value dropped from $5.80 to $5.10-a fraction compared with their movement in the past. On 31 October last year Southern Pacific Petroleum NL shares were worth $4.20. By 13 February they were worth $2.15. Their value had halved. In other words, over some five months--
—Mr Deputy President, I take a point of order. I would like you to advise the Senate whether the Minister is reading from a Government document or from some Press report.
—The Minister will tell the Senate in good time when he has the report incorporated.

—Mr Deputy President, I was reading from an article which appeared in the financial columns of the Press. I shall seek leave to have that article incorporated in Hansard. It shows that contrary to there being a talking up, in the five or six months prior to my visit to Rundle there was a fall by half in the value of the shares. The movement and sale of the shares is demonstrated as being very heavy in that six-month period, considerably heavier than afterwards.
—It was very heavy on 20 February.
—Order! Senator Walsh will cease interjecting.

—The interjection is that it was very heavy on 20 February. Let me say this: On 5 December last year 859,400 shares were sold. On 12 December, 1,045,000 were sold, and that is to be compared with 20 February, when the figure was 704,700. So in fact the figures are so much less.
—What about--
—Order! I call you to order again, Senator Walsh.

—I want to say again that there is recorded in Hansard a series of cautionary statements by me on this matter. It was also recorded in the Press in September that the Esso partner itself had put out a cautionary statement. So in fact the interjections are totally wrong. I seek leave to incorporate the document in Hansard.

ANSWER.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows:
RUNDLE TWINS' DECLINE WAS UNDERWAY
By Malcolm Maiden

A study of the share prices and turnover of Central Pacific Minerals NL and Southern Pacific Petroleum NL shares shows that the Rundle twins were out of favour with investors well before Monday's announcement that development of Rundle could be delayed.
However, a search of both companies' share registers reveals that the major shareholders in both have maintained their presence.
Neither company was buoyed by the recovery in share price which began last month. Their shares also failed to react early this month when foreign investors returned in force.

In fact Rundle's stocks were probably highest immediately after the Federal election of October 18-Prime Minister Malcolm Fraser had instanced the Rundle agreement between Exxon and the twins as evidence of the beginnings of a major resources boom.
In the last weeks before the Exxon announcement the share price of both Central and Southern dipped sharply as turnover accelerated.

Of particular interest is the solid increase in Southern Pacific turnover in the week before the gloomy announcement-exchange executives are understood to be concerned that inside trading may have occurred before Monday's announcement.

Southern Pacific has a 23.47 million share holding in Central Pacific-equal to about 23 per cent of issued capital, in line with the group's holding of 2.35 million shares last May; both companies made a nine-for-one bonus issue in September.

Central Pacific in turn holds 50.8 million shares in Southern Pacific-also about 23 per cent of issued capital; based on Southern's top 20 list of last May, Central would have received 52.54 million shares from the September bonus issue.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer and relates to the continuing growth in money supply over the past few weeks. What steps are currently being taken by the Government to keep this growth under control?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — The Treasurer made a statement with regard to the money supply matter earlier this week. In that statement, amongst other things, he did state that the money supply figures for March 1981 released by the Reserve Bank of Australia on 27 April show that M3 increased by 11.7 per cent over the 12 months to March. This compares with increases of 11 per cent over the 12 months to February and 11.3 per cent over the 12 months to January. This growth is significantly below the rate of around 13 per cent recorded during the first half of the financial year, but it remains above the Budget projection of about 9 to 11 per cent for the year to June 1981. The Treasurer stated that factors which contributed to the increase in monetary growth last month were much stronger private external transactions as compared with the year earlier and larger net redemptions of government securities, particularly of Treasury notes by non-bank groups. I think it ought to be said also that the latest figures need to be interpreted in the knowledge that over the remainder of the financial year there will be large provisional and company tax payments in April and May respectively which will swing budgetary transactions into substantially larger surplus than was the case last year. This will help to reduce growth in monetary aggregates. There will, of course, be many other influences on monetary growth in coming months such as private capital inflow and changes in the holdings of government securities. These and other influences on the money supply are subject to large month-to-month changes and consequently monetary growth itself can vary from month to month without necessarily indicating any change in the underlying trend. These are some of the comments which were made in the Treasurer's Press statement this week. I commend that statement to Senator Lewis if there are further facts that he would like to ascertain.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Finance. If the Government is genuinely interested in pruning superfluous expenditure, why has it not suspended the $170,000 a year being paid to the eight failed or retired Liberal and National Country Party politicians who have received sinecures from the Fraser Government which carry an aggregate salary of $360,000?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — If Senator Walsh is referring to former parliamentarians who have received benefits under the superannuation scheme which applies to parliamentarians--
—I am.
— It ought to be stated that these payments are made in accordance with the relevant Act.
—The Act does not require you to give them sinecures as well.

— They are payments which are made regardless of from which party a parliamentarian may come. I think if the honourable senator were to pursue the matter that he has been raising publicly, it could also be stated that all payments have been made in accordance with the Act and irrespective of from which party a former member may have come. The Act, with any amendments, has been supported through the Parliament by all parties from both sides of the House. It is an Act that makes provision for retirement benefits for parliamentarians, and I think that some of the statements made by Senator Walsh have been quite inappropriate.

—I wish to ask a supplementary question. Is the Minister saying that the parliamentary retirement legislation requires governments to give to retiring politicians government sinecures or, as they are more commonly known, 'jobs for the boys'?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I made no such statement. Again I state that it is the practice of governments to make appointments to statutory authorities and to government service in many instances. These appointments are known to be made in appropriate terms. I repeat that the comments that have been made by Senator Walsh ignore what has been a long-established practice of using people who have a particular experience and skill in capacities of service to the government.

—Has the Minister representing the Minister for Transport seen reports regarding cost recovery for general aviation which propose that landing charges for general aviation should be increased dramatically, for example, that charges at Adelaide Airport should be increased to $15 for both landing and take-off and at Parafield, South Australia, to $7? Will trainee pilots have to pay these increased costs? If so, will the Government, when considering the report, take into consideration the adverse effect of such charges, which could prevent many young people from training for a pilot's licence as many could not afford the higher costs when coupled with the previous increase in costs? Will it also take into consideration the effect such increased charges will have on air services and general aviation in many country areas throughout Australia?

—I am not aware whether the cost recovery program for landing charges applies to trainee pilots or whether there are special rates for them. I will take aboard Senator Young's suggestion that this could have an adverse effect on training and refer the matter to the Minister for Transport in another place for his consideration.

—Can the Minister representing the Minister for Trade and Resources explain to the Senate why certain equipment used by licensed citizen band radio operators and others is readily available on the local market and yet is illegal to use? Such equipment includes power boosters, scanners, beams, power microphones and telephones. Is it not a fact that the Government collects import duty and sales tax on these items, which are then declared by the Commonwealth Government to be illegal to use?

—I do not know whether this would come under Trade and Resources or Business and Consumer Affairs. In either case, it so happens that at this moment I am the representative Minister. I have no information on the matter. I will seek it out and let Senator Elstob have it.

—Is the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs in a position to indicate to the Senate whether the committee comprising members of the Federal Departments of Health and Aboriginal Affairs, et cetera, which is reviewing health facilities at Papunya, Northern Territory, has referred any decision or recommendations to the Government? Will the Minister advise what is the Committee's present position?

—Those who know the Northern Territory and the central region will know the difficulties that have occurred at Papunya, difficulties related to many of the community structures, not the least of which is health services. It is true that some time ago a committee was set up and that a senior officer from the central office of my Department, Mr Wanganeen, has been in the Northern Territory. He was at Papunya for some weeks carrying out an investigation. I am still awaiting the final report. It is not in my hands yet and I am not in a position to respond to the particular matters the honourable senator has raised. As soon as I get the report it will receive my urgent attention.

—Can the Leader of the Government in the Senate give any indication of the current state of the Government's thinking on the questions of whether the maximum term of Parliament should be extended beyond its present three years and whether the term of the Parliament should be fixed? In particular, can he tell us when the Government will formally announce its attitude and intentions with respect to the proposal for fixed four-year terms recently recommended to it by the back bench Government committee which was specially set up last November to consider these questions?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised that the proposals for four-year terms for parliaments in Australia have received considerable support in recent years. The advantages of longer term planning, increased flexibility and fewer expensive election campaigns are well known. The matter was discussed at the Premiers Conference in 1980. Since then Victoria has proposed a four-year term. A referendum is to be held in New South Wales with the State election this year. Reports indicate that Western Australia is also considering extending the term of State Parliament to four years. A four-year term for the Commonwealth Parliament is being studied by the Government parties. A referendum would, of course, be required if a change were to be introduced.

ANSWER.PARA: There is a question as to the appropriate Senate term and its relation with the term for the House of Representatives. If the House is to have a four-year term there is need for consensus among parties and between the Commonwealth and States. As I understand Senator Evans, he was referring not to a maximum four-year term but to a fixed four-year term.

TALK.START.PARA: —As a separate question.

—They are two quite distinctively separate questions. The House of Commons, of course, does not have a fixed term; it can hold an election earlier, as can the House of Representatives. The Senate has a fixed term and the House of Representatives has a maximum term. This matter is under discussion concurrently with the other matters.
—I wish to ask a supplementary question. When can we expect a government announcement on the latter question and, indeed, on the former question as well?
—I am not in a position to say. I will seek the information.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Industrial Relations. Is it true that the airline hostesses started meeting seven minutes ago in all capitals and that rank and file members have the opportunity to end the strike promoted by the Airline Hostesses Association? What is the Government's assessment of the dispute? What steps can the Government take to see an end to this kind of enormous disruption caused to the public by an unwarranted strike?

—I am not able to say whether the airline hostesses began meeting seven minutes ago or whether they will meet in 23 minutes time. But I understand that there are to be further meetings, either at 3 p.m. or 3.30 p.m. I understand that the rank and file will have an opportunity to go back to work. I think that would be the earnest wish of every Australian. I have no intention of making a statement at this point which might do anything to prevent that happening.

—My question is directed to the Minister for National Development and Energy and follows the question asked by my colleague Senator McAuliffe. Did the Minister not express great optimism about the future of the Rundle shale oil project at a Press conference on 2 February this year? Is it true, as reported, that Exxon, the parent company of Esso, told our Australian officials in New York that statements being made by the Australian Government about Rundle were too hard? Is it not also true that the Government received expert advice last year from senior members of the Australian Public Service that there were serious doubts about the feasibility of Rundle?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not believe that I expressed highly optimistic views. My views on Rundle must be taken in their overall context and Hansard will indicate how I have expressed the enormous challenge, the huge costs, the high technology and the unknowns on the journey. I have expressed enthusiasm for the undertaking to proceed because I believe that all Australians would want us to get synthetic fuel and would want these great enterprises to get moving so that we can be assured of fuel for the future. There is a vast difference between enthusiastically wanting these kinds of projects to get going so that we can be provided with energy balance for the future and being highly optimistic. I also direct the attention of the Senate to the various statements that I have made. I know nothing of any suggestion that there was advice to Australian officials in New York that we were taking too optimistic a view here. I have not heard that. I believe I must have heard it if it was in their possession. It was a responsibility directed to me.

ANSWER.PARA: As to whether any member of my Department or any other department advised me that there were serious difficulties, the emphatic answer is no. The first time that my departmental head, my second in command, the Director of the National Energy Office, and I heard of this was when we were in company in Gladstone and we sought a briefing. No such report from any officer was channelled to me through the Department. Certainly my departmental head and the head of the Energy Office were unaware of any such information.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister, relates to the present airline strike. Will the Government reconsider the arbitrary requirements for cabin attendants in relation to airline safety requirements at a more realistic and lower level with a view to replacing hostesses and stewards with flight safety officers? I might add that the present crewing strengths are set by the airlines and exceed the minimum Department of Transport requirements for safety. While this move is being undertaken, will the Government request Trans-Australia Airlines and Ansett Airlines of Australia to use volunteer labour, as Qantas Airways Ltd did in its recent strike? If other unions enter the dispute, will the Government unswervingly apply its secondary boycott legislation?

—I imagine that, as in all other matters where increasing costs are affecting transport and particularly airlines, the construction of aircraft, the provision of services and so on will be so designed that there will be an attempt to keep costs down by way of staff, so that that will be, I think, an automatic pressure and an inevitability as these costs rise. I will bring the matter to the attention of the Minister for Transport. It is true that the airline regulations provide for a minimum number of safety officers. I think the minimum on each aircraft is exceeded by one at this moment. It is a technical matter. I will bring the remainder of Senator MacGibbon's question to the attention of the Minister concerned.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN CAPITAL TERRITORY: LAWS RELATING TO RAPE AND SEXUAL OFFENCES

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Attorney-General. Bearing in mind the speed with which some ordinances for the Australian Capital Territory are gazetted at the Government's wish or whim, can the Attorney-General say why there has been no gazettal of the ordinance to reform the anachronistic and ineffective laws relating to rape and sexual offences in the Australian Capital Territory, even though that ordinance has been in preparation for more than five years? When can we expect this ordinance?

—I have considered several drafts of the ordinance and the matter has been considered by the other Ministers concerned. It was virtually ready to be submitted to the Australian Capital Territory Legislative Assembly when the New South Wales Government introduced reform of its rape laws. That legislation is called the Sexual Offences Bill, I think. That has been brought to my attention. I think that certain features of the drafting of that legislation are relevant and, if adopted, may improve in some respects the draft that I had seen and virtually approved of the ordinance for the Australian Capital Territory. That is being looked at now. I trust that within a reasonable period the final draft of the ordinance for the Australian Capital Territory will be ready for submission to the Assembly.

—I direct a question to the Minister representing the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs. What are the criteria under which exemptions are granted to import duty? It was recently drawn to my notice that a Swiss-made machine was imported for experimental purposes and is successfully preventing expensive and damaging mineral build up in water piping and fittings in the Pilbara. Importation under by-law was refused on the grounds that a manufacturer in Melbourne manufactures a similar machine, yet my information is that that machine is designed to remove algae from water by a totally different process and that the manufacturer has refused to manufacture a machine similar to the Swiss-made machine.

—I think perhaps it would be best if Senator Thomas were to give me the particulars of this case. I will have it investigated and also, at the same time, I will provide him with details of the general criteria which govern the matter.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: PROPOSED CONSTRUCTION OF UHF TRANSLATOR TOWER

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister repre- senting the Minister for Communications inform the Senate what are the latest developments in the proposal to build a UHF translator tower at North Head in Sydney? Is it a fact that the Government is giving prime harbourside land, free of charge, to the three commercial television networks to enable them to build a tower which will not only cause visual and environmental damage but also will improve television viewing for only a small number of people? Is it also a fact that the proposed tower has attracted a tremendous amount of local public opposition and that alternatives to the tower have been put forward but with no avail? Finally, is it a fact that the introduction of cable television will provide much better reception than the proposed UHF tower and that the likely impact of cable television on the three commercial networks is the real reason behind the proposal to build the translator tower?

—The question asked by the honourable senator really covers two main subjects. Both relate to the tower which he says is proposed for North Head and to the question of cable television perhaps being an alternative. The question involves a considerable amount of detail. I will refer it to my colleague the Minister and obtain an early response.

—My question, which is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry, concerns the Australian National Animal Health Laboratory at Geelong. I ask: Is it necessary to introduce certain dangerous viruses such as foot and mouth into this laboratory in view of synthetic viruses which are now available? I ask: Will primary producers be given a guarantee that they will be consulted before such viruses are introduced for experimental purposes in Australia?

—The honourable senator raises a matter which is certainly beyond my technical competence. He draws attention to the possible dangers of introducing dangerous viruses to Australia. He would be aware that it has been the concern of successive Australian governments to ensure that that does not occur. I am sure, therefore, that the matter which he raised will be treated with great seriousness by the Government. I will ask the Minister to let him have a reply which I am sure will indicate that the Government is taking steps to ensure that no action is being taken which might prejudice the critically important livestock industries in this country.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Veterans' Affairs and refers to repatriation matters, but in particular to the case of a South Australian ex-prisoner of war's continuing applications to have cancer of the bowel accepted as a war service condition. I ask the Minister: Has he had the opportunity to study the complaints made by this South Australian ex-serviceman, in particular the inquiries he made of the most recent appeal to the Repatriation Review Tribunal in June 1980? In December, when he inquired of an official of the Tribunal as to what was the position of his application, he was told that they were just starting to deal with the 1977 cases and that the gentleman would be looking at the end of 1981-maybe the middle of 1982-before the case could be heard. When the ex-prisoner of war asked what would happen if he died in the meantime the officer replied: 'Stiff cheese.' I ask the Minister to make thorough inquiries into this matter. At this stage is he able to advise in respect of this case? If not, will he research the complaint to make sure that this ex-serviceman gets justice?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Bishop was kind enough to show me the letter from his constituent; I am grateful for that. It is true that there is delay in bringing some cases before the Tribunal; there is no doubt that that is so. This is generally caused by strict compliance with several time-consuming procedures and also by the volume of applications received. The system is designed to ensure that each case is thoroughly prepared and that all available evidence is presented to the Tribunal for consideration. The tribunal has some 130 applications outstanding in South Australia and, in the interests of all concerned, it attempts to deal with them in chronological order of receipt.

ANSWER.PARA: I turn to Mr Fitzsimons's complaints. As to the advice he claims to have received-that the Tribunal would not be hearing his case until possibly mid-1982-I state that there is nothing to support this. His case is actually due for listing during the Tribunal's sittings in South Australia between 6 and 10 July 1981. That is one pleasing piece of news. Mr Fitzsimons will be advised of the exact time and date of his hearing by the tribunal clerk in South Australia. The Minister for Veterans' Affairs and the Repatriation Commission are aware of, and concerned about, the delays in these cases. They are constantly monitoring the situation in an attempt to find a solution to the problem that Senator Bishop has set out. They are attempting to reduce the time taken to finalise applications to the Repatriation Review Tribunal. Mr Fitzsimons also refers to not being informed of the delay in his case. Unfortunately, this is correct. He has a legitimate complaint in that respect. Steps have been taken to ensure that he will be kept informed of further progress and that no undue delay occurs in his case.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: UNITED NATIONS PEACE-KEEPING FORCE IN THE MIDDLE EAST

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs and concerns the recent suggestion by one of Britain's senior defence experts, Admiral Lord Hill-Norton, that because United Nations forces in the Middle East were becoming so politically unpopular they should be replaced by Australian troops. Does the Government agree with the Admiral that Australian and other Commonwealth forces in Zimbabwe performed with rare skill that astounded the rest of the world and that the techniques used in Zimbabwe could be applied on the Palestinian West Bank, the Iran-Iraq border or the Thai-Cambodian border? Further, does he agree that this kind of activity has far more to do with peace than all the unreal talk about disarmament? Has any consideration been given to the placing of this proposal on the agenda for discussion at the next Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting, or has any approach been made to the United Nations that Australia contribute to the United Nations peace-keeping force in the Middle East?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — The honourable senator's question is very comprehensive. It touches on foreign affairs, defence and Government policy in respect of a whole range of matters. I will refer it to the appropriate Ministers and ascertain whether they wish to make any response concerning the statement that I understand was made by Admiral Lord Hill-Norton when he was in Australia. I do not know what response there would be to such a wide-ranging suggestion by the honourable senator but if the Ministers concerned wish to comment I will see that he is advised.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Keeffe Sen J.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. Has a reply been obtained from the Prime Minister to the question I raised yesterday-and the lengthier one that I put on the Notice Paper-concerning Northern Ireland. My question yesterday was:

QUESTION.PARA: Can the Minister inform the Parliament whether the Australian Government is aware of the disaster likely to occur in Northern Ireland if House of Commons parliamentarian, Bobby Sands, dies? Can the Minister also inform the Parliament whether his Government has applied any pressure on the Thatcher Government to avoid such a disaster and to save the life of Bobby Sands? If not, why not?

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not aware that the Prime Minister has as yet provided an answer. I will seek to expedite it.
—Mr Deputy President, may I respectfully ask the Minister to obtain an answer urgently, because this man's life and three other lives are about to ebb away?
—I repeat: I will seek to expedite the answer.

—I ask the Leader of the Government in the Senate: Do passengers stranded by the current air hostesses strike have any recourse to the union, the airline, or the Government? In particular, I am concerned for special interest groups such as school parties, pensioners, musical groups, sporting groups and family groups on annual leave who have no opportunity to recover their losses or to make the alternative arrangements that are generally available to the business sector.

—My understanding is that there is no recourse in that regard. One of the great hardships arising from strikes in this country is that a small group of people seeking to further their own interests use the rest of the community as hostages and inflict punishment on them. One of the serious issues this community faces today is that we are not civilised in the industrial field and we have not learned how to resolve our difficulties without punishing other innocent people by using them as hostages. For example, I noted that the Labor Premier in New South Wales had something to say about this outbreak of industrial strife. I do not know of any recourse that people have. My understanding is that all travellers travel under the caveat emptor on the ticket-let the buyer beware. If there is any recourse, I will ask the Department of Business and Consumer Affairs to advise Senator Archer of it.

—by leave-I claim to have been misrepresented by Senator Carrick during Question Time. Senator Carrick, in answering a question from Senator Bonner concerning government funding of an amount of $5,000 for the provision of a homosexuality kit, stated that members of the Opposition were treating the matter as a joke. My reaction to the question was certainly no joke but a protest that Senator Bonner was using Question Time to put his own point of view. If Senator Carrick cares to check with Mr Fife's office, he will find that I have been in touch with the Minister's office on this matter both by telephone and letter and am still awaiting a reply. I take strong objection to Senator Carrick's saying that I, as a member of the Opposition, was treating this matter as a joke.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CARRICK
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-In my remarks I did not refer to Senator McLaren at all. I said that members of the Opposition were laughing and making derisory remarks. That is a simple fact. If Senator McLaren has written to the Minister, I accept that; and I accept the opportunity for him to state his view. But the facts are as I stated them: The Opposition was treating the matter as a joke.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from Senator Tate proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The failure of the government to adequately monitor and regulate the penetration of the Australian economy by foreign investors.
I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of senators required by sessional order having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the bringing forward of this matter of public importance concerning the failure of this Government adequately to monitor and regulate the penetration of the Australian economy by foreign investors, the Senate is being given an opportunity to discuss a grave matter which is central to Australia's future. I believe, and many honourable senators on both sides of the chamber realise, that what is really at stake is the very sovereignty of the Australian people not only over our economic, trading, business and commercial life-although that was so in the beginning-but also, because of the central part that that life plays in the social life of the whole nation, over the very structures and social wellbeing of the whole of Australia. Ultimately, we are dealing with the question of political sovereignty.

SPEECH.PARA: Political independence is only a sham if, going along with that notional political independence, is an attitude to foreign investors which puts our mineral, energy, manpower and skill resources at the disposal of foreign corporations and investors. If a colonial mentality is adopted in relation to the economic exploitation of the resources of this nation, inevitably and ultimately our political sovereignty will be in peril. If, as is indeed the case, this sort of claim is a recurring theme in this chamber, it is only because it is a recurring concern in the community. I believe that this matter of public importance does no more than express the concerns of people in the street. In the middle of 1978 a very eminent Australian said:

This increase in foreign ownership and control has led to concern in some quarters that foreign interests might acquire an unduly large and dominant role in the Australian economy. For myself . . . I must say I find it difficult to determine the degree of concern. I'm not sure that the man in the street really cares.

The eminent Australian who made that statement was Sir Bede Callaghan, Chairman of the Foreign Investment Review Board. If the Chairman of the Foreign Investment Review Board is so politically insensitive and not aware of the concern of ordinary Australians about this issue, it is not surprising that it has performed, with Government concurrence, in the inadequate way which will be highlighted in the speeches made this afternoon. It is a matter of concern to ordinary Australians, as one can see when one moves around the community. To make the point that it is not just a matter of ideological warfare or a matter of merely common concern, one can go to the very boardrooms of Australian companies. All honourable senators would have received in the recent recess a letter from CSR Ltd, perhaps one of Australia's leading corporations, in which concern is expressed about a matter which Senator Chipp brought to the chamber's attention in the first question asked today. In that letter from Mr Aldrich, the General Manager, Corporate Affairs, of CSR, note is taken of the way in which the international oil majors based in the United States of America are acquiring other resource or minerals companies within the United States to an extent which was outlined by Senator Chipp. No doubt he will elaborate on that. The final paragraph is very interesting. It states:

It is salutary to consider who would control Australia's future resource development in the absence of our long-standing and bipartisan foreign investment policies. These announced takeovers and speculation about further moves give emphasis to the need for Australian foreign investment policies and guidelines to exist and to be administered diligently.

Whilst that is not as explicit as may be the case in personal conversation, it is quite clear from that that the management of CSR is letting the parliamentarians of the national Parliament know that it is concerned that the guidelines that exist-they may be inadequate-are not being administered diligently in the service of ensuring that the Australian economy is not overly penetrated by foreign capital so that it is held hostage to plans and schemes of overseas shareholders. There is recognition there that ultimately our future development as a nation is at stake. It is interesting that that alerted me to the fact that Mr Gordon Jackson, who led CSR from being an agriculturally based company to becoming over recent years one of the great Australian resource developers, in an article appearing in the Australian on 21 January this year, having been named by that newspaper as Australian of the Year, said that the Government:
. . . need not be too encouraging in fields where the maturing Australian economy is becoming self-sufficient in skills and in ability to find funds and do business successfully.

The fact is, as I will demonstrate in the following moments, that the Australian Government has supinely and cravenly allowed foreign capital and foreign investors to move into fields which are quite adequately able to be developed to the benefit of the Australian people by Australian investors and Australian companies. One need go no further than the resources development projects in this country to make the point that was made by Gordon Jackson in that article when he said:

The Australian economy has matured markedly since the slogans about the virtues of foreign investment were first coined. Today there are several large Australian companies, experienced and confident, which have the capacity to take the leading position in major projects for the development and local processing of Australian resources.

So we have a combination of views-from the man in the street and from the leading Australian boardrooms-that the Government is inadequately protecting the Australian economy from being taken over in many respects by persons whose allegiance is other than directly to Australian society.

The Foreign Investment Review Board is operating under guidelines which are now almost totally discretionary. I will give one very brief example. In the uranium field we were told that foreign investors would not be allowed to buy into our uranium projects except to the extent of some 25 per cent. In other words, 75 per cent Australian equity would be required. But the Government has allowed, for example, in relation to Yeelirrie arrangements, 75 per cent ownership by the Western Mining Corporation; 10 per cent ownership by Urangesellschaft Australia Pty. Ltd., and 15 per cent ownership by Esso Exploration and Production Australia Inc. This arrangement is in terms allowing it to be said that there is 75 per cent Australian equity. However, 35 per cent of the capital costs of the Western Mining Corporation are being met by Esso and 35 per cent of the product is guaranteed to Esso. There is a very clear example of how there has been a manipulation, a modification, a total distortion of the guidelines which have been heralded by this Government as being so important in securing the future of Australia's resources, particularly uranium, for the Australian people.

It is quite difficult to ascertain properly the performance of the Foreign Investment Review Board, except to say that the number of applications it has rejected is a mere decimal fraction of those it has considered. But it can be said that the policies adopted by that Foreign Investment Review Board are unknown to this chamber. There is no requirement that its decisions be made known. There is no knowledge of the criteria upon which it acted when it does make known its decisions. In that respect the Government is merely being entirely consistent with its refusal, for example, to make statistics available to the elected representatives of the people on the penetration of our economy by foreign investors. It is well known that in mid-1978 the Treasurer, Mr Howard, ordered a complete blackout-it could only have been politically motivated-on the compilation by the Australian Bureau of Statistics of figures which would enable an assessment to be made of the penetration by foreign investment of the various areas of the Australian economy. It used to be the case that that Bureau would undertake a survey of some 200 leading manufacturing companies and the 20 leading enterprises in all other fields. The Government ordered the disbandment of that unit within the Bureau of Statistics, so there can be no exact monitoring by this Parliament or by the Australian people of that penetration.

I take up the point made by Mr Gordon Jackson that the Government should not allow foreign investment in fields where Australian enterprise is equal to the occasion. I will just very briefly mention three areas where the Government has failed to take note of that admonition, which is only one of common sense and national pride and dignity. In the area of the provision of food to the Australian people, for many years we have been used to such well-known labels as Kraft, Carnation, Nestle and so on on our shelves competing with those of Petersville and other Australian companies. But we now have the situation where, for example, Marrickville Holdings Ltd, which showed tremendous enterprise in the post-war period in Australia-changing the eating habits of Australians, creating an oilseed industry really within Australia, in other words, developing the margarine industry-has been bought out by Unilever in such a way that Marrickville Holdings is now left with five bowling alleys as its particular contribution to Australia's life.

But what is more disturbing-and this is in line with the point made by Senator Chipp in his question this afternoon-is the fact that during the Easter recess the Government gave permission to Caltex and BP to operate food retail outlets in Australia. What is it in the management expertise and knowledge of energy and resource development by these companies which makes them peculiarly apt to provide retail food outlets throughout Australia? There will be a $10m investment by these companies in the coming months to provide food retailing outlets, in conjunction with their petrol retailing enterprises throughout Australia, in a way which can only imperil, damage and ultimately lead to the destruction of many hundreds, if not thousands, of small Australian corner shops. What is it, in the Government's foreign investment policy, which allows permission to be given for this sort of activity which, as I have said, must be destructive?

TALK.START.PARA: —But it is not within the power of the Federal Government. It is for the local government authority to approve such a change in a development.

—The fact is that the Foreign Investment Review Board needed to give its permission for the Caltex and British Petroleum companies to become involved in these new ventures. The permission is contained in a Press release of 22 April by the Treasurer. That Press release makes very clear the role of the Federal Government in this matter. What I am saying is that we are already becoming conscious of the manner in which the oil companies, flush with funds, will try to penetrate not only Australia's mineral and energy resource projects but also every other area of economic, business and trading activity which appears to them to be profitable. No one can make a pretence that Australian enterprise is not able to provide food retail outlets for the Australian people.

SPEECH.PARA: There is a link between that matter and the next area of penetration by foreign investment to which I refer. It is an area which needs no such foreign capital. Jack Massey left the Kentucky Fried Chicken organisation in the United States in 1970, having created a $500m empire of some 3,000 stores throughout the United States. He then switched his attention to private hospitals. The Hospital Corporation of America, which he helped to create, is now carrying out the same investment programs in Australia. I think there is a very large ethical question as to whether the health care of Australians should be at the mercy of firms or enterprises which establish hospitals merely, solely and only for profit.

TALK.START.PARA: —Subsidised by the taxpayers.

—That is right. Australia has many private hospitals. They form a proud part of our health care programs. Some have a charitable base and some are set up by groups of local physicans in order to provide facilities for their patients. But this is a new phenomenon. United States hospital multinationals are moving into Australia in order to get rates of return on their investment which are now being denied to them in the United States.

SPEECH.PARA: I am indebted to Senator Justin O'Byrne for his series of questions and probing speeches in the Senate which have brought this matter to the attention of the Australian public. Dr Thomas Frist, President of the Hospital Corporation of America, has been reported as saying that government regulation of hospitals in the United States remains his chief concern and that projects in Australia are part of the company's plan to develop foreign markets in case the United States Government and State governments in that country apply controls which severely limit the profitability of domestic hospital operations. Their interest is in sheer profitability. This Government is permitting Australia's health care to be put at the mercy of multinational corporations whose interest is solely one of obtaining profit. They are establishing many hospitals and taking over many existing hospitals, not only medical and surgical hospitals but also psychiatric hospitals. I say that that raises a very large ethical question.

Of concern also is the takeover by foreign investors of Australian agricultural land. I have always thought well of the old adage that the owner's footprints are the best fertiliser that one can get on any property. But in Australia we are reaching a situation where many hundreds of thousands of hectares are being taken over by foreign capital. It is a fact that in the financial year 1979-80 over $100m of foreign capital was used to buy up an area of farming land in Australia equal to the size of Tasmania. That sort of trend is beginning to worry many people. I have here-it is not the Illwarra Mercury-the Queensland Country Life published in Brisbane on 16 April 1981. The bold headline reads: 'Farm ''takeover'' ' and the subheadline states:
Foreigners 'buy up' Australia as an investment deal.

It is very clear that in Queensland, as in many other States in Australia, representatives of graziers' associations and stock and farmers' organisations are becoming extremely concerned at the amount of agricultural land in Australia being taken over by foreign investors. I know, for example, that the Queensland grain growers have put a spotlight on this particular movement within our economy.

We have a situation in which once again this trend may very well be linked to the surplus of dollars available to energy companies. There will be competition for Australia's agricultural land in a way which I know is of great interest to the Australian Democrats. There will be competition between using that land to produce agricultural products and food to feed Australia and the hundreds and millions of people who may be dependent on our agricultural lands in years to come and the use of that land to produce the biomass to provide alternative fuels when crude oil stocks dwindle around the world. That competition for land in itself will force up the prices. But it is overseas investors who are proving adept at seeing the opportunity, getting in and paying the price now. There is no mechanism-in fact, Mr Howard has said that he will not introduce a mechanism-to monitor the purchase of land in Australia, particularly where it falls below the $250,000 per purchase level. Of course, one only needs to buy up several parcels of land, each costing less than $250,000 to escape the rigours of any inquiry-if they are rigorous at all-by the Foreign Investment Review Board. As I say, as very few applications have ever been knocked back, one wonders whether it is to submit to any great torment to go before the Foreign Investment Review Board.

The use of agricultural land in Australia, the provision of food and the provision of health care are examples of areas where there can be no argument that Australia needs particular management skills, the provision of capital and the provision of technology in line with the normal arguments in favour of foreign investment being encouraged in this country. There may be situations, particularly in our resource development, in which such foreign investment needs to supplement investment which can be raised within the Australian economy or overseas by Australian-owned companies using those resources as security for loans obtained overseas. That is, of course, the preferable way for these resource projects to be financed.

In conclusion, I state that the whole thrust of this matter of public importance is to express the concern that Australia must not become a dependency of overseas capital. That spectre, I believe, is emerging. It is sensed by every ordinary Australian. The Government is failing to take note of that concern and unrest within the country; it does so at its peril. It ought to give a very firm undertaking that it will monitor and make available statistics as to the penetration of foreign capital into our economy and, knowing that, then put forward firm and stringent regulations to control and modify the depredations of foreign capital within our trading and commercial life and hence in the whole social life of the nation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — (Victoria-Minister for Finance) (3.50)-Senator Tate has put forward a matter of public importance relating to foreign investment in the Australian economy. The Government welcomes the discussion of this important issue. It is an important issue, and I think the manner in which it was raised by Senator Tate allows us to have discussion of the matters that he has mentioned. In particular, Senator Tate referred to the sovereignty of Australia being at risk from foreign investment or our political independence being at risk. We would want to have the widest ranging discussions on these matters and involve the Australian community in such discussions. I speak as someone who spent a most interesting period-some 8 years ago-of my service in the Senate as a member of the Senate Select Committee on Foreign Ownership and Control. At that time foreign investment in Australia was developing as an interest of national significance and importance. I think that those who have an interest in the matter can see the work that was done in that Senate Committee and its relevance at that time and perhaps compare that with what has transpired in the last 10 years.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government welcomes foreign investment in Australia because of the contribution that it can make to the development of the Australian economy. It is our policy to encourage foreign investment on the basis that it recognises the needs and the aspirations of the Australian community. I ought to say that the basic approach under the coalition Government's policy is to examine certain foreign investment proposals to ensure that they do harmonise with Australia's interests and with the concerns that were mentioned by Senator Tate. Proposals are considered against a broad criteria which take into account economic, social and other national interests. These matters must be studied when consideration is being given to foreign investment by the Foreign Investment Review Board.

Some comments were made by Senator Tate with regard to the activities of the Foreign Investment Review Board. He expressed some concern with regard to the way in which decisions are made by that body as an instrument of government. I think it ought to be said that a very comprehensive guide is produced for investors. It sets out the requirements of the various categories of investment. There need be no doubt about information, guidelines or requirements of government with regard to investment in the various sectors. There may be some time later to look at some of those but at the moment let me just say that if we are looking at the natural resources sector, there are guidelines for Australian equity participation. The Government expects that new projects for the mining and production of uranium would have 75 per cent Australian equity and to be Australian controlled. Where this 75 per cent Australian equity is clearly unobtainable, and that is after time is given for this to be pursued and attractive proposals put forward as ways of encouraging Australian investment, alternative proposals are considered. Uranium has been regarded as a special case. If the 75 per cent Australian equity is unavailable, the project would need to be of significant economic benefit to Australia. There would then be required at least a 50 per cent Australian equity, and Australian participants would be given the major role in determining the policy of the project. So a very special case has been created with regard to equity of Australians in this important development.

When we are talking about other natural resources projects, the goal is a 50 per cent Australian equity together with at least 50 per cent of board voting strength being held by Australian interests. Again, there is flexibility. Projects may be approved with less than 50 per cent Australian equity, provided they are not contrary to the national interest, if Australian equity is not available on reasonable terms and conditions. It may be recalled that we introduced naturalisation provisions to the foreign investment policy to offer a framework and an incentive to foreign companies with a substantial level of Australian ownership in order to introduce additional Australian equity.

The Foreign Investment Review Board, which was established in 1976, advises the Government on all matters that relate to foreign investment. Very active advice is sought and given, and that is pursued. I do not have time in this debate today to go into all the details of the way in which that matter is pursued, but I can certainly say as a member of Cabinet that where we are looking specifically at a new proposal or development of a proposal with regard to our natural resources, there is a great deal of discussion. In particular, there is an emphasis placed on attracting Australian investment in our own development of these natural resources areas.

I think it is probably worthy of comment that a statement was made recently by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Hayden) on existing Australian businesses. It is also worth noting the operation of the Foreign Takeovers Act in this connection. That Act requires non-residents or foreign-controlled corporations or businesses to notify the Government of proposals to acquire or increase a substantial interest in a company. In order for proposed foreign acquisitions of Australian businesses to be approved, foreigners must demonstrate to the Government that their acquisitions would not be contrary to Australia's national interest. If we are talking about real estate investment-Senator Tate mentioned this area of investment-the Government is concerned that foreign interests should not engage in speculative real estate investment without accompanying benefits to the Australian economy. Again, in the booklet I mentioned titled A Guide for Investors 1981 there is a section on real estate. Requirements in that field of investment are given as a guide for those who are seeking to invest in this country. All proposals that are examinable are considered in the light of their expected benefits to the Australian economy, having regard to the level of Australian participation in ownership and control of the business.
