Overall, the total number of all foreign investment proposals examined by the Foreign Investment Review Board and decided by the Government in 1979-80 was just over 1,100, of which 757 were approved without conditions, 329 were approved subject to conditions, and 20 proposals were rejected. In addition, 360 proposals were found not to require approval under the Foreign Takeovers Act or the foreign investment policy. Total expected investment foreshadowed by proposals approved during 1979-80 was $5,808m-well above the $3,521m recorded in the previous year. The foreign investment policy of the Government enables comprehensive coverage of foreign investment activities in this country. It enables the Government to take action to reject or approve, subject to conditions, any proposed investment that may not be in Australia's best interests. With regard to the monitoring of foreign investment, the Review Board is kept informed of the on-going operations of foreign businesses.

Senator Tate mentioned the discontinuance of the Bureau of Statistics surveys on overseas ownership and control. In 1978 the Statistician made an assessment of the relative priorities within his Bureau, given the resources that were available to him, and it was decided to discontinue the surveys on overseas ownership and control.

TALK.START.PARA: —Decided by whom?

— The decision was taken by the Statistician. Perhaps, I ought to add that the decision to discontinue the surveys was taken by the Statistician and was supported by the Government, after considering the availability of foreign investment data from other sources. For example, the Foreign Investment Review Board examines and monitors foreign investment proposals that fall within the ambit of the Foreign Takeovers Act or other areas of the foreign investment policy. In addition, the Board, as appropriate, keeps in touch with the activities of foreign companies in Australia by monitoring progress in the implementation of proposals and ensuring that the conditions required have been complied with. Other sources are available that give a measure of the level of foreign ownership. Figures on foreign investment flows are available, as are figures on the proportion of company income payable overseas. Other statistical information is available, through the Bureau of Statistics, on the levels of equity in Australian industry held by foreigners and stocks of foreign investment by industry. A number of measurements could be quoted with regard to this.

SPEECH.PARA: I think some concern was expressed about either monitoring or review. It ought to be said that, given that around 1,000 foreign investment proposals are dealt with each year, it would be impracticable to institute follow-up checks in respect of all of them. The costs of that sort of detailed procedure could become prohibitive. The Foreign Investment Review Board and its Executive are in frequent contact with the parties to proposals and, through correspondence and discussion, follow up conditional approvals as may be necessary and, particularly in the case of the larger and more sensitive foreign investment proposals, a continuing contact is developed. However, in many cases the parties to proposals are required to report periodically to the Board on progress in the implementation of their proposals and in satisfying the conditions that are applied to their approval. As I have said, some approvals are given subject to satisfaction of specific conditions.

With regard to ensuring that claim benefits are realised, in most cases the benefits are inherent in the proposals put forward rather than additional features designed to obtain government approval for the proposals, and it is in the commercial interests of the parties to ensure that these benefits are realised. From the period July 1979 to October 1980, 11 new natural resource development projects were approved. Nine of these projects provided for at least the required level of Australian equity-that is, 50 per cent-while the remaining two projects were required as a condition of approval to meet the guideline level before production commenced. In other words, they had some time in which they could achieve that Australian equity. Of the 17 new coal projects that were approved to the end of 1979-80 and were examined under the foreign investment policy, 11 met the Australian equity participation guidelines, two were approved with less than 50 per cent Australian equity, two were rejected, and two were approved at the exploration stage only. So there are different steps of approval that can be taken if there is concern for the national interest or the participation of Australians in natural resource development.

It could be said that there is a great difference between the Opposition's attitude on foreign investment and that of the Government. Sometimes when speaking to particular groups the Opposition makes it clear that it acknowledges that some foreign investment is necessary and that there are benefits from it. Perhaps it is also stated at times that these matters are approached very differently by the two main political parties. However, I think that there is an attitude in this country of public acceptance of foreign investment policy. It was stated by Senator Tate that Australian people were concerned about it. I hope that that is a healthy interest in the development of our resources. I do think that there is public acceptance of the need for foreign investment. There is a public recognition--

TALK.START.PARA: —In some cases.

— I think that is right. There is a recognition of the need for foreign investment to add to the savings of the Australian community to enable development to be undertaken. I believe that the policy has been accepted as being fair and reasonable. It is one that I think is understood more clearly by those in foreign countries who seek to invest here. The essential aim in the features of this policy have remained unchanged for over five years under the present Government. I think that investors understand and accept this policy as being one that is sustainable in the long term. They appreciate that there is not an open door approach, and that an open door approach would not be acceptable to the Australian community and therefore would not be sustainable in the long term. In other words, if this became a political issue and there were a stop-go policy, if foreign investment were attracted and developments were not able to be completed, it would be very detrimental to the development of the economic resources that become available to the Australian people.

SPEECH.PARA: In the past 10 years-I think it is important to state this because, with some of the things that were said by Senator Tate, there may be no understanding of the size of foreign investment in this country-foreign investment has accounted for about 10 per cent of national savings. It is significant that 10 per cent of foreign investment is accounted for in national savings. The annual supplement to domestically generated resources which Australia derives from abroad runs on average at about 2 per cent to 3 per cent of gross domestic product. So if we are talking about sovereignty and political independence, those figures of 10 per cent of national savings and an average of 2 per cent to 3 per cent of gross domestic product ought to be seen in the context of responsible policy which needs to be pursued. Without continuation of the supplement that I have mentioned, the present pattern and level of economic activity and living standards could not be fully sustained. Foreign investment has increased Australia's access to up to date technology and managerial skills which are essential if Australia is to maintain its competitive position in the world. Foreign investment also brings to this country commercial links and it offers access to new markets and financial arrangements. It has played, and I believe it will continue to play, a major role in the development and diversification of the Australian economy. This development can only have beneficial effects on employment opportunities and regional development, exports, foreign exchange reserves, import substitution and competition and provide a wider range of products or services.

When we are talking about foreign investment we are talking also about our ability to develop the Australian economy, to create new jobs and to raise the standard of living of all Australians. We are talking in particular about our capacity to finance the mineral development which is under way and which is within our reach. The problem with an alternative approach to foreign investment is that it could undermine the basis on which we are able to enhance that development. Relating that to the subject of this discussion, I ought to say that not all sections of the Australian Labor Party are adopting a negative approach to development. The development and decentralisation taking place in New South Wales under the Wran Government are striking confirmation of the need for foreign investment. Recently, the New South Wales Government published a document entitled 'Development Projects in New South Wales' in which the Honourable Don Day, the responsible Minister, gave a graphic illustration of the benefits of a resources boom for that State and for Australia. Among other things, that publication of the New South Wales Government states:

Although the percentage of local and overseas content will vary for individual projects, it is likely that between 70 and 80 per cent of the total capital cost of projects planned in New South Wales will be spent locally.

The picture, as it emerges from this publication, is of foreign capital coming into Australia under the strictest of guidelines-that is, with Australian equity, Australian management and majority Australian partnerships-and bringing with it the highest skills and technology and new employment opportunities for our young people and for those who have the skills useful in the development of resource projects.

When the Labor Party was last in government investment in mining and resource development collapsed and petroleum exploration ceased. It is probable that in some sector of the ALP there is a policy that there ought to be more direct government involvement in the development of resources. This would be at the expense of the Australian taxpayers. Labor in government would be using funds compulsorily extracted from the people, through taxation or in other ways in areas in which private enterprise can carry out the function and assist in development. The proposals of the ALP to expand the functions of the Foreign Investment Review Board would probably again frighten off foreign investment in Australia, and this at a time when it is being shown that great benefits can accrue from this investment provided the guidelines are adhered to and there is a policy that observes the requirements for Australian participation in this development.

Given the importance of foreign investment to this development, I simply want to say that the policy of the Government is designed to serve the interests of the Australian community. It has enhanced the development of the Australian economy and it will ensure that the great resources development which is now taking place will benefit all Australians. I welcome the opportunity to discuss this important matter in the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I compliment Senator Tate for the manner in which he introduced this matter for discussion and Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle for the way in which she responded on behalf of the Government. However, I am bound to say that the response by Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle on behalf of the Treasurer (Mr Howard) does not satisfy the Australian Democrats. We are discussing as a matter of public importance the failure of the Government adequately to monitor and regulate the penetration of the Australian economy by foreign investors. I was very taken with the speech by Senator Tate, particularly the piece of philosophy-a bit home spun-which he injected into it. I will paraphrase what he said.

SPEECH.PARA: He said: 'In this country we seem to have, on behalf of the Government, a colonial mentality towards foreign investment which puts our political sovereignty at risk'. Is there not basic truth in that statement? If we do have a colonial mentality towards foreign investment-if we say that foreign investment is inevitable, that it must come here, that it does not matter whether the foreign investors and multinational corporations own most of our industries as we cannot do anything about it-at a time of crisis our political sovereignty would be put at risk because the governments of this country would not make the decisions concerning our resources and our businesses; those decisions would be made in the foreign board rooms. Unhappily, the sort of colonial mentality that Senator Tate referred to seems to be shared by Sir Bede Callaghan, the Chairman of the Foreign Investment Review Board. I will have something to say about that in a moment. He said, as mentioned by Senator Tate, that his view on foreign takeovers and foreign ownership of Australian industry was that the man in the street could not care less, or words to that effect. If that is the view of the Chairman of this Board, one can understand some of the rather quaint remarks in the report of 1979-80 which I shall read in a moment.

Why should Senator Tate and people on this side of the chamber be concerned about the failure of the Government adequately to monitor and regulate the penetration of the Australian economy by foreign investors? I have mentioned the figures on foreign investment three times in the Senate this year and I will do so again and again to try to impress on the man in the street that this is a serious question because our political sovereignty could well be at risk. I will quote from the United Nations publication Transnational Corporations in World Development, New York 1978. I apologise for not being able to cite later figures but, as Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle has just conceded, a couple of years ago the Government disbanded that section of the Australian Bureau of Statistics which kept figures on foreign takeovers in Australia. This publication says that 55 per cent of all mining ventures in Australia are owned by overseas companies. I would ask Senator Lajovic, whom I respect and who will follow me in this discussion, whether, as a good, stout, sturdy Australian, it gives him no cause for concern to know that 55 per cent of all mining ventures in Australia are owned and operated by foreign companies? I shall also mention the figures for the ownership of other industries. Thirty-six per cent of our manufacturing industry, 48 per cent of our service industries, 62 per cent of our chemical, coal, rubber and petroleum industries, 100 per cent of our motor vehicle industries and 91 per cent of our oil refineries are owned and operated by multinationals. Seventy-four per cent of all oil exploration in this country is done by foreigners-multinationals. Eighty-one per cent of our tin production and 62 per cent of our mineral sands projects are in the hands of foreigners. Rather quaintly, 51 per cent of all our advertising agencies are now operated and owned by foreigners. I will have something more to say about that in a moment.

We have been informed by the Government of a $29 billion resources boom in the 1980s. I will not quibble with that figure today except to say that it would be a useful exercise for someone to find out exactly to what extent Australians-the man and woman in the street-will in fact benefit from that $29 billion boom. Today I will be strongly critical of the Foreign Investment Review Board. I am appalled at the latest report. According to the report, the Board examined 1,466 foreign investment proposals during the last financial year-say 1,500 proposals. Of these proposals 360 did not require approval under the various Acts, 757-that is well over half-were approved without conditions, 329 were approved subject to conditions, and 20 out of 1,500 were rejected. That represents 1.4 per cent.

This Board is the Government's watchdog in regard to foreign intrusion into Australian industry. The Democrats say that is not good enough. I place these figures on record. On the one hand, payments totalling $1,547m for acquisitions of shares and assets, and prospective new investment expenditures totalling $4,261m were envisaged in the proposals which were approved. On the other hand, payments totalling only $38m for acquisitions of shares and assets, and prospective new investment expenditure of only $450m were envisaged in the proposals which were rejected. The point is that not only was the percentage of rejected applications 1.4 per cent, but also the amount of money involved in those which were approved was infinitesimal.

I wish to read something to the Senate and to those people who are listening. I will play a little party game with the Senate and with people listening. I will not divulge the source of what I read until I conclude. But I ask people listening and honourable senators to try to figure out what sort of organisation would put this in its annual report. I give a clue. It could be the 1980 report of an American corporation seeking to quietly acquire ownership in Australian businesses. The report contains a nice chummy success story of the Americans in regard to private hospitals. I share Senator Tate's concern. He wondered about the ethical nature of foreigners coming into this country and making money out of the chronically ill in private hospitals and being allowed to take over our hospital services and show massive profits. The joke is that they would not be able to make profits out of the terminally ill or out of the sick unless it was for massive Government subsidies paid and funded by the Australian taxpayer under our national health scheme. In regard to the acquisition of private hospitals the report states:
In total,-
That is for the year-

19 applications by United States firms to invest in private hospitals in Australia have been approved in terms of the foreign investment policy. Foreign investment approvals in this industry were expected to lead to investment of $45m.
The report goes on to state:
The companies concerned are also required to admit a minimum of 35 per cent local equity into their Australian operations within three years.

This report makes very pleasant reading for officers of an American multinational company or a wealthy American group which wants to make a profit out of the dying and the sick in Australia. In respect of advertising agencies the report states:

Takeovers of advertising agencies reflect a number of industry characteristics including relative ease of entry and attractive prices payable by the larger agencies for agencies with growth potential. During the past two years, eleven takeover proposals of Australian-owned agencies by foreign (mainly United States-owned) firms have been approved. In 1979, almost 75 per cent of agency billings accrued to the top twenty agencies, of which six were wholly Australian-owned. About one-third of gross income generated by these agencies during 1979 accrued to Australian equity investment. Among the top ten agencies, which in 1979 accounted for about 55 per cent of agency billings, the Australian share was about one-quarter.

That extract is not taken from an American document. It is not taken from the report of an American corporation seeking to quietly acquire ownership of Australian businesses. It is taken from the Foreign Investment Review Board's report of 1980. If an Australian wrote those words in this report he ought to be ashamed of himself. It brings nothing but shame to me that a group of three Australians constitute this Board-Callaghan, Pettingell and Pooley. Where is their sense of national pride when they gloat and are so proud of the easy way in which wealthy Americans and multinationals can take over our private hospitals and advertising agencies? They say in their report, almost with avid glee, that it is so easy to do. There was a response by Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle, on behalf of the Department of the Treasury, in regard to the worrying matter, about which I asked a question today and to which Senator Tate referred. I asked about the excess money-billions of it-lying on the floor of oil companies which look at mining companies to become targets for their oil industries drive to diversify. The reply I got was: 'Don't worry, Senator Chipp. Everything is all right. It is in the hands of the Foreign Investment Review Board'. To jog the mind of the moron who wrote this report and of the so-called Australians who approved the words, I use an Australian expression which might be familiar to them: 'Why do they not wake up to themselves?' There is a march on Australian ownership of our industries.

I think it is significant that a highly respected Australian company, CSR Ltd, should point out the way in which mining companies are buying up, with their billions of dollars of petty cash, companies such as Amax Exploration (Aust) Inc., St Joe Minerals Corporation, and the Kennecott Corporation. I think it is significant that CSR sent this not just to the Cabinet, not just to Ministers, not just to members of the Liberal Party but to all members of Parliament to awaken them to the dangers which lie ahead in this field. I warn those people concerned with the championing of foreign takeovers of private hospitals that this will be subject to a searching examination in the Senate in the very near future, particularly in regard to some of the applications-why they have been approved, the ownership and the names of companies which have been taking over private hospitals-and why they have been changed to suit someone's convenience. I will be wanting answers as to why the Foreign Investment Review Board allowed those changes to take place.

The situation is verging on the ridiculous. Either the FIRB is not doing its job properly or the Foreign Takeovers Act is defective, or both. Why bother having such a Board if such a small proportion of foreign investment proposals is subject to rejection? I conclude by pleading with the Government to do several things. Will it look at the question of double tax on the dividends of the small investor to give the small investor an opportunity of investing in public companies? Will it again look at a resources tax? Will it look again at some way in which to tighten up its woefully inadequate foreign investment guidelines before it is too late?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lajovic Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Chipp said that he knew I was concerned about the people of this country and how its industries were being taken over by foreign investment. But I would like to answer the honourable senator by telling him and everyone who may be listening to the debate that I am even more concerned about the standard of living of Australians, a standard which is one of the highest in the world. It is one that we are all used to and one which has been achieved by employing a great deal of foreign investment. If we did not have foreign investment I would like to know how we would obtain the money to develop industry and to develop exploration for mineral resources. I ask Senator Chipp where he would get the money to do all these things.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Tate referred to political independence and the colonial mentality. I wonder what Mr Wran, the Premier of the premier State of Australia would say about that? He has been gallivanting around the world, telling us that he is out to sell New South Wales, a task which he is achieving quite effectively. If the level of foreign investment is as bad as Senator Tate and the socialists claim, I wonder why Premier Wran goes abroad and tries to sell New South Wales-which, as I say, he has done quite effectively. I do not have before me figures on the amount he has sold, but according to the Press, he has sold quite a lot.

I am convinced that local industries are quite able to do the job. I hold local industry in very high regard, but ask: Where will it get the money with which to expand? Returning to the subject of socialism-I really enjoy talking about the socialists-how strange it is that in a typically socialist country such as Yugoslavia, from 1968 to the present, one-quarter of the total investment in enterprises has been foreign investment. That has happened in a socialist country. We have heard today typical socialist rhetoric. When the socialists are in opposition they oppose everything. When they are in government, they act differently. If the Australian Labor Party were permitted to go through with its proposals concerning foreign investment, that would have a substantial effect on the economy of this country. It is clear that the policy of the socialists and of the Labor Party is one which has a superficial appeal. In principle, Australia would continue to obtain a substantial supplement to its domestic resources, but without the implications for foreign ownership and control of its industries and resources that private foreign capital entails. Under the so-called socialist plan for foreign investment, the taxpayer would have to contribute heavily in order to supplement the financing of the projects necessary to pursue the development of this country in the way in which we are accustomed and in the way in which the Australian people want it to take place. No one can deny that, under the Fraser Government, Australia has achieved an economic stability and success that is the envy of Western countries.

In today's Press we read the headline, 'Caltex offers $90m local equity'. That relates to investment in the development of Australian industry. We read of that offer to Australians to buy an equity in Caltex and on the same day read, though not in the same newspaper, a quite small article which is headed, 'TAB set to top $1 billion mark'. The reference is to the New South Wales Totalizator Agency Board. The article states:
The New South Wales TAB will crack the magic $1 billion mark in turnover in the 1980-81 season.
Mr Robertson--
He is the general manager of New South Wales TAB-
said the TAB was now holding $20m a week.

I repeat, that in New South Wales $20m a week is being diverted to this form of so-called investment. If we had that degree of national pride which ought to exist in this country but unfortunately does not, we would be able with such an investment to buy in two weeks the hospitals to which Senator Chipp has referred. The total investment in those hospitals-I do not know their number-is $45m. I repeat that the so-called investments in TAB in two weeks would buy all of them.

I turn now to the statistics concerning the so-called investments in TAB, with licensed bookmakers and in lotteries. The figures are from the Year Book Australia 1980. In 1975-76 the total sum invested throughout Australia in betting and lotteries was $3,715m. In 1976-77 it was $4,099m. In 1977-78 it was $4,488m. Thus, in three years, Australians have made so-called investments in gambling and lotteries totalling some $12,000m. That figure merely covers the forms of gambling that are recognised by the statistics. How many bets were placed during that time with illegal bookmakers? We do not know.

TALK.START.PARA: —Twice that.

—Senator Tate says that twice as much was devoted to that form of investment. If we assume that it was only half as much in a period of three years some $18,000m was invested in gambling and lotteries.

SPEECH.PARA: The statistics on direct foreign investment in Australian enterprises show that in 1975-76 a total of $579m-or one-sixth of the total amount spent on gambling during that year-was so invested. In 1976-77 total foreign investment in our enterprises was $1,074m, while at the same time we invested four times as much in gambling. In 1977-78 total foreign investment in our enterprises was $1,008m, while we invested $4,488m in gambling. Anybody who talks to me about buying back the farm or about our doing something that we should not do by allowing foreign investment should consider those figures. They would realise that if we in this country looked at our priorities in a different way and were interested in national pride, we would have the money to develop our local industries without asking for foreign investment if we wanted to do so. But who will do it? Will anybody say to the Australian people: 'Next Saturday do not go and bet. Put that money into the development of an Australian project'?

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Keating will do that.

—I do not know when that will happen. I know only one thing: All the critics of our foreign investment policies should consider the figures I have just cited and should be realistic. They should understand and appreciate that the tremendous foreign investment we are fortunate to get because of our economic and political stability is helping to sustain the way of life and the standard of living to which we have become accustomed. We intend to continue those policies, regardless of what the socialists say, because the socialists have only one aim-to make sure that people's living standards come down, that they become destitute. The socialists would then be able to say: 'Look how the capitalist system is failing. We will do it better'. If we look at the records of all so-called socialist countries where socialism reigns supreme we can see that the people are poorer there than anywhere else, despite all the grandstanding and grand talking about a love of humanity, a love of human beings and a love of their countrymen. But when it comes to delivering the goods, they fail miserably. I feel that the only way to sustain our standard of living is to continue our foreign investment policy, because all of us want to sustain that standard of living.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Nearly half of the speech of Senator Lajovic, who preceded me in this debate, was taken up with the delivery of a long and boring set of figures, the object of which was to support the ludicrous proposition that investment on the Totalisator Agency Board is comparable with investment in industry. I am surprised that such a proposition should come from a member of the Liberal Party. It would not be so surprising if such a proposition came from another party around this Parliament. With backbenchers such as Senator Lajovic, it is no wonder that the Liberal Party has the sorts of Ministers that it has. The great fallacy in the proposition he was putting is that when people put that $4 billion on the TAB and into other forms of gambling they expect to get back, and do in the aggregate get back, about $3.5 billion as dividends. So they are in a way comparable.

SPEECH.PARA: Foreign investment is not something to which the Australian Labor Party or, to my knowledge, the Australian Democrats are completely opposed. What is being questioned in this debate is the rate at which foreign capital is coming into the country and also the type of foreign capital which is coming into the country. The reference to a colonial mentality which was made by both the previous speakers on this side was an apt one because the mentality of this Government, both economically and politically, is and will remain colonial. It is colonial in the economic sense because the Government believes that it must have an open door policy on foreign investment, and it is colonial in the political sense because it believes no Australian is fit to occupy the position of Governor-General and it has to go to Prince Charles.

The rationale in the past for foreign investment-a rationale which is still spuriously advanced by members of the Government-was that it brings new technology and entrepeneurial skills into the country. Whatever validity that may once have had has now been largely wiped out and, if present trends continue, will soon be entirely wiped out. Equity, portfolio or takeover investment, terms which are almost interchangeable, comprised 10 per cent of total foreign investment in 1979-80 and 39 per cent of total foreign investment in the first six months of 1980-81. In other words, there was a fourfold increase in the proportion of foreign investment which has been directed towards the takeover of existing enterprises or portfolio investment in existing enterprises.

The following figures are provided by W. D. Scott and Co. Pty Ltd. In the calendar year 1980 institutional loan and equity investment from overseas-that is, new investment-which was directly invested increased by $84m over the figure for 1979, and the indirect investment of this type increased by $1,109m over the figure for 1979. If we look at the Bureau of Statistics figures, where the breakdown is somewhat finer, we find that portfolio investment in corporate equities, which in the whole of the 1979-80 financial year stood at $623m, has reached $610m in the first six months of the present financial year. In other words, corporate equity investment for the first six months of this financial year was running at double the rate that obtained in the previous financial year. Total capital inflow for the nine months ended March 1980 was only $600m. This year it has climbed to $3.9 billion. That is, almost $4,000m of foreign capital has flowed into the country in the first nine months of this year.

A significant contributor to this alarmingly high inflow of foreign funds is, of course, the built-in inertia of the Foreign Investment Review Board. Of the 5,000 applications which have gone before the FIRB since its creation almost five years ago, no fewer than 3,800 have been applications for takeovers of existing enterprises; and only 45 of those applications, or a little over one per cent, have been rejected. Recent action in the courts regarding attempts-unsuccessful attempts, I regret to say-by the Commissioner of Taxation to levy tax in lieu of the tax avoided by such companies as Comalco Ltd through transfer pricing operations draws attention to the inherent dangers of enabling Australian enterprises to be controlled in the managerial sense from overseas. Yet this Government has made virtually no moves to restrict this trend, which is growing at an alarming rate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Section 136 has been rewritten.

—It is being rewritten! It is about time members of the Liberal Party, even Senator Watson, learnt that, given the persistent rulings of the High Court and given the way in which over the last five or six years the High Court has emasculated the avoidance provisions of the existing taxation Act, the only way of dealing with it is with a clear, credible threat of retrospective legislation which, once made, probably would never actually have to be enacted. The takeover of existing enterprises would be less alarming if the displaced domestic capital was productively invested. Whilst there are no absolutely reliable figures on the destination of the displaced domestic capital, it is clear that it is going substantially into real estate speculation, which has the anti-social and inflationary effect of pricing land and houses out of the reach of the great proportion of the population and raises the question of the discrimination within the existing taxation system which was touched upon by Senator Chipp.

SPEECH.PARA: If somebody decides to invest capital productively in, say, a factory-it could be some other business-and if it succeeds he will pay tax on the dividends. If it is a public company or a proprietary company the profits will be taxed as company profits and they will be taxed again as profits to the shareholder, if and when they are distributed. If a person goes into a business as a sole trader he will pay personal income tax on profits made. He also runs the risk of capital depreciation, of actually losing money either because he has been unlucky or because he has been managerially incompetent and the business fails. On the other hand, if somebody decides not to invest in productive activity and decides to speculate in land or housing, the profits gained from that speculation are tax free. It is an article of faith of this Government that those windfall profits will remain tax free.

Quite apart from equity considerations, sufficient evidence is already available on the distortion of investment decisions caused by this fundamental anomaly that profits from speculation are tax free and profits from productive investment are not. The evidence is clear enough to demand prompt action from the Government but that will not happen until this Government is replaced. What is happening in Australia, roughly, is that private domestic capital, particularly that displaced by foreign takeovers, goes into anti-social speculation. Public domestic capital is largely squandered on pork barrel projects. The Ord River scheme is a significant example from the 1960s. The editorial in today's Age, which I do not have time to read, cites numerous other examples of far more recent vintage. In fact, it cites a few of the 61 uncosted or dishonestly costed promises which were included in the last election speech of the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) for a wide variety of mostly uneconomic and almost entirely pork barrel projects designed to save the Government from the electoral defeat which it feared at that time was staring it in the face.

Instead of squandering and frittering away public capital to the extent of an incremental $2 billion, which it promised to do in that 1980 election campaign, the Government ought to be establishing a national investment fund to mobilise the individually small savings of the great bulk of Australians which could then be invested both in new projects and in holding, or preferably increasing, the Australian equity in existing projects. Given the multiple, manic obsessions of this Government-to use Mr Peacock's phrase-the massive inflow of foreign capital, which, I repeat, reached almost $4 billion in the first nine months of this financial year, will do enormous damage in the short term to the economy as well as squander the nation's birthright. Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle, as we know from experience over the last few months, knows almost nothing. She is unable to answer almost every question delivered to her. She takes the place of a postal pillar in the Senate, referring requests for information to more knowledgeable people in other places. At Question Time today Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle showed that even she knew that the massive capital inflow of nearly $700m in the month of March was the major factor in the money supply, M3, increasing by 11.7 per cent in the 12 months just passed, which is, of course, above the Government's planned target.

Whether, in fact, a money supply growth rate of that magnitude is really a problem under present circumstances is debatable. But the important point for the present is that the Government sees it as a problem largely of the Government's own making. The Government's response to that is to impose the most savage credit squeeze in history. The Australian savings bond interest rate is 12 1/4 per cent. The trading banks' prime rate is 15 per cent. The small overdraft rate is 12 1/2 per cent and the large overdraft rate is 16 1/2 per cent. All those percentages are still rising. Interest rates of that magnitude have never before been seen in Australia. For those who are forced right out of that area of borrowing and into the personal loan and fringe finance area interest rates in excess of 20 per cent are the norm. These high interest rates establish a vicious circle. The high interest rates attract hot money from overseas, as does the expectation of further revaluations of the Australian dollar. That hot money from overseas leads to more stringent application of the credit squeeze on the domestic economy via higher interest rates which, in turn, attracts more foreign borrowings. The Government has created a vicious circle and it is being fried inside it.

It is an appropriate time, I think, to reflect upon the economic perspicacity of this Government. On 10 December I issued a Press statement which said that the Government is laying the foundations for a massive credit squeeze in the autumn. As a result of that statement, I was interviewed by the Australian Broadcasting Commission radio program PM in which I repeated that statement and made a number of other comments. The ABC, as was appropriate under the circumstances, put that statement to the Treasurer (Mr Howard). John Highfield from the ABC asked:
Treasurer do you accept Senator Peter Walsh's claims that the government is laying the foundations for a credit squeeze in the autumn?
Mr Howard replied:
No certainly not I completely reject those claims, they are ill-founded speculation, there's no basis to them and it's quite irresponsible of Senator Walsh to make those claims.

The claim was that there would be a massive credit squeeze in the autumn. The response of Mr Howard, the Treasurer, the man in the Fraser Government who is supposed to understand these things-perhaps he is the best the Fraser Government has to offer; I do not rule out that possibility-was to describe that statement as ill-founded speculation and quite irresponsible. I wonder whether he stands by that comment today given that interest rates are at record levels and rising. Unless the Government, as it has so often done before, chooses to redefine what is a credit squeeze, if interest rates at record levels of 2 per cent and 3 per cent-at least for overdraft rates-above what they have ever been do not constitute a credit squeeze, I would like to know what does.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scott Sen The Hon D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: — I rise to take part in this discussion of a matter of public importance, which indeed it is. The matter relates to the alleged failure of the Government to monitor and regulate adequately the penetration of the Australian economy by foreign investors. I think in the first place that the word 'penetration' has somewhat sinister reflections about it. I think the matter of public importance would probably be better phrased if it referred to monitoring and regulating the development of the Australian economy. That is what this discussion is all about. It certainly should not be a discussion which involves itself with a whole lot of emotional concepts; it should be a discussion which leads to a real measure of enthusiasm amongst Australian people.

SPEECH.PARA: We are talking about our own country and its massive capacity and resources and, in spite of what is said from time to time, the determination of Australians across a wide board to develop those resources for two reasons and along two particular lines. Firstly, we have to ensure that the socio-economic development of this country is such that it enables every citizen of Australia to be as affluent as is humanly possible. That is the first objective. The second objective of this development surely must be referable to our responsibility to the world and in particular to the developing countries. Our quite massive resources are especially related to the important fields of energy and food and fibre production. These are basic elements for the survival and development of the developing world. Consequently all Australians should be determined that we should be following a process and policy that will enable the 14 million people of Australia to develop the massive resources of 3 million square miles as rapidly, effectively and fairly as we possibly can.

So, there should not be a conflict of ideologies in this place. There should be a determination to establish the conditions and circumstances under which Australia is developing its massive resources. We need to identify whether such conditions are meeting with a real measure of success and to identify the rapidity of the development. We need to take a view, naturally, that some areas need to be regarded with a measure of flexibility and need from time to time, to change as circumstances change. Individuals demand a whole range of activity and, consequently, whatever guidelines, determinations and statistical targets we set ourselves from time to time we will have to adjust. That is reasonable and proper and it is written very clearly into the policy of this Government.

I remind the Senate that the Government has seen an immense amount of capital coming into this country which is aimed at the development of our extraordinary resources. I do not believe that is something to be ashamed of. Australia's resource capacity is no reflection on the genius of Australians; it is merely a reflection on our geological structure. But our political stability and resource capacity are attractive enough to bring massive amounts of development capital into this country. What we, as a responsible government, have to ensure is that that capital comes into Australia in such a way that Australian equity and involvement are maintained and ensured, and that significant benefits go not only overseas but also, in the first instance, to the Australian people.

I suggest that this Government has established clearly identified guidelines in which it seeks that 50 per cent of equity, as Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle said earlier, in most development operations. Most industry in Australia should be in Australian hands, and in the more delicate area of the mining and processing of uranium there has to be an equity of 75 per cent. A measure of flexibility must, of necessity, be added to those statistics. Senator Lajovic said that the Australian people's priorities relate very much to the Totalisator Agency Board. Who are we to establish the total and absolute priorities of Australia's 14 million people? The Government has to ensure that the population of Australia is secure and that it benefits from the massive development and resources of the country.

It is essential that this developmental process shall continue within the guidelines basically set by the Government, and observed and monitored by the Foreign Investment Review Board. There has been a measure of criticism of that Board in this chamber this afternoon. Of course, whatever board, entity or organisation is discussed there will be a measure of criticism. One of the criticisms directed at the Board I find somewhat fascinating, that of all its investigations to date-it was established, I think, in 1976-it has seen fit to rule out totally only 1.4 per cent of applications. Of course, that may well be so. The obvious reason for that is that it is a board which operates with guidelines and values that are so clearly understood by the investing people, whether they be from inside or outside Australia, that unacceptable elements or objectives are seldom found within the applications. The Government has made doubly clear on numerous occasions, inside and outside Australia, the sort of Australian equity that it expects ultimately to establish, and having that in view overseas investors would be virtually crazy to put to the Review Board propositions that are hopelessly outside the guidelines. Consequently it is normal that there should be relatively few total rejections. Indeed, a very significant number of applications have to be revised to make them fit the guidelines and Government policy.

I suggest that the multinational-I speak of the foreign investment angle-in the Australian society and economy is nothing very new. There was a time when the total investment in the United States of America was foreign and virtually all Americans were foreigners. Americans have built out of that beginning a multicultural society of which they are proud and which, at least on the guidelines or yardsticks of social, economic and technological development, rates very highly in the world today. So the fact that foreigners and foreign moneys plays a part in the development of this country is nothing in itself that should be worried about. Rather it may well bring a considerable contribution to the ultimate Australian establishment, character and society or community.

I believe that the foreign investment guidelines and policies of this Government, which are looked over carefully and are continually reviewed by the Foreign Investment Review Board, are basically of very great significance for the ultimate and most rapid possible development of our country and for its position internationally. They serve to develop the country far more quickly than it would ever be able to develop alone. They serve a socio-economic purpose because they establish a circumstance in which all Australians should and must benefit. Over and above that, I believe that they are relevant in some measure to the security of this country.

It always seems strange to me to assume that significant nations-whether they be West Germany, the United Kingdom or the United States of America-are prepared to invest almost countless billions of dollars in this country and have no regard for its internal or, indeed, external security. I imagine that such a regard would be a contribution of properly controlled foreign involvement in this country. After all, the Australian Government has total control over export, for instance. That is a pretty strong control over the operation of any organisation. Surely it is reasonable to assume that foreign involvement in this country, from the point of view of development capital, in staying here and continuing to be involved in employment and technological advances, and in funding markets-many of these international organisations have very important connections to markets around the world-is relevant not only to the socio-economic stability of Australians but also to the security of the land. What investor, whether it be another honourable senator, me or a country, is interested in investing somewhere in something which has no guarantee of security at all?

As time is racing by, I conclude my remarks by referring the Senate to one or two of the results of foreign investment and development in this country, particularly by the mining companies. I think it was Senator Tate who said that 55 per cent of the mining companies are foreign owned.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was Senator Chipp.

—It was Senator Chipp. I beg the honourable senator's pardon. Let me make it clear that of 100 mining companies in this country last year a payment of $674m in tax alone was made to the Australian Treasury. There was a payment in dividends to Australian and overseas investors of nearly $400m. A further payment of $209m was made to State governments for the port and rail facilities which they provide. These companies paid $2.4 billion in wages to Australians. I do not have time to continue along these lines. I hope that I have made it clear that this country is involved with foreign investment to the extent that is necessary to develop the country's full potential. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the business of the day be called on.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle)-by leave-agreed to:

(1) That, for the purpose of choosing a person to hold the place in the Senate rendered vacant by the death of Senator John William Knight, a senator for the Australian Capital Territory, until the expiration of the term and in accordance with the provisions of the Senate (Representation of Territories) Act 1973, as amended by the Senate (Representation of Territories) Amendment Act 1980, the Senate meet with the House of Representatives in a Joint Sitting.
(2) That the place and time of the Joint Sitting be the Senate Chamber at fifteen minutes past 2 p.m. on Tuesday, 5 May 1981.
(3) That the foregoing provisions of this resolution be forwarded by message to the House of Representatives for its concurrence.
Powers, Privileges and Immunities of Senators
Motion (by Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle)-by leave-agreed to:

That the Senate resolves that it be a rule and order of the Senate that, at a Joint Sitting with the House of Representatives, pursuant to the Senate (Representation of Territories) Act 1973, as amended by the Senate (Representation of Territories) Amendment Act 1980, the proceedings are proceedings in Parliament, and that the powers, privileges, and immunities of senators shall, mutatis mutandis, be those relating to a sitting of the Senate.
Rules for Conduct of Business
Motion (by Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle)-by leave-agreed to:

(1) That the following rules be adopted for the conduct of the Joint Sitting of the Senate and the House of Representatives to choose a senator pursuant to section 9 of the Senate (Representation of Territories) Act 1973:
Matter to be Considered at the Joint Sitting

1. The purpose of the Joint Sitting shall be to choose a person to hold the vacant place in the Senate pursuant to section 9 of the Senate (Representation of Territories) Act 1973, and no other matter shall be considered at the Joint Sitting.
General Rule for Conduct of Business
2. In any matter of procedure not provided for in the following rules, the Standing Orders of the Senate, in force for the time being, shall be followed as far as they can be applied.
Chairman of the Joint Sitting
3. The President of the Senate or, in the absence of the President, the Speaker of the House of Representatives, shall be the Chairman of the Joint Sitting.
Clerks of the Joint Sitting

4. The Clerk of the Senate and the Clerk of the House of Representatives shall act as Joint Clerks of the Joint Sitting and either of them may exercise a function expressed to be exercisable by the Clerk.
Minutes of Proceedings
5. Proceedings of the Joint Sitting shall be recorded by the Joint Clerks, and such records shall constitute the minutes of proceedings of the Joint Sitting and shall be signed by the Joint Clerks.
Time Limit on Speeches
6. No Senator or Member of the House of Representatives may speak for more than 5 minutes on any proposal or question before the Joint Sitting.
Objection to Rulings of Chair

7. If any objection is taken to any ruling of the Chairman, such objection must be taken at once, and a motion of dissent, to be submitted in writing, moved, which, if seconded, shall be proposed to the Joint Sitting, and debate thereon shall proceed forthwith.
Entitlement to Vote
8. On any question arising in the Joint Sitting each Senator and Member of the House of Representatives, including the Chairman, shall have one vote.
Voting

9. Questions shall be decided by a simple majority of the Senators and Members of the House of Representatives present and voting, and, if the votes are equal, the question shall be resolved in the negative.
Choice of a Person to Hold the Vacant Place in the Senate

10. (a) A Senator or Member of the House of Representatives, addressing himself to the Chair, shall propose a person to hold the vacant place in the Senate and such proposal shall be duly seconded. When any person is so proposed the proposer shall state that such person is willing to hold the vacant place if chosen.

(b) In proposing a person to hold the vacant place in the Senate, the proposer shall declare that that person is eligible to be chosen for the Senate and that the nomination is in accordance with the provisions of sub-section 9 (3) of the Senate (Representation of Territories) Act 1973, as amended by the Senate (Representation of Territories) Amendment Act 1980.

(c) If only one person is proposed, and seconded, the Chairman shall declare that such person has been chosen to hold the place of the Senator for the Australian Capital Territory whose place has become vacant.
(d) If more than one person is proposed and seconded, the person to hold the vacant place shall be chosen by ballot. Before the ballot proceeds the bells shall be rung for three minutes.

(e) Before giving directions to proceed with the ballot, the Chairman shall ask if any Senator or Member of the House of Representatives desires to propose any other person to hold the vacant place, and no other person shall be proposed after the ballot is commenced.

(f) Each Senator and Member of the House of Representatives present shall be provided with a ballot-paper certified by one of the Joint Clerks, and shall vote by writing thereon the name of one of the persons duly proposed, and shall place the ballot-paper in the ballot-box.

(g) If two or more persons are proposed, the Chairman shall appoint a person from each House to be a scrutineer. The scrutineers, with the Joint Clerks, shall ascertain the number of votes for each of the persons duly proposed; and the scrutineers shall report the result to the Chairman.
(h) No informal vote shall be taken into account.

(i) If on the first ballot no person receives an absolute majority of the votes cast, a second ballot shall be taken, and the name of the person who receives the fewest votes at the first ballot shall be excluded; but if at the first ballot the names of only two persons are submitted and the number of votes for each such person is equal, the scrutineers shall by drawing lots determine which of such persons shall be chosen to hold the vacant place, and the person whose name shall be first drawn shall be deemed to have been duly chosen.

(j) Until one of the persons proposed obtains an absolute majority of the votes cast, or (as the case may be) is chosen by lot to hold the vacant place, successive ballots shall be taken, and at each such ballot the name of the person who receives the fewest votes at the preceding ballot shall be excluded.

(k) If on any ballot it is necessary to decide which of two or more persons is to be excluded from a subsequent ballot because of the number of votes for such persons being equal, a special ballot shall be taken at which the names of only those persons shall be submitted, and the name of the person having the fewest votes at such special ballot shall be excluded; but if on any special ballot it shall be necessary to decide which of two or more persons is to be excluded from a subsequent ballot because of the number of votes for such persons being equal, the scrutineers by drawing lots shall determine which of such persons shall be excluded, and the name of the person last drawn shall be excluded.

(1) If at any ballot, other than the first ballot or a special ballot, the names of only two persons are submitted and the number of votes for such persons is equal, the scrutineers shall, by drawing lots, determine which of those persons shall be chosen to hold the vacant place, and the person whose name is first drawn shall be deemed to have been duly chosen.

(m) As soon as any person obtains an absolute majority of the votes cast, or (as the case may be) is chosen by lot to hold the vacant place, the Chairman shall declare that such person has been chosen to hold the place of the Senator for the Australian Capital Territory whose place has become vacant.
(n) The ballot-papers shall be retained by the Clerk of the Senate, who shall be the custodian thereof.
Conclusion of Joint Sitting
11. Upon the declaration of the person chosen to fill the casual vacancy in the Senate, the Chairman shall forthwith declare the Joint Sitting closed.
(2) That a message be sent to the House of Representatives informing the House of the rules adopted by the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-The fundamental goal of this Government in the health area is to ensure that all Australians have proper access to health care services of high quality at a cost the individual and the community can afford. A large and increasing amount of scarce resources is being allocated to the health area to maintain the high quality services we have all come to expect. Clearly, if this level of quality is to be maintained, given priorities in other areas, every effort must be made to ensure that the resources allocated to the health area are used in an efficient and cost effective way. It is not an exaggeration to state that the health care delivery system could become a bottomless pit down which an ever-increasing proportion of gross domestic product could be poured without any real increase in the health standards of Australians. All of us, whether we be providers or recipients of health care, should be conscious of the cost of health services. For example, health professionals should become aware of the high cost of some individual services that they provide or seek access to when simpler procedures would be as effective. Equally individuals should become aware of the cost of the services they use by contributing to the cost of such services. Those responsible for the operation of health institutions must also be fully responsible for ensuring that they provide services on the most efficient basis possible.

SPEECH.PARA: For many years concern has been expressed about the nature and distribution of the institutions, particularly hospitals, which provide our health care services. Hospitals consume by far the greatest amount of resources allocated to health care. They are expensive institutions to run. In many cases they are not physically located to ensure easy access by the community which they serve nor do they necessarily provide the types of services required by that community. Duplication of services between hospitals exists, particularly in the area of high cost technology. Regrettably, many hospitals compete with others in an attempt to provide all services without any regard to duplication, needs, priorities or costs. If hospitals are to be used effectively, it is important that those people admitted actually require the services provided. It is important to ensure that where a person can be adequately cared for at home, appropriate support services are available. For too long hospitals generally have concentrated on providing services within the hospital rather than in the community. The Commonwealth has reacted to this and, through the Domiciliary Nursing Care Benefit and the Home Nursing Subsidy Schemes, has attempted to encourage people to remain in the community rather than be institutionalised where this was not required. More needs to be done.

The Government recognises too that private hospitals form an integral part of the hospital system in any one State. It is important that a balance between public and private hospital beds be maintained. The Commonwealth believes that any growth of private hospital beds should be consistent with overall State priorities for hospitals. The Commonwealth also recognises the important role of private doctors in providing health services in the community. In the great majority of cases general practitioners provide primary health care services on the most cost effective basis. The Government therefore believes that the important role of general practitioners should be enhanced, wherever possible, and should continue to be the first point of contact for patients with the health care system.
In order to ensure that these general objectives are met the Government believes that firm measures should be adopted so that:

(i) States fully accept their constitutional responsibility for the provision of health services and determine their own priorities as to how funds are to be allocated to the different parts of the health system.
(ii) All Australians become far more responsible for their own health care needs and lifestyle and more aware of the full cost of the health services available to them.
(iii) Special assistance schemes designed to cover people's hospital and medical bills are only available to those in genuine need, namely, eligible pensioners and the disadvantaged.
(iv) Those people in the community who can pay their own way should be required to contribute to the costs of the health services they receive-either by personal payment or through health insurance.
(v) Health insurance should be available to all at a reasonable cost and should have wide coverage in order to support the community rating principle.
(vi) Government assistance towards the health costs of those who can afford to contribute towards their health services should be restricted to those who are willing to help themselves.

(vii) The important role of the private sector of the health care delivery system should be fully acknowledged and action should be taken to ensure that the private hospital sector continues as a viable complement to the public system.
(viii) Providers of health care services should be more aware of the costs they generate.

Concern over Australia's burgeoning health bill and significant doubts as to whether the large sums of taxpayers' funds allocated to health were being spent properly led to the Commonwealth establishing the Commission of Inquiry into the Efficiency and Administration of Hospitals in 1979. The Government believes that the Commission's report has shown that the Government's concern was justified. The health care delivery system in this country is extremely complex and its many parts are inter-related. It is therefore essential that any review of a major part of that system-such as public hospitals-should be carried out in the context of the Commonwealth's overall health policy. The Government has done so over recent months. My colleague the Minister for Health (Mr MacKellar) and I believe that the Commission's report has provided a sound basis on which to develop an equitable and responsible health policy. The co-operation of all those involved in the health and care delivery system will, however, be required if that policy is to benefit all Australians.
Public Hospital Funding Arrangements

At present, under the hospital cost sharing arrangements, the Commonwealth shares with the States the agreed net costs of operating their public hospitals systems. Honourable senators will be aware that these agreements are due to expire on 30 June 1981, except for South Australia and Tasmania. The agreements with South Australia and Tasmania expire on 30 June 1985. In 1976, these agreements were re-negotiated with the States to remove the open-endedness of the original agreements negotiated by the Whitlam Government. History shows that the decision to re-negotiate the agreements was correct at a time when hospital costs were accelerating. Since 1976 growth in recognised hospital expenditure has slowed down markedly.

Despite the considerable success of these agreements in slowing down the rate of growth in hospital costs, the Jamison inquiry was highly critical of them. The inquiry said that the agreements concentrated on reimbursement of expenditure. As a result little account was taken of the relative needs within and between States for hospital and health services, their distribution and their accountability. States with the most expensive and inefficient hospital systems at the commencement of the cost-sharing arrangements received proportionately more funds than States which had attempted to move with the times, to remove wasteful and inefficient services and facilities, and to concentrate on services appropriate to the communities that they serve. As the Commission stated:
. . . the Cost-Sharing Agreements have rewarded the expensive and punished the efficient and have perpetuated rather than solved some of the main problems in Australia's health system.

I should point out also that even in those States which have made attempts to remove waste and inefficiency, there is still much more work to be done. Today, the members of the community cannot be expected continually to support, by way of taxation and their own personal expenditures, any wasteful and inefficient public hospital systems in Australia. In the face of the evidence produced by Jamison and earlier inquiries, failure by the Commonwealth to ensure that efficiencies are effected would mean that it would be abrogating its proper responsibilities. The Commonwealth cannot stand on the sidelines and see taxpayers and health fund members bearing increasing costs because of inefficiencies, inequities, and unnecessary duplication in public hospitals. On the basis of its criticisms of the cost-sharing agreements the Commission of Inquiry recommended that the agreements due to expire should not be renewed. The Government has accepted that recommendation.

In its consideration of the funding arrangements that should replace the existing hospital cost-sharing agreements the Commission found that a major factor behind such inefficiencies was the divided responsibility between the Commonwealth and States. The Commission therefore recommended that the States should be required to take up their full constitutional responsibility for the provision of health care services. The Commission also recommended that the level of Commonwealth funding for the States' health services should be altered so that the amount of funds provided was based more closely on States' needs-as determined by their respective populations and taking into account recognised measures of efficiency. The Commission recognised also that there was a need for States to be able to use health funds provided by the Commonwealth for priority areas in their health service system rather than be confined to narrow program type funding.

The Government has been considering a range of options aimed at overcoming the problems highlighted by the Commission in this vital area. It agreed with the Commission that the responsibility of the States should be more clearly defined and that they should be required to take up their full responsibilities for the provision of health services. It also agrees that a new method for determining funding levels should be introduced. In reaching this decision the Government has been mindful of the warning of the Commission of Inquiry that one should hasten slowly. Quite clearly in a situation involving hospitals where there is a large capital investment and where some communities have become used to facilities or services-even when they are not needed-dramatic changes cannot be made over night. As the Jamison report stated:
sharp, sweeping changes can be disruptive and impractical . . . much can be gained from continual small measures, rather than from sweeping structural change.

The Government has therefore decided that the funds it provides for public hospitals, the general Community Health Program and the School Dental Scheme should be included in general revenue grants. This will afford the States the greatest possible freedom as to how the moneys to be allocated are spent. There will be no requirements laid down as to the services to which they should be allocated. The States will be totally responsible for making such decisions. Further, the Government has decided that, at least for the initial period of the new arrangements, the amount to be included in the general tax sharing arrangement should be identifiable as representing the Commonwealth's contribution to the cost of the health services provided by the States.

In view of the importance of ensuring that funds for health services allocated to the States are appropriately based, the Government has also decided that the determination of an appropriate mechanism for allocating funds between States in the longer term should be referred to the Grants Commission. The Commission will be asked to look specifically at relativities between States and to design incentives for States to correct inefficiencies in their health systems. The Commonwealth firmly believes that the peoples of each State will, as taxpayers, fully support the Government's decisions since the proposed measures are designed to ensure the maintenance of the high quality health care delivery systems in Australia while protecting the position of all taxpayers by ensuring that the greatest value possible is received for each dollar spent on health services provided by the States.

I draw the Senate's attention to the fact that the Commonwealth has decided that the position of eligible pensioners and their dependants should be protected at all times under the proposed funding arrangements. The Commonwealth and the States have over many decades recognised their responsibility for eligible pensioners. The Commonwealth will continue to meet this responsibility in the hospitals area by requiring States to provide free public hospital accommodation and treatment for such pensioners. The Commonwealth will also ensure that free hospital services will continue to be provided to the disadvantaged. The Government will consult with the States on the question of appropriate administrative arrangements.

The Commonwealth holds the view that there should be consistency between the definition of the disadvantaged used by States in relation to public hospitals and that followed by the Commonwealth in relation to the bulk billed medical services provided to them. The Government believes that only eligible pensioners and their dependants and the disadvantaged as defined should be protected in this way. It further believes that all other persons should be required to contribute towards the cost of services received in institutions, particularly hospitals, and that States should take appropriate actions to ensure that they do. The Government recognises that such actions should result in increased revenues being raised for both inpatient and outpatient services, particularly if the States raise the bed day charge in public hospitals from $50 for a shared room and $75 for a private room to a level which more closely approximates the actual daily bed cost involved.

As any increases in revenue resulting from such actions would reduce the net operating cost of the States' public hospital systems, the Commonwealth is of the view that its funding in this area can be appropriately reduced on a progressive basis without jeopardising the quality and standard of care now provided in public hospitals. The new arrangements will, from the Commonwealth's point of view, apply from 1 September 1981. The Government has therefore decided that the funding to be allocated to New South Wales, Victoria, Western Australia, Queensland and the Northern Territory that represents its interest in the provision of health services should be equal to the sum necessary to maintain in real terms and funding provided in 1980-81 for public hospitals, the general community Health Program, and the School Dental Scheme, less a share of the revenue the States could be reasonably expected to raise through the introduction of appropriate inpatient and outpatient charges in 1981-82 and the user pays principle in public hospitals. The resultant total sum involved is expected to be about $1250m. It is expected that the funds to be allocated to South Australia and Tasmania will be based on the existing hospital cost-sharing arrangements. However, the Commonwealth will be seeking to adjust those agreements to ensure that conditions relating to free access to public hospitals are uniform across Australia.

I emphasise that if the States accept the Government's view that free access to public hospitals should be restricted to eligible pensioners and their dependants and the disadvantaged as defined by the Commonwealth, they will not be required to introduce a means test. I further emphasise that no State will be required to introduce inpatient and/or outpatient charges for any or all persons. However, should any State decide that free public hospitals should be provided to all persons it will be required to meet the extra cost involved out of its own resources.
Protection of the Aged, the Chronically Ill and the Disadvantaged

As I emphasised earlier, the Government will be acting to ensure that free access of eligible pensioners and the socially disadvantaged to public hospitals is maintained. The Government will also continue to protect the position of such people in relation to their medical costs. It has therefore decided to retain the present arrangements in relation to eligible pensioners and their dependants. However, it has decided that new arrangements should be introduced for the disadvantaged. This new arrangement involves the Government in clearly defining the disadvantaged. The Government has decided to do so because of a dual concern, namely, that bulk billed medical services provided under the existing disadvantaged arrangements are growing at a rate which would indicate that those services have been made available to persons who could not normally be regarded as disadvantaged; and that people in genuine need are not always able to gain the protection of those arrangements.

The Government believes that the following groups in the community should be regarded as disadvantaged: All migrants and refugees in their first six months in Australia; current unemployment and special beneficiaries who meet the pensioner health benefit income test; and other persons who meet a specified income test. In respect of bulk billed medical services received by such people, a Commonwealth medical benefit of 85 per cent will be payable, as is now the case in relation to eligible pensioners. Doctors will be able to bulk bill the Government for such services or a disadvantaged person may take a doctor's account to a health fund for payment of the appropriate Commonwealth medical benefit.

Honourable senators will be aware that the current Commonwealth medical benefit for services provided to the disadvantaged is 75 per cent of the scheduled fee. This new arrangement means that the insured population, eligible pensioners and the disadvantaged will receive benefits for scheduled medical services at approximately the same level. This new arrangement will operate from 1 September 1981. It is expected that a maximum of one million people will be eligible for assistance under this scheme. I now seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a statement of the main details of the new arrangements to apply in this area.
Leave granted.
The statement read as follows-
DEFINITION OF THE DISADVANTAGED
Under the Commonwealth definition of the disadvantaged the following would be included:
Migrants and refugees in the first six months in Australia-(no income test);
Current unemployment and special beneficiaries (including dependants) with private incomes below the PHB limits.
This group would not become PHB ''pensioners'' and would not qualify for other Commonwealth 'fringe benefits';

A married couple who have a joint income less than the cut-out point for unemployment benefits for a married couple (rounded up to the next whole dollar) plus $20 and twice the rate of additional benefit for each child. On this basis the income limit is $160 a week for a married couple plus $20 for each child.
For a sole parent, with one child, the income limit will be the same as for a married couple. For each additional child, the limit will increase by $20.
For single people, without dependants, the income limit will be 60 per cent of the income for a married couple i.e. $96 per week.
Overall approximately 1 million persons are expected to be covered by the new arrangements.

TALK.START.PARA: —Honourable senators will be aware that the assistance provided by the Commonwealth to help cover the hospital and medical bills of eligible pensioners is considerable. The cost of such assistance on the medical side alone is now running at over $300m annually. Despite this, the Government believes that further assistance should be given to protect the aged and chronically ill in relation to the cost of nursing home care.
