It has therefore decided that it will take over full responsibility for the payment of nursing home benefits as from 1 September 1981. At present the Commonwealth pays nursing home benefits only for uninsured persons. The estimated cost of this decision is $120m annually. This is expected to take Commonwealth assistance to nursing home patients to about $560m in a full year.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government has also decided to increase its assistance for the aged and the chronically ill through greater support for organisations providing home nursing services. The Government believes that such services increase the quality of life of people receiving them and help contain costs by keeping people out of institutions when there is no medical reason for them to be there. As honourable senators may be aware, a number of home nursing services have expressed concern at the restriction imposed in 1976 on the number of nurses the Commonwealth will subsidise under the Home Nursing Subsidy Scheme. Recognising the important work carried out by these organisations the Government has decided that this restriction on the number of nurses subsidised by the Commonwealth should be lifted as from 1 July next. The immediate effect of this will be that additional Commonwealth subsidies will be paid in respect of about 195 nurses. The estimated full year cost of this decision is $1m.
Health Insurance

As I stated at the outset, the Government believes that health insurance should be available to all Australians at a reasonable cost and should have a wide coverage of the population in order to support the community rating principle. Regrettably, the combination of free public hospitals to all people irrespective of their incomes and the existing Commonwealth medical benefit arrangements has resulted in a gradual erosion of health fund membership and, as a result, of the community rating principle. If this trend were to continue it could threaten the Government's health insurance policy, the viability of the health funds and the position of those dependent on insurance-taking special account of the aged, the chronically ill and families with children.

In order to arrest that trend and bring about an increase in the numbers of people insured the Government has decided that the following major changes should be made to the present health insurance arrangements: Firstly, a tax rebate separate from the existing concessions deduction arrangements will be introduced for the cost of basic hospital and medical insurance with registered health funds with effect from 1 July 1981; the rebate will be set initially at 32c in the dollar. Full details of this decision are to be announced in another place by the Treasurer, the Honourable John Howard, later today. Secondly, Commonwealth medical benefits will be restricted to those people with at least basic medical cover with a registered health fund. Thirdly, a flat rate Commonwealth medical benefit of 30 per cent will apply to all schedule medical services and the existing 0 per cent/$20 limit arrangements will be abolished. Fourthly, the Government's payment to assist health funds to help cover the hospital costs of the chronically ill will be set at $100m. Fifthly, the basic level of medical insurance will be increased from 75 per cent to 85 per cent of the schedule fee and benefits of $10 per service. Sixthly, current insurance tables classed as 'optional to basic' will be prohibited. Unless indicated elsewhere the commencement date for these decisions is 1 September 1981.

As honourable senators will be aware, basic health insurance covers benefits in medical and hospital insurance as defined in the National Health Act. Basic medical insurance will, as from 1 September next, provide to the insured contributor medical benefits at 85 per cent of the schedule fee with a maximum patient payment of up to $10 a medical service at schedule fee levels. Basic hospital insurance provides hospital benefit at the level of charges on insured persons for shared ward accommodation in public hospitals and other such approved charges, that is, out-patient, in public hospitals.

In addition the Government has decided that it should enter into urgent discussions with the health funds to establish a mechanism to protect members of registered health funds in the event of the collapse of such a fund. The Government is concerned to ensure that health fund members are not financially disadvantaged should any funds cease operation. However, it would expect that such a mechanism would be fully financed by the health insurance industry.

As I stated earlier, the Government believes health insurance should be encouraged. The decision to introduce a tax rebate is a major step designed to promote that objective. It will significantly assist all those who take out health insurance. These decisions are based on the Government's firm view that community support towards health costs through health insurance should be based on the community rating principle and on significant Commonwealth subsidisation that is financed through the general taxation arrangements. The Government firmly believes that such support, when coupled with special arrangements to protect the more needy sections of the community, is the most equitable and responsible means of providing health insurance cover.
The private sector

Mr Deputy President, the Government fully recognises the valuable role played by the private sector in the health care delivery system. It believes that a strong health insurance industry underpins the continued viability of the private sector. The Government is particularly aware of the importance of private hospitals, particularly religious and charitable hospitals. Private hospitals are an essential component of Australia's health care delivery system that should be maintained and strengthened. The Government believes that possible action by the States to confine free access to public hospitals to those in genuine need and possible State action to increase public hospital charges will considerably strengthen the position of private hospitals in the medium to longer term. However, it is aware of the increasing cost of servicing surgical beds in private hospitals when compared with medical and other beds and that action is required to ensure that such beds continue to be available to the community. The Government has therefore decided to increase the present $16 a day bed subsidy for surgical patients in private hospitals to $28. The existing bed day subsidy level of $16 will be retained for other private hospital patients.
The control of health services costs

As I stated at the outset, the Government is keen to ensure that health services are not unnecessarily requested by consumers or ordered by providers and that abuses do not occur. As part of this the Government has been carrying out an ongoing review of the Commonwealth medical benefits arrangements for some years now to ensure that benefits are paid only where services are reasonably required for medical treatment and to prevent abuse. Recommendations on further changes to the medical benefits schedule are currently being finalised by my Department for submission to the Minister for Health with a view to implementing changes as from 1 July 1981.

The Government has also taken action to reduce the incidence of abuse by those few people in the health care profession who may seek to misuse or defraud the system for their own gain. A major example was the establishment of the Medical Services Committee of Inquiry in 1977. These committees are effectively a peer review system designed to prevent over-servicing by doctors. The Government has recently agreed to a number of changes to the committee's operation which should considerably increase their effectiveness. My colleague will be announcing details of these changes when he introduces the necessary amendments to the Health Insurance Act later in this parliamentary session. In addition, my colleague is currently examining, in conjunction with the Attorney-General (Senator Durack), a number of other suggestions designed to strengthen further the effectiveness of these committees. Subject to the outcome of discussions on these proposals he expects that the resultant changes would be introduced as soon as possible.

The Jamison inquiry made recommendations in the area of salaried medical practice. The Government has considered these recommendations and has decided that it should consult with the States on the matter. However, the question of the administration of hospital systems is primarily a matter for the States.
Conclusion

The overriding aim of the Government's health policy is that all Australians should have access to high quality health care. At the same time, individuals should be encouraged to be more responsible for their health care needs. The system must be equitable, paying particular attention to the capacity of individuals to contribute towards their health costs. But it is also important that all governments ensure that the high costs involved in maintaining that system do not cripple the general community. The Government's health policy, therefore, should also be responsible providing adequate checks and balances to prevent abuses. The decisions I have spelt out today will ensure that both these objectives are met through special assistance to help cover the hospital and medical costs of those in genuine need; ensuring that those who are in a position to do so should contribute towards the cost of the health services they receive; the promotion of insurance for those providing such a contribution through subsidy arrangements financed through the adoption of health service funding arrangements designed to minimise waste and inefficiency in costly institutions; and acting to ensure that consumers and providers of hospital and medical services do not abuse the health care delivery system.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I make this statement on behalf of the Minister for Finance (Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle) who in this chamber represents the Treasurer (Mr Howard).

SPEECH.PARA: As has just been announced, the Government has decided to introduce a new concessional rebate for health insurance contributions. I have explained the nature of this new concessional rebate, which will be rebatable outside the $1,590 rebate block at the standard rate which is presently 32 per cent. I emphasise that tax savings from this new concession will not depend on a taxpayer's total rebatable expenditure exceeding $1,590.

The Government believes the introduction of a concessional rebate for health insurance will be widely welcomed and will, we believe, be of particular benefit for families. In considering the introduction of this new concession the Government has given very great thought to the question of tax indexation.

As indicated in the policy speech of the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) of September 1980 the existing policy of half-tax indexation will provide taxation reductions of about $500m in a full year commencing in July next. As honourable senators will be aware, there are significant arguments for and against tax indexation and I shall not weary the Senate by canvassing all of these arguments today. It is true, as members of the Government have frequently stated in the past, that tax indexation does oblige Governments to legislate tax increases, and to that extent has been a discipline. It can equally be said, however, that to the extent to which either expenditures or revenues are automatically indexed, the Budget flexibility available to a government to respond to changed economic circumstances is thereby reduced.

The Government has decided that discretionary adjustments to taxation scales and allowances are preferable to tax indexation. However, the Government is conscious of the precise terms of what was said in the Prime Minister's policy speech and accordingly confirms that half-tax indexation will apply from 1 July next, thus providing in full the benefit of some $500m foreshadowed in that speech. That half-tax indexation adjustment will, however, be the last indexation adjustment. Future taxation adjustments will be determined-usually in the Budget context-on a discretionary basis and in accordance with economic considerations.

As with similar rebates in respect of special categories of expenditure the medical insurance rebate will generally speaking be received on assessment. As a consequence, the revenue impact of introducing this new concession will be negligible in 1981-82. The full year cost of the new concessional rebate health insurance will be in the order of $600m. Legislation providing for the half-tax indexation adjustment will be introduced later this session. My colleague Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle shall also, at a later date, be providing details of the half-indexation factor to apply in respect of 1981-82 and details of the impact of half-indexation on taxation scales in that year.

DEBATE.TITLE: HEALTH CARE SERVICES HEALTH INSURANCE CONTRIBUTIONS

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Peter Baume) proposed:
That the Senate take note of the statements.
Debate (on motion by Senator Gietzelt) adjourned.
Sitting suspended from 5.51 to 8 p.m.
(Quorum formed).
Debate resumed from 28 April, on motion by Senator Carrick:
That the Bill be now read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Melzer Sen J.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —At the beginning of this debate last evening I was expressing concern that this Government had stated that it will bring one million migrants into this country in the next 12 months. On its past record of little care and concern about their future, I believe it does not augur well for the people involved, the people coming into Australia, or for Australia itself. We in Australia have extraordinary unemployment at the moment. We have a shortage of skilled tradesmen even though we have high unemployment. Why do we have a shortage of skilled tradesmen when we have high unemployment? It is because we did not train people. Governments were not concerned and industry expressed no concern at all about training the skilled tradesmen it needs to carry on. Australia did not care because it used to go shopping to Europe for the skilled tradesmen it needed. But now it finds that people are not so keen about coming to Australia. Why should they come half way across the world and disrupt their families when their wages in Europe are as high, their social welfare payments are better than ours and, after tonight, of course, their health care is infinitely better than the health care in Australia. So we cannot pick up the skilled tradesmen we used to.

SPEECH.PARA: What do we do now? We go to other parts of the world and we recruit semi-skilled people even though there are millions of people, young people especially, here in Australia who cannot get a job. They cannot get a job because we have not given them any opportunity to train. The Government sees no necessity to train the thousands of people we need to fill those vacancies for skilled tradesmen. So we try to recruit in other parts of the world.

Why does this Government insist on suggesting even that we bring a million extra people into this country when there are no jobs, there is no housing and there is no proper education for them? The Government is bringing out that great mass of extra people because it knows that by bringing them out it can put pressure on the work force that is already here. There is no greater way of making a man put up with the bad conditions he works under, put up with the poor pay he gets, than to have a long line of people at the factory gate waiting to get his job. That is the reason this Government is contemplating bringing out to Australia these thousands and thousands of people.

I was pointing out yesterday evening before the debate on this Bill was interrrupted that in some inner suburban schools in Melbourne there can be up to 80 per cent of the pupils who come from non-English speaking backgrounds and that at the same time there can be as few as four migrant English teachers for over 700 students in that same area. One wonders what the position will be when another influx of non-English speaking people come into those areas. I have been in schools in the inner suburbs of Melbourne where in one class 27 different languages can be spoken yet there can be not one migrant English teacher. This Government has the cheek to blame teachers, parents and even the children for the unemployment that people are suffering. How can children in these circumstances possibly obtain the skills they need to obtain jobs in the sort of market area that exists in Australia today?

Perhaps these million extra migrants whom this Government is going to bring in will be sent to places like the Latrobe Valley in Melbourne where certainly at the moment jobs are available. Jobs are available but there is no housing available. Schools there are in as bad a position or a worse position than the schools in the inner Melbourne area. It is just inconceivable that the Government could contemplate forcing more people into an area that is groaning at the moment because none of the services there can cope with the population that presently exists. For instance, absolutely no housing is available in the Latrobe Valley. The houses that occasionally come on the market there are rented out for amounts approaching, or more than, $200 a week. How on earth can unskilled people, even in that area, hope to balance the budget when they have those sorts of costs loaded on to them? How do people pay those sorts of costs? Of course, if this Government took housing seriously we might start to pull ourselves out of the economic mess we are in. It is interesting to note in tonight's Victorian Herald the comments of the Housing Industry Authority. The article states:
A boost to home building in Victoria would do more for the State's economy than waiting for the resources boom to be a financial cure-all, according to the Housing Industry Authority.
The HIA says that while resource projects-and in particular the Latrobe Valley and Alcoa Portland developments-are vitally important to the State, present realities should not be forgotten.

The Housing Industry Authority was reported as pointing out that while we are pouring millions of dollars into those sorts of areas that will provide very little employment for people, we are neglecting areas such as housing which would provide many more jobs and many more long term jobs and which might provide some stability for the people who are seeking jobs and a future in Victoria today. But this Government does not see the future of Australia that way. Victoria even is in the ridiculous position this year of paying the Federal Government more in interest on the Federal money that has been made available for housing in the past than it will receive this year for housing. So how on earth will Victoria, for instance, cope with thousands of new people being injected into the area?

As for health, how will people who are unable to find jobs and unable to obtain the skills needed for the few jobs that are going and with no housing available at a price that they can pay, now pay for health care, for this new and glorious health care policy that this scandalous Government has brought in-a government, remember, that promised not to touch Medibank? That is another promise broken. But it is not just a promise broken; it means that the very future, the very health of thousands of people across Australia is now in danger. Why? Because this Government is determined to follow its policy that people do not matter but profit does. The Minister for Health (Mr MacKellar) said today, 'Modern health care is an expensive commodity'. What does that mean? It means that there are thousands of people who now find food too expensive; so how will they get on when they have to meet the high cost of health? These migrants believe that they are coming to a rich country. Government members go around the world telling people that Australia is a rich, safe country. It is for some people. It is for those people who are at the top of the tree. This Government is determined to keep Australia as a place that provides rich resources and returns to the people who have money. We are going back to the dark ages, to the 1970s, when the attitude was: 'When you have the money you can have good health'; for the rest, back luck. They are told: 'It must have been your genes' or 'it is the area in which you were born. That is just too bad. You are not going to have the money to pay for good health'.

Of course, we have great resources in Australia. This Government keeps telling people that we have great resources. They will benefit the people, but when is that benefit to begin flowing? When will the people at the bottom of the ladder begin to derive some benefit from the resources that we are selling at tuppence a ton to reward the friends of Malcolm Fraser? This Government cares nothing for the people at the bottom of the ladder. That is where the migrants are. That is where the millions of migrants that the Government will bring out to Australia will end up. This maniac Prime Minister that the Government has foisted upon Australia is determined to favour the profit-makers, those who have forced the Australian people to suffer the greatest poverty and ill health in history so that greater profits can be made. For whom? It is for the private health funds, the private hospitals and the doctors. It is no wonder that everywhere one goes in the community, one finds people selling up their assets to invest in private hospitals. One could almost have thought that they knew something like this would happen-that private hospitals would skim the cream off the health market.

In line with this belief-that the profits to be made from our resources are to go to overseas shareholders-we find that our minerals are being used up for the benefit of others, that the people of Australia are going further downhill than they have ever been before. I have pointed out before that this Government purports to care about people who are forced to be refugees but that when they come to Australia and the problems of life here catch up with them, we deny them proper pensions, force them to exist by begging, force them to exist on special benefits and charity. Yet we offered them a new way of life. We suggested that they come out of the terrible situation in which they found themselves, to this land of milk and honey, this rich country with all these resources, this country which was going to provide a new way of life for its people.

As I pointed out last evening, it is not just the young people, who get no schooling and not just the unemployed who have no future, who make up the migrant world. There is also, for instance, a group of older migrant women who are not allowed to become citizens. If their husbands are alive and they speak English, these women can be naturalised. If their husbands die and the women do not speak English, they will be denied Australian citizenship. Because of the sort of life that they lived, many are illiterate in their own language, as well as in English; but why deny them, at their age, this right to be Australian citizens. The Government knew when they came here that they were illiterate in their own language, let alone in English; yet it accepted them as migrants. When they were young the world in which they lived denied them education. That was reserved for the males of their community. Any women who came here from parts of Europe and who were born before the last War, would be in that position. Why do we have to be so cruel? If their husbands are alive and speak English, that is enough; they can become Australian citizens. But if they are left as widows who are isolated, if they want the comfort of an Australian passport and the security of Australian citizenship when confronting the question of social security, we deny it to them because they cannot speak English. We forget the background from which they came; we forget that it is not their fault. The Government forgets conveniently that it has done little to give them the opportunity to learn English. It seems hard that we cannot extend this concession to these women, to whom this sort of letter is written:
I refer to your personal representations on behalf of-
I will refer to this woman as 'X'-
who has been unable to satisfy the English language requirements for the grant of Australian Citizenship.

The Citizenship Act is quite specific in relation to applicants possessing an adequate knowledge of English and the only exemptions that can be made to this requirement are for people who are the spouses, widows or widowers of Australian Citizens, people over the age of sixty years and those with serious permanent disabilities in hearing, speech or sight.

I appreciate that Mrs X would find it difficult to learn English because of her illiteracy and her age but unfortunately the Minister does not have the discretionary powers to waive the requirements in such cases.

Therefore unless the deceased husband of Mrs X held Australian Citizenship it will not be possible for her to gain citizenship until she reaches the age of sixty years on . . . An application from her would be acceptable six months prior to that date to ensure that processing would be completed by the time she reaches sixty years of age.

What a typically piddling response from a government that does not really give two hoots about ordinary people. This woman has left her homeland and has brought up children in Australia. She has contributed to the Australian way of life. She has contributed citizens to Australia, yet we deny her this one last comfort because she has not had sufficient education to enable her to learn English.

There is yet another group-citizens without country because of this Government's negligence in not changing archaic laws. Recently in Sydney there was a case in which a mother applied for citizenship but her 12-year-old daughter was denied it because, according to the authorities, only her father was regarded as a responsible parent. Her parents were divorced. She and her mother came to live in Australia. In this instance, a 12-year-old has been told that she can apply for citizenship in her own right. The Minister said that the relevant section of the Citizenship Act definitely needed updating, but it has needed updating for a long time now and there seems to be no move, even at this point, to do that. Why has it not been updated? How dare a government in this day and age tell a mother who has been given responsibility for her children by a court of law that she is not to be regarded by the Australian Government as a responsible parent. How is it that we just manage to miss that area? How many other children are affected in this way? Would this Government grant Australian 12-year olds a passport if they applied on their own behalf? Of course it would not. It would say that the parents must apply on their behalf. In this instance the Government is sexist enough to have regarded this mother as being not a responsible parent. It results from laziness and sloppiness, from a general disregard for people as people. The Government sees people as mere factory fodder. In fact, if it were honest it would admit that in many instances it would prefer to use the term 'guest workers' rather than 'migrants' because it would be very convenient under this policy if, having brought them out and found that they were in excess of requirements, it could send them home again.

TALK.START.PARA: —Say something nice, Senator.

—There is not much that is nice that one can say about this Government in the area of immigration. It proposes bringing to Australia a million additional people. It cannot house them, feed them, find jobs for them or educate their children. It has the cheek to take over their lives and ruin them. That is what is has done. It brings them half way across the world and then says, 'bad luck'. It does not have the guts to say: 'Really, you are only guest workers. We only brought you out for the period when we needed you. Now we are going to send you home again.' European nations have the guts to say that but this Government has not. It brings people out here and then finds that it can do nothing with them. Nor can the Government develop Australia to the point where anything can be done with them. We will have the report of the razor gang tomorrow. It will be interesting to see what this Government will do with migrants after tomorrow. After tomorrow's report there will be less welfare, less education and fewer jobs. As long as this Government's friends are getting profit, what do jobs matter? Machines can do the jobs. It would be more to the point if the Government brought in more machines. More and more people are being enticed here by this Government and more and more are going to the wall.

SPEECH.PARA: Finally, may I quote from one of the Government's friends, the Australian Industries Development Association, which has been pressuring the Government to cut more money out of welfare. After all, people should be independent, people should support themselves, and people should look after their own futures! It does not matter that they do not have jobs and that they rely on the Government's charity.

TALK.START.PARA: —There would not be too many new Australians who would be in that situation, would there?
—Now, Senator, remember those people in your area. The Australian Industries Development Association said:

SPEECH.PARA: The political difficulty of biting deeply into welfare expenditures is acknowledged.
Honourable senators opposite have to remember that there will come a day when they will be up for re-election. This friend of the Government went on to say:
Nevertheless it is clear that not only constraint on growth but expenditure reduction is necessary in the welfare field.

Senator MacGibbon has already said in this place that this country has spent too much on welfare and not enough on defence. It would be all right, I suppose, if the Government were to provide more jobs from that spending on defence, but it will not even provide jobs there. It will spend overseas that money it has earmarked for defence, thus making more money for its friends. It has not even got the guts to spend those defence dollars here in Australia to provide jobs. All I can say is that, as this Government is providing no indication that it feels in any way differently from the way the Australian Industries Development Association feels, its project to bring one million extra migrants to Australia is nothing more than immoral. After the report on health that the Government made this afternoon, the whole of Australia will brand this Government as an immoral government.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before calling Senator Martyr, I remind the Senate that this will be the honourable senator's maiden speech in this chamber. I trust that he will be accorded the usual courtesies.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martyr Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I rise to make my maiden speech, I reflect on the fact that I am in a quite unique position. It is not every day, or even every year, that a blushing neophyte like myself has a chance to be a maiden-twice! I am reminded by the presence of at least one gentleman from the other place that on the last occasion I was there as the honourable member for Swan somebody who was not very kind but who nonetheless was prescient about the events of last October said: 'This is his swan song'. All I can say in my new-found glory in this place is: 'Some song, some swan'. But this is a different pond. I have already farewelled my friends and colleague, in another place. I said: 'Don't call me. I'll call you'. Seriously, I will always value my time in that place. People have said to me that I should look upon it as an apprenticeship. It was an apprenticeship, and a very valuable formative period. It is my privilege to know personally and to have a deep affection for many over there on both sides.

SPEECH.PARA: I ask you, Mr Deputy President, to convey my sincere thanks to Mr President when he returns for his delightful words on that historic day a few weeks ago-the words 'Admit them'-whereupon Senator Bjelke-Petersen and I tripped delightfully, as a twosome, into this illustrious chamber. I thank Senator Sim, who is not in the chamber this evening, for identifying me to the President. It has been my tribute to his long service in this place to have him sponsor me in the chamber.

I know the Senate will not object if I thank the more than one hundred members of the Liberal State Council of Western Australia for sending me here. I was very surprised that they chose me, for in my blunt way I said a few things to them which may not have been at the time in my best interests. However, if they are punishing me they have done it in a most pleasant fashion. I pay tribute also to their fairness. I am indebted to them. I am also indebted to all my friends and supporters in Swan and throughout Western Australia. After the sad events of last October I received many letters of-I have to say it-electoral condolence. It was apparently their delight to welcome me back into political life. I suppose I might say that those who were sad in October 1980 during the summer of my discontent-it was not a winter-are now made glorious. I thank them all for their efforts and their kindness to me.

I thank also the State parliamentarians of Western Australia. I have the Hansard record of the joint sitting which ratified my appointment to this place. Mr Ron Davies, the Leader of the Opposition, seconded the motion of the Premier, Sir Charles Court. He did not do it with joy or gratitude. Mr Davies and I enjoy good relations. Presumably he felt there was enough joy and gratitude in my heart for both of us. I should also tell the Senate that Mr Brian Burke, who is a member of the State Parliament, said that I was a fascist; and the Honourable Bob Hetherington-I thought a friend of mine-said that I was a retread. Mr Davies concluded his seconding speech by saying that he did it with distaste and reluctance and said further that I had been a member of the Australian Labor Party and of the Democratic Labor Party before I was in the Liberal Party. I tell the Senate all this without any inhibition or rancour because I know that if I do not do so, somebody else will bring it up-and all too soon! I am agreeably surprised to note that those are mild and gentle criticisms which are not a patch on what I have been called in the other place.

I want to pay tribute to some former senators who impressed me greatly. The late Ivor Greenwood I knew but briefly. I can say only that I loved him and that I loved what he believed in. He, I think, was a genuine conservative; and I think that is what I am. There is a difference, of course, betwen reactionaries and conservatives, and I am not going to bore the Senate with that difference. I think everyone here knows what it is. I remember with affection and respect Reg Wright and Magnus Cormack. Magnus Cormack I always found somewhat crusty but very kind of heart and always trying to help anyone who came to him for advice. I think I have to be honest and say that for a while I regarded Reg Wright as the conscience of the Liberal Party. I heard recently something that may not be to his credit. I understand he was visiting here recently and somebody asked him what he thought of the place. He thought it ought to be burned down. I hope I am not misquoting him.

I regret that those men are no longer with us. They were not too old at all, in my opinion. I sometimes lose patience with those who demand a cosmetic perpetual youth for their parliamentary representatives. I admit that I am in need of some cosmetic uplift. Nonetheless, I get angry when I hear it suggested, and I know that Senator Bjelke-Petersen probably feels the same way as I do. I must say that I am gratified by the election of President Reagan at the age of 69, and he has just recently proved his physical toughness and powers of recovery. The belief that age is a handicap in a leader and that the best candidates are young and preferably glamorous is an American and, apparently, Australian trait.

Europe's post-war recovery owed much to three very great leaders-Churchill, Adenauer and De Gaulle-and, given their age then, they would make many of the men who have retired from this chamber look like mere boys. The antagonists that the free world has had over all these years also have not been young. Ho Chi Minh was no baby and Mao Tse-tung swam the Yangtze at a great age. An elderly Iranian gentleman is causing a lot of trouble in his part of the world at the moment. This penchant for young, handsome people is something that I think this country has to get away from. We have to go for those who have the ability and the capacity and those qualities are not necessarily found only in the young.

TALK.START.PARA: —Bald is beautiful.

—Yes. I am proud of my baldness. I do not do anything to disguise it. I understand that there are one or two senators in this place who do; but not my friend, Senator McIntosh. He and I glory in it. I mention these matters to emphasise that the world owes as much to age as it owes to youth and that there has to be more gratitude, understanding and response to the problem of the old by the Australian people as individuals, rather than from their government.

SPEECH.PARA: I have been appalled for years at the callous indifference displayed by sons and daughters-many of them are my former electors-to the plight of their aged parents. I refuse to blame the Government for this. I believe that these are personal matters and defects of character that are part and parcel of human nature. What is the exact solution for this problem, I do not pretend to know. But I emphasise to the Senate that it is a problem of the individual and not a problem of the Government. As I have said, it is part of the total human problem that exists today in Australian society, which, in my judgment, has experienced no real worries since 1945.

I listened with interest to a speech made earlier and I have listened to a few other speeches since I have been a member of this chamber and I have heard used expressions which would indicate that this country is in serious trouble and has been in serious trouble. I insist that we really have not had a serious problem in this country since 1945 and probably for a couple of years before that. The only really serious problem that any nation can say it has is when the enemy is knocking at the door and the citizens of that country are likely to lose their liberty. That is the most serious problem that any nation can face. I think that we in this country can glory in the freedom that we have had and the capacity we have to make up our minds on how we want to live our lives. I feel that part of the reason for people believing that life is really difficult today is the constant feeding of soothing syrup in social welfare handouts from government of our kind and calibre. I think this is not helping the situation; I think it is hindering it. I think it may well have created the situation I alluded to before in which everybody expects the Government to pick up his personal problems and carry them.

Surely, if we have any sense about these matters, the reverse ought to be the case. Surely the Government ought to be the last resort rather than the first resort in matters such as this. Surely the family is the most important delivery mechanism for any kind of social service, and I am not referring to government social services. Instead of helping family solidarity, all the welfare that we have been dishing out over many years has tended to break it down. For instance, take the unemployed youth. I can remember the days of my childhood when things in this country were not as good as they are today, in spite of what people might say. There was far greater unemployment then than there is now. The family took care of its own. It was able to do so, in my judgment as I reflect on those times and what I have seen in the years between then and now, much more effectively than we are doing today with all the social welfare we have.

For instance, take the care of the aged to which I have already alluded. The family did it once but not now. In how many instances in recent years have honourable senators heard their constituents say whenever the problem of aged parents is talked about: 'Bung them into a home'? That is a dreadful statement to come from sons and daughters. Let us consider education. What people did for themselves once is considered today to be a real hardship not to be repeated by our children.

Though we might not like to hear it, there is a limit and the reason for stopping at that limit is not just the Government's reluctance to continue to come to the party. The demographic fact today is that we are running out of people. This means higher and higher taxes for those who are left to pay for more and more welfare. I believe I have already demonstrated that personal selfishness-from which I do not exclude myself, incidentally-is rampant in Australia. If this selfishiness is correct, and I think honourable senators will concede that it is, the fewer people will not pay the taxes necessary to maintain the welfare. So who then pays the pensions and who looks after the aged? I recollect that not so long ago some hard-hearted person who had been following this argument said to me: 'You have had plenty of kids. Your kids can do it'. That is not a bad sort of reflection and one I would accept if only a few more people would share the load and have a few more kids.

I come to another point. I believe that the popular disregard for the aged that is apparent today began at much the same time as the popular disregard for unborn life. I know that almost everyone in this chamber has been expecting me to get round to this subject sooner or later. I have been very patient for 15 minutes and I have finally got round to it. I have always maintained-God knows there is enough experience and evidence to prove it-that if we make one section of human life expendable it is only a matter of time before we move on others. Therefore, I was delighted when the Senate acknowledged the unborn in recent human rights legislation and I thank the Senate for that. I know that Senator Puplick says very quietly that I only extend human rights from conception to birth and not after, but I know that he does not mean that. The current legislation is much the final terms of what was struck on in another place last year, I think to the extreme discomfiture of the Senate. I hope that those who, up to date, have been involved in a very tough and courageous campaign in favour of the right to life, particularly Mrs Tighe in Victoria, Mrs Woolf in Canberra, Mrs Harrigan in New South Wales and their dedicated helpers-I could not mention them all by name tonight-will continue their work for the unborn human life. I hope they will continue to exercise the sort of courage they have exercised so far.

Australia desperately needs population. We must have it by either natural increase or migration. I wish to read from an article appearing in the West Australian of Saturday, 25 April which is, curiously enough, Anzac Day. It is a day that always brings to my mind what had to be done on one occasion and what has had to be done a couple of times since to preserve this country. The article states:
The head of the department of environment and life sciences at Murdoch University, Professor D. C. O'Connor, said ZPG meant an ageing society with zero innovation.
Australia had five per cent of the world's land mass and only 0.34 per cent of its people. It was unreal for a country like Australia to have policies which were not based on growth.

What I have been saying so far is not just the instinctive rambling of someone who does not really understand the situation. There are demographic facts to support every single thing I have said. If that is not enough, the Executive Director of the Confederation of Industry in Western Australia is reported in an article as saying:
. . . migrants would create jobs and bring in capital.
The article stated further:
Mr Atkinson said the curtailment of increasing migration in the early 1970s was a major factor in Australia's economic decline.

Anybody who understands the basic economic concepts of supply and demand-indeed, sometimes when I have listened to debates in this place and elsewhere I have wondered whether those factors are understood at all-knows that if we bring in people a creative cycle is engaged in which, to use economic terms, is bound to exercise a multiplier. We should immediately support an immigration program because Australia is desperately short of people. I think it is quite obvious that no matter what happens we are not going to get the quick natural increase which I think is vitally necessary in this country. I believe that at the same time we should immediately cancel any Government support for killing the unborn. It is just madness, as far as I am concerned, to continue policies of subsidising the killing of the unborn when we desperately need people. This is completely irrespective of the moral position, which I believe is unassailable anyway. I offer that argument to the Senate on purely political grounds. I conclude discussion of this matter with another quotation from the article which appeared in the West Australian on 25 April. It stated:

But with the nation gearing-up for a massive expansion through the resources boom, it is also facing a domestic zero population growth. The reproduction rate is eight per cent below the long-term replacement level.
Australia is also becoming an ageing society. While the total population is expected to increase by 30 per cent by the year 2000, the number of people aged more than 65 will increase by 70 per cent.
The number of children younger than 14 will increase by only 20 per cent. The average age will rise from 29.5 to 33.

If those three very well based quotations do not demonstrate everything that I have been saying in the last 20 minutes, I do not know what does. It occurs to me that at this point I should mention an old adversary-the Australian Conservation Foundation. I did not want to be too political as this is a maiden speech but I suppose there will be opportunities, not very far in the future, for people to answer what I have to say. I have tried, unsuccessfully, for five years to get this organisation off the Government handout list. In my judgment-I think I have enough evidence-it has wilfully abused government money, using it to attack government policy on growth and development. Just the other day Dr Mosley attacked the migration program. He has been an advocate of zero population growth for years. Rumour has it that the honeymoon may be over and that it may get no more government money. I hope so. I do not deny that this organisation in its early years may have had attached to it people who were motivated from the very best basis and who hoped to achieve some sort of stand against those who wilfully polluted or destroyed the atmosphere or the land. But I think everybody would have to agree that in recent years the early objects of the organisations have not been achieved. It has used the sustenance that this Government has given it to attack the Government and all of its policies. To me, for a government to subsidise its own destruction, is an act either of very great even- handedness or of plain foolishness. I have no objection to the Conservation Foundation's funding itself, pursuing its own objectives and having its own organisation-good luck to it. But it should do so in its own time and with its own money.

I wish to say something about my own State and its problems, the chief of which at the moment is not Canberra. I know that that will be a surprise to some honourable senators who are interested in the present state of Federal-State relations. The Western Australian conservation movement in its class action against Alcoa of Australia Ltd, the aluminium company, could jeopardise not only the alumina contracts but also the very important North West Shelf off-shore gas project. I shall quote to the Senate a most instructive article which appeared in the Economist on 28 March this year. It is rather humorously headed: 'Courting trouble abroad'. It states:

The environmentalists are suing one of its most important customers, Alcoa of Australia (51 per cent owned by the Aluminium Company of America), which is now refusing to sign purchase contracts till the legal issue is settled. This could take months, or even years if both parties decide to contest judgments.
The projects'--
That is, the North West Shelf project-

developers, Shell Australia, BP Australia, BHP and Woodside Petroleum, have already signed construction projects worth over $A650m. So far, however, their only firm sales contract is with Western Australia's state energy commission. The commission signed up last year to buy 385m cubic feet of gas a day for 20 years after production is due to start in 1984.

This is the only sales contract for gas which exists at the moment. I think the Senate can see the obvious difficulty that will arise if this suit continues. I am very grateful to the Attorney-General (Senator Durack) and I know that the people of Western Australia, by and large-even including some trade unionists-are also very grateful. The Government has decided to use all its force and strength in the United States to see that this class action is unsuccessful. If it is successful it will not only prejudice the aluminium development but it will also prejudice the North West Shelf development and quite a number of ancillary projects which are tied to it.

In the time remaining I commend to all honourable senators a series of articles which have appeared in the West Australian newspaper. In case anyone gets the impression that I am touting the favour of the West Australian newspaper, I say that I am not. It just seemed to me that the articles which appeared in recent weeks were the best articles that I could recommend to the Senate in order for honourable senators to achieve a better understanding of what makes that State, and those of us who come from it, tick. The articles are not just about secession, but that feeling has to be understood. It is there. It has been well said about Western Australians: 'If you scratch them you will find a secessionist'. It is perhaps a tribute to some of the reasonable people who have been involved so far in trying to cement a decent Federal-State relationship that Western Australia has persevered with Federation, but that situation will not necessarily continue.

I have no evidence at all for suggesting that there is any major force that will even consider or bring about this situation, but I think the Senate has to understand that this feeling is always there and is based on quite reasonable grounds. The Senate may not ever have had this situation put before it, but Western Australia, in its 10 years of responsible self-government between 1890 and 1900-before Federation-was in a state of prosperity which was quite incredible. This prosperity was quite satisfactory to the majority of people in Western Australia who were native-born West Australians. When the question of federation came along there was a very great reluctance to be involved in the Federation. The only thing that eventually swung the referendum was the large number of immigrants from the eastern States located in the Kalgoorlie area. It was this majority that swung the vote in favour of federation. Western Australia came into the Federation but because of high tariffs and certain other difficulties in the Federation there was enormous dissatisfaction. One particular individual, the one time Lord Mayor of Perth, said:
Twenty-five years ago-
That was in 1900-

we all boarded the good ship Commonwealth for a lifetime voyage, with the full assurance that there would be only one class for all the passengers. During the voyage we found to our great surprise that there were four classes.

Victoria and New South Wales had secured all the saloon cabins, South Australia and Queensland the second class, little Tasmania was put in the steerage, whilst Western Australia is compelled to work for her passage in the forecastle.

TALK.START.PARA: —Those days have changed.

—Senator Lewis says that those days have changed. I wonder whether they have. Today about 86 per cent of Western Australia's exports are sold overseas in a competitive market which affords no special protection to this State and 60 per cent of our imports come from the tariff protected and subsidised industries of the eastern States, meaning inflated prices plus freight. With less than 9 per cent of Australia's population, Western Australia earns more than 20 per cent of the nation's income from overseas. Put another way, the average West Australian is responsible for bringing more than twice as much money into the country as his or her counterpart in Victoria or New South Wales. So who is running the Federation now? We are almost at a stage of having taxation without representation. I am pleased to see that Senator Withers agrees with me. We have not always agreed on things, but tonight we do.

SPEECH.PARA: I thank the Senate for its tolerance. I will take just a few more minutes. I want to quote what the free-market economist and Nobel laureate, Professor Hayek, has prepared as a guide for us all. As this is a free enterprise party and a free enterprise government, I think it is appropriate to have his words in the Hansard record. In the circumstances, the quotation is a little long and I would ask, as a first favour from the Senate, if I might incorporate this in the Hansard record of my speech.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-

Almost everywhere the groups which pretend to oppose socialism at the same time support policies which, if the principles on which they are based were generalized, would no less lead to socialism than the avowedly socialist policies. There is some justification at least in the taunt that many of the pretending defenders of 'free enterprise' are in fact defenders of privileges and advocates of government activity in their favor, rather than opponents of all privileges. In principle, the industrial protectionism and government-supported cartels and the agricultural policies of the conservative groups are not different from the proposals for a more far-reaching direction of economic life sponsored by the socialists. It is an illusion when the more conservative interventionists believe that they will be able to confine these government controls to the particular kinds of which they approve. In a democratic society at any rate, once the principle is admitted that the government undertakes responsibility for the status and position of particular groups, it is inevitable that this control will be extended to satisfy the aspirations and prejudices of the great masses. There is no hope of a return to a freer system until the leaders of the movement against state control are prepared first to impose upon themselves that discipline of a competitive market which they ask the masses to accept. The hopelessness of the prospect for the near future indeed is due mainly to the fact that no organized political group anywhere is in favour of a truly free system.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. I hope that in the conflict to come between myself and those who do not agree with me we can have the same civilising and civilised friendship that I was able to enjoy in the other place. If we have to fight each other hard, that is the way it ought to be. But I would not want anything that I have said now-which I suppose is a declaration of where I stand-or anything that I may say in the future to upset any personal relationship that may exist and I hope will exist between us all.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mulvihill Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Convention decrees that I congratulate Senator Martyr on his maiden speech in this place. I would regard him-I think he would accept this comment-not so much as a maiden but rather as a political 'broad', in the American sense, who has been around for a long while. I think he will accept that.

SPEECH.PARA: The first point I want to make concerns the way in which the honourable senator was elected to this Parliament. It is due largely to the charitable attitude of the Australian Labor Party in the 1972 to 1975 era when Premiers cheated in respect of parliamentary replacements. A referendum was held and the people in their wisdom voted by a big margin for the proposition that when an honourable senator departs from the Senate, he should be replaced by a member of the same party. I say with respect to the honourable senator who has just resumed his seat that the Labor Party, via the angel of death, could probably have picked up some advantages on occasions if it had retained the other system. Whenever people talk about a monopoly on democratic concepts, it should be remembered that we had every reason to advocate a 'no' vote in respect of the four constitutional referendums that were held, but we did not do so. If ever a similar situation arose again, I would be amazed if the Government parties advocated that there should be a bipartisan affirmative vote. So I say this: The very presence of the new senator from Western Australia in the chamber is indicative of the Labor Party placing democratic concepts ahead of its own political expediency. It should never be forgotten that when former Senator Milliner died, in his place we got one of the greatest dills who ever entered any parliament. In the case of New South Wales, Senator Bunton was chosen as the replacement senator. He was a very fine man, but he was certainly not here to implement Labor Party policy. Those acts were a prostitution of democracy. So I never want to hear any lecture from anybody on the other side of the chamber about obligations in politics. They were dark days for democracy, and when honourable senators come here, as the recent addition from Western Australia has, they should remember that they are here largely on a dream run, because, as I say, we gave first priority to the principle of democratic replacements.

While I am on my feet, there are two particular matters which I would like to mention. I was amazed at the honourable senator's oversimplification of the position in regard to population and jobs. There is one Minister in the present Government for whom I have a great deal of respect. That is the present Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, Mr Ian Macphee. I mention him in regard to job opportunities. I met him on one occasion when there was a consolidation of the rubber tyre industry in New South Wales and it was considered preferable for Dunlop Australia Ltd to move to Victoria and end its plant operations in New South Wales. Firestone Australia Pty Ltd vacated the field. I could give a long discourse on this Government's policy in relation to tyres and how many tyres are imported from Korea and one or two other countries, but I do not intend to do that.

I wonder whether people like Senator Martyr who advocate this idea that the jobs are there if we have a large population would change their minds if they had sat with me and Barney French, the secretary of the Federated Rubber and Allied Workers Union of Australia, and the Minister, Ian Macphee, at the telephone for four hours. Finally we were able to get jobs for 800 people. I do not think he would say then that in 18 years' time it will be easy to get jobs for everybody who is born in Australia now and that there will be a job for the fifth or sixth child of any family.

I am not trying to score political points. Those are the cruel realities of the technological changes that are coming. Senator Melzer mentioned this and I can assure the Senate that there was no xenophobia in what she was saying. If we go into the working class areas of Sydney and Melbourne and no doubt the other capital cities, that is where we find the boys and girls who came to Australia at age 11 or 12 who face the barriers in relation to mathematics and things like that. A woman might want her son to be an apprentice fitter and turner with Qantas Airways Ltd or some other glamour company which employs metal trades apprentices. We have to tell her that there are so many waiting in the queue that she cannot have that apprenticeship for her son. Some people will say that this is a good country and that the migrants are better off here than they would be in the country they came from. That may be so. I am not a psychologist but I can imagine the position of a boy of 15 or 16 who has to take permanent employment as a process worker. I do not say he is any the worse for that, but I wonder whether these people who talk in terms of percentages ever look at that boy and realise that he has stunted ambitions. That is the point about human relations. It would be stupid to deny that at every trade fair one attends there are new technologies and new appliances that visualise there being fewer workers. Now it may be that with a smaller population people can work the shorter working week. That is well and good. But to say blandly today that things will be good in 15 years' time for any family with seven children under 14 years of age is just rubbish. That is not Labor Party thinking. All the early research that has been done over the last decade by the Commonwealth Department of Labour, which is now the Department of Industrial Relations has indicated that the people in the work force will probably have to be retrained twice. They are sober facts. It is not a question of ideology or party politics; it is a question of job opportunity. We may err on the conservative side in these matters. But I do not believe, when I look at some low paid jobs-whether it be the female work force in the cannery business or in one or two other industries that I can think of-that people who came to Australia before their teenage years should remain permanently in those jobs. Conversely, honourable senators opposite talk about computers and say that the work load will be a lot lighter. Of course, it will be. But not everybody can be transferred to that type of work. It is necessary to have a high mathematical aptitude to get that sort of job. It is very nice to talk in platitudes, but if some of the honourable senators opposite-including our new senator, the ex-member from Swan-wandered around the inner city areas over the weekend, they would realise that these are the unpalatable facts that we have to face up to.

My third point is this: If we are to deal with market forces, it might be argued that families should pick up the tab more for their dependants. I am looking at this now from a capitalist angle, not from a socialist angle. It is probably accepted that the dream of the young married couple, if they can go back into the work force after having a couple of children, is to own their own house by the time they are 45. That is the reverse of what happened to people I know. My father, who was a gas worker, did not have his house paid off until he was 59. I do not think that the previous speaker and all the other backwoods conservatives on the other side of the chamber are saying that we can go back to that situation. Taking the new senator's attitude, I wonder what the cash order people would say if hire purchase of houses and accessories was spread out until a person was in his late fifties or if he never paid off the debt. Even if honourable senators argue from a capitalist concept, they will find that these are the dangers we have.

Senator Martyr referred to living with people who have different views. I respect the honourable senator's right to express that view here, but this is 1981 and that is simply not on. I know of situations where a woman has done office cleaning to supplement her husband's low wage, the children of 12 and 14 years of age are not given the attention they need, and so domestic problems arise. Honourable senators can ask any social worker about those problems. It is not merely a case of putting some religious concepts. If I could get close to the bone, I know Senator Martyr's background. I have read about him in Newsweekly. I am sure that he has read the serves they have given me, and probably they will continue to do so. I am not trying to score points from a sectarian angle. Senator Martyr can get that right out of his head. If he read some modern papers from that area, I think he would find that they do not buy that pre-World War II attitude. It is just not on.

I rose tonight to deal with four matters. The first matter relates to Senate Estimates Committee B. Monday night was a night of infamy. Senator Rae and other honourable senators talked in this place on Thursday night about how we could make Estimates committee work better. On Monday I attended Estimates Committee B as a guest senator. I am a member of another committee, together with Senator Sibraa and my illustrious Western Australian colleague, Senator McIntosh, and we will go into action tomorrow on foreign affairs, defence and immigration. However, I attended Estimates Committee B, and I pay full tribute to Senator Kathy Martin for the way she handled things. We started at 10 a.m. and at 10 o'clock at night we started Communications. There is not a senator here who does not have problems relating to Australia Post. I had the temerity to raise a question about which the Minister already knew. At the request of the Yugoslav community, I wished to ask about SAL, which is a type of overseas postal concession. I wanted to know why the Netherlands, West Germany and Greece got this concession and Yugoslavia did not. I had received a semi-answer to question on notice No. 190 from the Minister for Communications (Mr Sinclair) and I wanted to follow up the matter. I also wanted to know something more about the industrial dispute at the Black Mountain Tower.

I think Commissioner Payne was present at the Estimates Committee hearing, but nobody else. A departmental officer said: 'Well, Senator, we will take these matters on board'. That is not good enough. If I am there as a guest senator until 10 o'clock at night and I have questions to ask then senior officers of the Department should be present. After all, when the Department of Communications is listed for hearing by the Estimates Committee, surely Australia Post is one of the matters that will be discussed. I repeat that I think it is a pretty shabby show. I know the difficult job that the secretariats have, but Senator Rae and others expressed the gospel about making Estimates committees more viable. It just did not work on Monday night, and the dilemma rests squarely with the Government. It has increased the number of Senate Estimates committees from six to eight, and some of us have to act like kelpie dogs and run round and round to catch up with them. On Monday I was able to attend the Committee but, like other senators, I have other Senate committees I want to patrol. I think that this is a pretty poor show. I say to the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Senator Peter Baume, who is at the table-this is not a personal attack on him-that I hoped when I asked for a fleshing out of the answer to question on notice No. 190, which dealt with overseas airmail concessions, that the Yugoslav communities in Sydney, Melbourne and Perth, for the benefit of the new senator from Western Australia, would receive a better answer. In fairness to the frank response I got from a member of the staff of the Minister for Communications, somebody said that the Yugoslav community had not asked about it.

Australia Post must do one of two things. Perhaps it sits on its backside and lets things go by, although I do not think that that is the answer. I suspect that somebody got out an atlas of Europe, closed his eyes and pointed to a country with a pin. If we are prepared to give concessions to the Netherlands, West Germany and Greece, then I cannot see why, in terms of geographical affinity, Yugoslavia was not included. I think that Senator Lajovic will agree with me that the Yugoslavs are proud people. They are not going to grovel and they should not have to. We hear a lot of drivel about everyone being equal. It is time that I got an answer to this question. I could easily inundate the Senate with petitions. I believe that this is a shabby show, and it is an insult to the Yugoslav community that it did not get the same response as other groups in the community received. I will be quite fair. I am not one who believes in privilege; I believe in equality. I say to the Minister that I hope Australia Post will give me a quicker answer to my second salvo than it did to my first.

There are two other matters to which I want to refer. One involves a strange magistrate named Nichols who operates in the Australian Capital Territory. As honourable senators know, I live in the electorate of Lowe. I am the resident senator there and the House of Representatives member is a former Prime Minister, Sir William McMahon. It is a quaint relationship; the electors have a pretty effective double. I was approached by a Mr Rowe from Abbotsford, which is in that electorate. Mr Rowe told me about the cross he has borne. On 25 November 1980 his son, John T. Rowe, and a friend were killed in a motor car accident in the Australian Capital Territory. Six charges were laid against a driver, who was travelling at 80 kilometres an hour. Magistrate Nicholls was content to fine the offender $250. My initial probings in the Australian Capital Territory reveal that the police here believe that people can get away with all sorts of mad driving if they come before Magistrate Nicholls. I have had a reasonable dialogue with the Minister for the Capital Territory (Mr Hodgman) on one or two other matters. This may be a matter for him or it may be a matter for the Attorney-General (Senator Durack). Considering the road toll, I think that there is something wrong with this magistrate's appeasement policy. A boy in his prime-20 years of age-was cut down and the offender got a miserable $250 fine. There were no counter-charges that the people in the panel van were at fault. The police laid six charges and the person got a $250 fine. It is a by-word in the Australian Capital Territory. There is not much point in the police doing extensive work to get statements, depositions and all the rest of it when we have a magistrate who perverts justice. I regret that Magistrate Nicholls perverts justice as far as major traffic offenders in the Australian Capital Territory are concerned.

We hear a lot about law and order, and it is rather significant that tonight the new senator from Western Australia referred to the late Ivor Greenwood. I remember early in the piece when that senator was a senior Minister, and I shared with him the idea of more effective gun control. I know that the States have certain responsibilities, but I want to refer to a recent meeting of police commissioners chaired by the South Australian Police Commissioner. Apparently there are Customs loopholes in relation to certain foreign assault weapons. A U2, which is an Israeli machine pistol, and a Soviet Union product apparently can be imported fairly easily, due to inadequate definition. I referred to a former Attorney-General, Ivor Greenwood, and I have spoken to subsequent Attorneys-General. Under our federal system, it is difficult to get unanimity between the States and their responsible ministers. There have been far too many seige cases lately involving people who have even gone beyond using armalite rifles. They have much more sophisticated equipment. I appreciate that there is a valid argument for people who live on farms in remote areas having a need for a rifle for certain purposes. My remarks are not aimed at them. The point I am making is that under the present regulations it is very easy for odd people to have access to high-powered weapons. I appeal to the responsible Minister, whether it be the Attorney-General or the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs (Mr Moore), who is in charge of imports, to take a hard line in this matter and, if necessary, call an early meeting of the appropriate Ministers with a view to blocking this loophole in the regulations.

I am pleased to see that Senator Carrick is present in the chamber. We have had extensive dialogue on the present uranium operations in the Kakadu National Park region of the Northern Territory. I think that the Minister and I accept virtually as gospel the second Fox report as far as co-existence between the developmentalists and the conservationists is concerned. The Koongarra uranium project is being mentioned frequently in the papers. It appears that the authorities are on the verge of granting approval regarding this project. With due respect to the autonomy of the Aboriginal community in this area, the plain fact of the matter is that as late as about six weeks ago the Senate Standing Committee on Science and the Environment, which is headed by Senator Jessop, questioned the Chief Scientist and his people on this subject and they could not promise that an additional mining operation in this area would not overload the fragile environment of the Alligator Rivers region. Another mining operation in this area could be a fatal blow.

If we go beyond the maximum number of mining operations in the Kakadu National Park area we will be ignoring the umpire's decision. I feel very strongly about that. As an advocate of conservation policies, I have tried to get co-existence between legitimate development and adequate protection for the environment. I say quite candidly that if we get away from and ignore the recommendations in the very costly second Fox report we will certainly provoke the conservationists. They are already rather cynical about the present situation.

While I am on the subject of conservation, I want to make a point in defence of Dr Mosley, the Director of the Australiam Conservation Foundation. I know of the long feud he has had with Senator Martyr from Western Australia. Let me say that I see a parallel between trade unionism and the aims of the conservation movement. The former does not always involve a log of claims. The unions must keep employers up to safety standards and a lot of other things. If the Conservation Foundation had not come into being, I doubt whether we would be still haggling over the Kakadu National Park, whether the wetlands of Coburg should be a reality and so many other things. They are issues on which governments have to draw a line. But the Conservation Foundation, whether it be through Dr Geoff Mosley, Milo Dunphy or those other fellows who, of course, are controversial, has a role to fulfil and it has done so. There has never been anything disreputable and money has been accounted for. The Foundation has endeavoured to educate people and it deserves support. Senator Martyr spoke about the need for a high degree of nationalism. Surely he would know that in years gone by when mining operations were not controlled a good deal of damage was done and the depradation was costly to repair. The Minister for National Development and Energy (Senator Carrick) and I represent the State of New South Wales and we are aware of the Lake George mining company fiasco. It was necessary for the Federal Government and the New South Wales Government to spend about $1.5m to rehabilitate damage which was occasioned to the Molonglo River area. There was also the earlier fiasco in the Northern Territory on the Finnis River. Damage was done because there was no control. Let us be fair about this matter; the Australian Conservation Foundation has a role to play.

Another matter I want to deal with relates to whaling. I think it can fairly be said that in the Senate-I will be polite about this-a small group of misguided Liberal senators tried to stop the passage of whaling legislation but sanity prevailed. The present policy virtually enjoys bipartisan support. I believe we have reached a satisfactory situation with our whaling protection legislation, and thank goodness. The 200-mile off-shore zone can be deemed as a mammal sanctuary. The people who support Project Jonah and other people feel that Australia is a bit slow when it comes to obtaining adequate marine research facilities and scientific know-how. Because we now have this off-shore zone, whales will be able to enter the waters around Australia with safety. This zone is a sanctuary for them. We do not have much knowledge on why schools of whales have beached themselves. The Tasmanian Government and the New South Wales Government in particular have been confronted with this problem. But when it comes to research into effective techniques to implement saving whales which beach themselves we are a bit slow. It is virtually a suicide operation for the whales. I do say to the Minister that I believe we all share a bipartisan attitude as far as the whaling legislation is concerned but we cannot stand still. We have to go forward and redouble our efforts in research so that we will be able to save whales which beach themselves.

I repeat that I hope that the fiasco before Estimates Committee B the other night is not repeated. I hope that when the estimates for a department are before a committee the department will have a full team present, not a skeleton force.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Robertson Sen E.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I join my colleague Senator Mulvihill in congratulating Senator Martyr for his maiden speech. Even though he has left the chamber, I am sure that he will be glued to the speakers outside the chamber to hear all the comments that we make about him. On behalf of the Opposition, I welcome him to the community of the Senate. Tonight I want to raise briefly in this first reading debate a matter which is of concern to parents, teachers and children in the Darwin area. There is a petition going forward to the Northern Territory Legislative Assembly at the present time. It reads:

SPEECH.PARA: The Petition of the undersigned in the Darwin area respectfully showeth:
That the proposed commercial development adjacent to Bullocky Point and alienation of parts of Darwin High School grounds:
would severely inhibit continued use of the bush area currently used for instructional purposes and activities by biology, physical education, geography and geology students
would prevent direct access to the beach which is used for instructional purposes
would be inappropriate close to a school
would place pressure on existing space due to a possible 20% increase in student population if Year 7 students are incorporated into high schools
would destroy one of the remaining bush areas close to the city-an area which contains rare trees
would remove public land from the foreshores
would place in jeopardy the proposed community recreation centre.

Let me give a little of the background to that petition. Darwin High School is built on Bullocky Point, as indicated by the petition. Bullocky Point is a small peninsula some two miles from the city centre. It is the site of the former Vesteys meat works.
