The area originally set aside for the high school complex was some 35 hectares. Some part of that area has been taken for the museum and art gallery which is being built. This is quite acceptable to staff and students of the high school and I will have more to say about this later. The present proposal is to reduce further the 35 hectares to 13 hectares. It is not only the reduction in the area that is opposed but also the purpose for which the land is to be put. The proposal is for a motel and water slide complex. The parents, the staff and the students are very much opposed to this sort of development. They have prepared the petition, part of which I have read, and they have sent letters to parliamentarians. I will read an extract from a letter signed by the President of the School Council, the President of the Student Representative Council and the Principal of the Darwin High School. It states:

A school is not an 'ivory tower' remote from the community it serves, but it is very much a special-purpose organisation. As it has been sited on Bullocky Point, Darwin High School has had several extremely valuable features:
Foreshore study access for study and sport;
Convenient access to and from the city and suburbs it serves, but freedom from the distractions and intrusions of every day commercial life; and
Useful proximity to the Botanical Gardens, and the valuable sports facilities of Gardens Oval, the Ski Club and the Bowling Club.

In regard to the first of those facilities, much of the detail there will be lost. Much is at risk. I think it is fair to say that there is a concept in town planning that certain kinds of buildings go together. I think it is also fair to say that this concept is basic to modern town planning which is utilised throughout the world. The Darwin City Council obviously concurs with this view because the present city plan embraces the concept. This is why we in Darwin accept the fact of the museum and the art gallery being close to the school. The school, the art gallery and the museum have a similar function and the art gallery and the museum provide a convenient annexe to the school. It will be convenient for students, when the museum and the art gallery open, to be able to go down and make use of those facilities.

The performing arts centre, which was originally to have been built close to the school, also would have been acceptable. The original plan was to have it just on the other side of the main road from Bullocky Point in the area close to the Salonika School. But this performing arts centre is now included in a private development project to be financed by an overseas company. I have spoken on this subject before. I have described how the Northern Territory Government and the Darwin City Council worked secretly together to give overseas companies public land. Northern Territory Government land, Federal Government land and city council land was given to an overseas company for the building of a motel and a performing arts centre complex. But, of course, it is not really that. What it is is a motel and a conference centre-the sort of thing we see in most cities. This $40m project will be built by overseas money. It is interesting that we have had no reaction from the Federal Government to my comments, made a couple of weeks ago, that it agreed to give its land to a foreign company. It seems strange to me, particularly after we heard the excellent debate this afternoon when there was a good deal of unanimity on both sides of the chamber on this matter of foreign investment, that not only are we keen to develop this but also we are prepared to give to these companies, which come to Australia, great areas of our own land. It is appropriate and, I think, fair to say that there is not a lot of support for the motel complex in Darwin. Joe Fisher is a former member of the Legislative Council and he now writes a weekly comment in the Northern Territory News. In the Northern Territory News of 4 April 1981, under the heading 'Justice must be seen to be done', he stated:
Territorians must have a voice in major community decision or living here will be meaningless.
The furore over incorporating the performing arts centre in a private development project is a healthy sign.
The take-it-or-do-without attitude of the Government and the civic corporation should be mellowed.
Docile acceptance of government and civic 'fait accomplis' over the past three years was a bad omen of indifference where the community's interests are concerned.

It is appropriate to have some developments on a site if there is enough room. We will not go into that argument, but it is certainly inappropriate to have others. As far as I am concerned, it is completely inappropriate to have a motel and a water slide within 50 metres of a secondary school's main entrance. I should not need to dwell on this point. I think that honourable senators would appreciate the undesirability of it. It is also inappropriate to have within walking distance the major casino complex in the Top End of the Northern Territory. This again was one matter in which the Northern Territory Government and the city council colluded in defiance of the expressed views of the people of the Northern Territory. The people do not count any more in the Northern Territory, so it would seem. We have a State-type government which has gone mad. These are not all the comments which I have made about the water slide, the motel and the casino. The letter from the parents' group, the childrens' group and the staff also had this to say:

On the other side of Bullocky Point, there is a big new marina planned and, with it, on what is now school land, medium-density housing. If all these plans were to go ahead, the School's land would be reduced to one third of its original size-one third of what it was at the time of self-government--

One third of what it was at the time when the Leader of the Government in the Senate handed over the education department to the Northern Territory Government. There is no appreciation of the traffic problems and no appreciation of the needs of the school. Because we have other matters to go on with, let me make the point that the development of a motel and a water slide complex is completely inappropriate so close to a high school. It creates entirely the wrong sort of environment. Let me make the additional point that the land taken from the school is needed by it for additional playing fields, for recreational facilities and for the biological and other studies which the letter quoted. There is no shortage of land in Darwin for the sort of development proposed. At the present time we seem to have the frightened fawn approach towards development in the Northern Territory which the Federal Government had so many years ago. The bulk of the development in the Northern Territory at the present time is foreign development. It is being done with foreign capital, and the buildings and the complexes are owned by foreign companies.

TALK.START.PARA: —And the profits.

—The profits will go back to those countries, as Senator Ryan has said. The Federal Government has some responsibility in this matter. Full statehood has not been achieved and will not be achieved for some time. Acts of the Northern Territory Legislative Assembly can be reserved for the Governor-General's assent. So some responsibility remains with the Federal Government. The Federal Government ought to require that there be much more public discussion, that there be more appropriate use of land resources, that safeguards be taken to make sure that the education available to the Darwin students is of the best possible sort, and that we retain the integrity of city planning. If we want to sum it up in one phrase we could say that the Federal Government has a responsibility to protect the people of the Northern Territory from a government which is swamping them in foreign developments.

SPEECH.PARA: Debate (on motion by Senator Carrick) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Earlier today the Government brought down a statement on health care in Australia. Insofar as it is a statement of government policy, it represents a recycling of numerous government initiatives over many years in relation to health care in Australia. It is a recycling because this is the fifth Fraser health policy to be enunciated in the Parliament. What is happening as a result of five changes in Fraser health policy is that the people of Australia are being used as social guinea pigs for experiments by the Fraser Government because of its difficulties in sorting out its ideological position on a variety of issues, and particularly the issue of health care.

SPEECH.PARA: The statement deals, in a long and somewhat argumentative manner, with a number of proposals on health care and purports to be a response to the report of the Jamison Commission of Inquiry into the Efficiency and Administration of Hospitals. It is a very patchwork document. I tell the listeners that if they look at the document which the Government has brought down today in relation to health care in Australia they will see that it is a patchwork document in the true sense. Not only is it a document which is typed and which is clearly set out in a number of respects, but also it is a document which has additions and changes which have clearly been made at the last moment and it is a last minute response, clearly, to the tortuous process of sorting out the Government's attitude to health problems in Australia.

It is Mark V, as I said, of the Fraser Governments health care responses. Let me quote the words of a journalist in the Sydney Morning Herald this morning who talked about the activities of the so-called razor gang of the Fraser Government which will cut government expenditure in a number of respects. The way the razor gang activities are being handled is, in the words of the journalist in the Sydney Morning Herald, not bad government but mad government. The statement brought down earlier today on health care is a typical example of mad Fraser Government as distinct from bad government to which we have become accustomed over the last five years.

The first thing I say about the statement brought down by the Minister for Health (Mr MacKellar) is that it ignores the principal findings of the Jamison Committee of Inquiry into the Efficiency and Administration of Hospitals to which it purports to be a response. Let me draw attention to one or two major issues which the Jamison Committee commented on. The response by the Government totally ignores the Jamison Committee's findings and its suggested method of dealing with the matter. The Jamison Committee opposed the absorption of hospital costs into general revenue grants. The Government will absorb hospital costs into general revenue grants. I will come back to that question in a moment. Secondly, I point out that the Jamison Committee was a joint initiative of the Federal and State governments, a sort of exemplification of the Fraser policy of new federalism, of co-operative relationships between State governments and the Federal Government on an important matter such as health care. The implementation of the report of the Jamison Committee is not an example of co-operative relationships between the State governments and the Federal Government. Let me point to that in a simple way by referring to the Victorian Minister of Health, Mr Borthwick, who described the way in which the Federal Government had responded to the provisions of the Jamison report as a cynical exercise. The Government was using the Jamison report as a method of launching yet another Fraser health policy on the Australian community and was not in fact responding to the terms of the Jamison report. So much for Fraser federalism and the notion of co-operation between the Commonwealth Government and the State governments on a wide variety of health matters which are crucial to the Australian people and crucial to all governments which provide health services.

The Fraser Government has had its response to the joint Commonwealth-State committee which dealt with health care described by a Liberal Minister of the Victorian Parliament as a cynical exercise. He has been joined by the Queensland Minister who has already criticised the Commonwealth Government's attitude towards the provision of health care services and the response to the Jamison report as he understood it in similar terms.

TALK.START.PARA: —What do you think of the absorption of these block grants?

—I hoped to come to that aspect in a moment, but as Senator Chipp has asked me what I think about the absorption of Commonwealth grants to hospitals into general revenue grants as distinct from specific purpose grants, let me say that the Opposition has no particular objection. However, it does object to one thing-the Government's stated intention that these Commonwealth funds will be earmarked for only a limited period. We take the view that if we do not earmark the Commonwealth contribution to health and hospitals in particular over a long period and in a sense in perpetuity the State governments will compete for a variety of purposes which may detract from the health care function of the State and Commonwealth governments. We are not saying that we disapprove of the States' administering hospitals with the assistance of general purpose grants from the Commonwealth. We are saying that the Commonwealth's contribution should be earmarked for health purposes continually. We think that is very important because we are concerned about national standards in health care and hospitals.

SPEECH.PARA: We do not quarrel with the concept of the Government's response which is in terms of general purpose health grants rather than specific purpose grants. We quarrel with the looseness of the Government's statement about how far the Commonwealth will specify that the Commonwealth money is available for health purposes. I will return to that subject in a moment when I speak in connection with community health services and school dental services. I say to Senator Chipp that I want it to be quite clear that the Opposition feels that a national government has a role to play in insisting as far as possible, on the maintaining of uniform national standards for hospitals and so on. Let me illustrate that point in a particular way by quoting Dr Lionel Wilson of the Australian Medical Association. The quotation to which I wish to refer concerns statistics on planning, building, facilities and manpower in relation to health. Dr Wilson said:

There is no rational information system allowing meaningful comparisons of the efficiency and effectiveness of health care delivery in the various States. Without such a system allocation of money will continue to be arbitrary.

The point Dr Wilson is making is that if we do not have some sort of Commonwealth supervision of the way Commonwealth money is spent we will get a very arbitrary system of allocating money for health services in Australia. We would be opposed to such an arbitrary system.

We take the view that at this point of our national history-if we can refer to this country as a nation-there is a minimum set of standards which should be applicable to all Australians in relation to the delivery of health care services. Under the Fraser Government policy Mark V there is no provision for a minimum national standard of health care services. When we talk about minimum national standards we have to bear in mind that culturally and socially in the Australian society there is one law, one provision, for the poor and another for the rich. That has been so for a long time. If a person is rich and ill everything is open to him. If a politician is ill all sorts of sophisticated medical care is available to him. If a person is poor and ill in Australian society those services are not available to him. That is a cultural and social fact of a society which we should bear in mind.

I turn now to a number of specifics of the statement brought down by the Minister for Health in the House of Representatives and also brought down by the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Senator Peter Baume) who represents the Minister for Health in the Senate. I said earlier that the statement is a very patchwork document. It has all the hallmarks of being put together at 4 o'clock this afternoon. It is a monument to the ineptitude of the Fraser Government, a Government which is characterised not by decision but by a capacity for indecision. The history of health care in Australia reveals that since 1976 we have had five experiments in mucking around with the provisions relating to health care and health insurance-five experiments on the Australian people who, by now, ought to be sick of being guinea pigs for the Fraser Government's ideological experiments in this field. We have before us a patchwork document which obviously was put together at 4 o'clock this afternoon. It is typical of this Government that this is so.

I referred earlier to the so-called razor gang, the report of which is presumably to be delivered tomorrow. As one commentator in the Sydney Morning Herald said this morning, this is not bad government; it is mad government. Of course, a Government which is obsessed with its own intrinsic divisions cannot possess a capacity to make decisions about these important matters. That is not possible for a government which is presided over by a Prime Minister who, in the words of one of its former distinguished Ministers, has a manic obsession with getting his own way. Such a Government cannot make decisions in the interests of the Australian people. This document is yet another monument to that fact. On 27 March the Minister for Health, Mr MacKellar, was saying in Melbourne something quite contrary in relation to health care to what is said in the statement that has been brought down tonight. Why has it been brought down in its present form? It is because the manic obsession of the Prime Minister has again prevailed over the advice of the Minister for Health.

I propose now to refer to some of the specific matters which are dealt with in the report. The Government set up the Jamison inquiry at a cost of half a million dollars. We who sit in the Senate, in contradistinction to all those who might be silly enough to sit listening to the broadcast of proceedings, know of numerous reports commissioned by the Government-such as the Holcroft report on aviation-which have been ignored when finally brought down. This is a Government which, in order to avoid making decisions, resorts to the appointment of inquiries and seeks the presentation of reports, thus obfuscating and eliminating the necessity for making decisions in the short term. The Jamison inquiry on hospitals in Australia cost half a million dollars. For a long time it was projected by the Government as a method of solving its problems in relation to health costs. Because the Jamison inquiry did not come up with the answers that the Government wanted, weeks of Cabinet meetings have been devoted to formulating the Government's fifth health scheme in as many years. The response to the Jamison Commission's report has been produced this week by the Government because the Premiers are meeting next week and the question of hospital and health funding as basic to their deliberations.

The Government has reversed one important Jamison recommendation. It is requiring means testing in regard to public hospital beds, a course which the Jamison inquiry rejected. It has reversed a second recommendation of the Commission in that it is absorbing hospital grants into general purpose grants, another course which the Commission rejected. Insofar as this is a response to the report, it is a facade. In the words of the Victorian Health Minister, it is a cynical exercise. Furthermore, the Government has now recommended a 32c tax rebate, a course which the Jamison Commission did not even consider. These are inventions and crazy fantasies of the Fraser Government projected in this response to the Jamison Commission's report.

The response indicates no real acceptance by the Government of the first tenet of the Jamison report: That the Commonwealth is a provider of funds, with overall responsibility for making available facilities which will promote the good health of the people of Australia. The document brought down tonight by the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Senator Peter Baume) is not one which is concerned with the good health of the people of Australia. It is one which is concerned with the ideology of the Fraser Government, an ideology which has been described by one eminent authority as manically obsessive and concerned with the saving of Commonwealth funds at the expense of the States and of the people of Australia. This is not a Government which is concerned with the good health of the people of Australia and it has produced a statement which shows that it is not.

As I said earlier, what is most important is that the Government is abandoning responsibility for national standards and national needs in regard to health care. It is really recycling the old days-going back to the health system of the 1950s and 1960s. Hospital costs, the community health care program and the school dental services will revert to the States and after this year will be incorporated in general revenue grants and earmarked for specific purposes.

What the Government has done, in the guise of telling the States that they will have freedom to spend the allocated funds, is dictate to them what they shall do. The Grants Commission has been allotted the unfortunate and unhappy role of working out the 'appropriate mechanism' for allocating funds between the States. That is a sad imposition upon the Grants Commission. No particular information is provided as to whether it can carry out that function. The Commonwealth is demanding that the States do exactly what it wishes. If not, funds for health will be cut. Implicit in this statement is that the funding of State public hospital systems can be reduced on a progressive basis without jeopardising the quality and standard of care provided in such hospitals. There is no evidence to support that implicit suggestion in the Government's response to the Commission's report. There is not one tittle of evidence that funds can be reduced and the same quality of care maintained in public hospitals.

If one reads the rhetoric in the first five pages of the statement by the Minister for Health-I invite Liberal Party senators, only two of whom are in the chamber tonight to read it-one will see that it contains all sorts of rubbish and gobbledygook about what the people of Australia should consider as appropriate in relation to health care standards. The people of Australia are invited to play a greater part, to accept a greater responsibility for their own health and health care. That is a laudable invitation, if I might say so to Senator Thomas, one of the two Liberal Party senators who happens to be in the chamber. It really means that the people of Australia are being invited, without being given any assistance from this Government-whatsoever the causes of ill health-to make a contribution additional to that which they have traditionally made. It is a very glib sort of statement. I find it extremely debatable, to say the least, to claim that despite cuts in funds the State hospital systems can deliver quality health care. I want to make one point in relation to Queensland. Queensland has provided for some years-37, I believe-a free hospital system. Under the terms of the statement brought down in the House of Representatives today by the Minister for Health, Mr MacKellar, it is estimated that the Queensland Government will have to pay an additional $100m from State funds if it is to maintain its free hospital system. I make that point specifically for people who live in Queensland and who have enjoyed what I believe is an excellent system of free hospital treatment.

TALK.START.PARA: —And there are no Government senators from Queensland even in the chamber.

—No, there are no Queensland senators from the Liberal or Country parties here tonight. They are probably out having a drink about the fortunes of their rival candidates for the Liberal Party leadership and discussing other matters of great moment to this country. In my view, it does not matter whether we have one lightweight or another as leader of the Government in this country. That is probably what they are doing tonight. I invite Senator Watson, a senator from Tasmania who has now come into the chamber-a laudable exercise, if I might say so-to tell his Queensland colleagues that it will cost the Queensland Government an extra $100m to provide the services it has provided in the past in relation to free hospital care in Queensland if this statement is carried into government policy. Senator Watson, I know, is a man of goodwill and I hope that he will tell Queensland senators in the morning about that prospect.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to deal with a number of matters in the statement, but let me just summarise some of the most important points. The first area I want to go into is health insurance funds. This is a government which in terms of its ideology and rhetoric has talked a great deal about individual freedom in Australia. Malcolm Fraser has talked in his numerous election speeches-he said it on 5 December last year in South Australia-about the importance of the freedom of the individual under Malcolm Fraser's Government. He said again yesterday, in a ludicrous response to the former Minister for Industrial Relations, how much he stressed the importance of the freedom of individuals to spend their own income in Australia under Malcolm Fraser.

Let us look at health care and health insurance and the freedom of the individual in Australia under Malcolm Fraser's Government. The Fraser Government, as a consequence of this statement, proposes to force all Australians into health insurance funds. They are all taxpayers, but they are to be forced into health insurance funds under the freedom which is provided by Malcolm Fraser's Government. They are to be forced into health insurance funds in a number of ways. First of all, there will be no Commonwealth benefit for uninsured patients, even though they are taxpayers. A taxpayer has no option; if he wants to receive the Commonwealth benefit for health insurance, from now on, under Malcolm Fraser's Government, he has to belong to a fund.

TALK.START.PARA: —What? No freedom of choice?
—No, there is no question of freedom of choice. That is the stick.
—It is like Eastern Europe.

—Somebody said that it sounds like Eastern Europe. The Fraser Government, the government of freedom of choice, the government of freedom of the individual, by providing Commonwealth health insurance benefits and tax rebates only to insured patients, is going to force all Australians into health insurance funds.
—Not the disadvantaged?
—I am sorry? A perceptive interjection, I detect.
—Not the disadvantaged?

—I want to come to that in a moment. There is a very small group of disadvantaged people which the Fraser Government recognises and to which a traditional sop has been extended. I invite the honourable senator to go back to his electorate in Tasmania and to tell somebody on $200 a week what he has to do under the new Fraser health insurance proposal. He has to join a fund, at accelerating contribution rates. He has to recognise that if he goes to a public hospital he will have to pay an increased daily bed fee. He has to recognise all those things. Liberal senators should tell such a person in the States they represent what that will mean to him. I hope they will do it honestly. There is no freedom of choice available to him. If Senator Watson can make a speech telling me that there is, I will be the first to applaud him.

SPEECH.PARA: So, there will be no Commonwealth benefits for uninsured patients-a stick from the Fraser Government, the government of freedom of choice. Secondly, there will be tax rebates only for insured patients-a stick from the Fraser Government, the government of freedom of choice and of individual liberty. Thirdly, the current optional insurance tables will be prohibited for all those who insure and there will be no free hospital treatment for bed day patients or for out-patients. What sort of society is that? What sort of society will Liberal senators tell us that is in terms of freedom of choice? I just draw attention to the fact that, under the free enterprise Fraser Government, the contributions to health insurance funds into which all Australians are to be forced by prescriptive legislation and by conscription will be raised significantly because of the increased hospital charges that the States will impose and because the facilities provided by the funds will have to take account of that fact.

TALK.START.PARA: —The increased membership surely will bring down the cost.

—I understand that increased membership of the funds will provide some set-off. I recognise that. But this is Mark V of the Fraser Government health policy. It is the same sort of disaster as the last four and it will benefit only the rich, not the poor and underprivileged in Australian society. I will be happy to debate that in six or seven months time with any senator on the Government side.
—Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —These measures, I think, represent rough surgery on what is admittedly the sick man of Australian public life-our health system-but the Australian Democrats think it is perhaps necessary rough surgery. It would be delightful for all of us if somehow the huge and growing costs of medical care in Australia could be paid for by somebody else. That would be just fine, but unfortunately it does not work that way. One way or another, we pay for it ourselves. I was rather disappointed to hear the Opposition spokesman on health, Dr Neal Blewett, on tonight's PM program on the Australian Broadcasting Commission deplore the passing of free hospitals. There have never been and never will be free hospitals. The community pays in one way or another. I think we have had that lesson spelt out time and again over the last few years by the enormous increase in costs, which in my view are demonstrably necessary, particularly in hospital administration.

SPEECH.PARA: It is a fact that if unlimited amounts of money are made available to bureaucrats they will spend it and go on spending it in enormous quantities, apparently regarding the public purse as bottomless. It is not bottomless. These enormous costs have been reflected already in huge costs to the Australian public for health care, whether or not people are insured. It is against that background that the Australian Democrats acknowledge these measures as at least the Government's effort to remove some of the fat from health care costs. The extent to which that effort is successful will be reflected in due course in the cost of health insurance. Senator Watson interjected a while ago and said that additional membership should provide a set-off. Senator Button conceded that point. Let us hope that that is so. Let us see what does happen in that area.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator, you have said in this chamber that the New South Wales Government should have funds to spend on upgrading hospitals and aged persons homes.

—Indeed, I have, Senator Tate. That is a point I will return to later in this speech. The way in which funds are spent, which I think Senator Tate will concede was more the point I made in that speech and I will make it again, is an interesting argument in the whole matter of block funding versus the absorption principle. I take the view that we are not necessarily going to ensure that there is any real control over the way a State spends its Budget allocation by having it as a special purpose grant if it is merely for health care. The situation will come about in which institutional spending will take priority over everything else because it is easier for public servants to administer it. That is one thing that worries me about this whole situation. In any case, these measures may not be successful. We shall wait and see. The Australian community will be watching them with great care and, no doubt, will make political judgments on whatever happens.

SPEECH.PARA: The policy of the Australian Democrats from the inception of the party has been for a community funded national health scheme in which we would seek to maintain fee for service private practice but on a community service basis. In other words, we see a strong obligation on the medical profession to do, in many cases, better than it has done in the past, to provide a real service to the society. By that we mean that doctors should be available in every locality on a 24-hour basis and that doctors should get together in group practices and make sure that they do that. It is only on the basis that they provide that service to the community that they should come to a government or the community and say that they have a right to earn money from it. They have no automatic right to rip off the public, as pathologists are doing to a disgusting extent in this country. Enormous fortunes are being made by medical pathologists, quite unnecessarily. That profession must clean up this kind of Aegean stable before I will agree, and I think most other Australian Democrats will agree, with the Government's view that private enterprise alone can deal with this problem and that there should not be any other form of medical service in this country. That is something I will return to in a few minutes.

It is also our policy-this is a matter I still commend to the Government-that higher excises on alcohol and tobacco should go directly to help finance national health measures in view of the very considerable financial burden that the diseases related to these products impose on the community. I think that is a matter that should not be lost sight of. I think it is a perfectly valid view for a community to hold. Why should the great majority of Australians who do not destroy their health in this way have to pay for the indulgences and the self-inflicted wounds of those who do?

We would like to see much greater emphasis placed on preventative medicine and on community health services which are aimed at health maintenance. We hope that these objectives eventually will be realised. They must now be pursued at the State government level because the basic truth about the proposals we are debating tonight is that the Commonwealth Government is abdicating a very considerable area of responsibility and, curiously, retaining other areas. The Australian Democrats would ask: Is the Government now to use the absorption principle of including all the funds for public hospitals, the general community health program and the school dental service in general revenue grants? It says that on page 10 of the statement. It says that all those things will, indeed, go into general revenue grants. If so, why is the Government, as described on page 19 of the statement, taking over full responsibility for the payment of nursing home benefits? If the State governments can be trusted with the vast body of medical care, why not trust them with this area also? It seems to me to be inconceivable that they should not be trusted to see that the aged and chronically ill are not thrown to the wolves. There is an inconsistency in this area which I would like a Government senator to explain to me at some stage.

It is fairly common knowledge that the decision whether funds should be absorbed into general revenue grants or block grants over which the Commonwealth Government would retain some control has been an agonised one. I have some comments to make on that. If, indeed, funds are to be absorbed into general purpose grants, we must hope that all State governments will at all future times, take a proper and responsible view of their obligation to provide, as is stated on page 1 of the ministerial statement, 'health care services of high quality at a cost the individual and the community can afford'. I do not necessarily believe that block grants purely for medical purposes would avoid that. Surely it is the priority of spending that is important. On an earlier occasion in the Senate, I raised a matter concerning a body scanner approved for the Royal Perth Hospital. I raise the matter again now because it is interesting. There was some criticism earlier this year by a health care consumers association in Western Australia of the decision to provide, at a cost of $75,000, a new body scanner for the Royal Perth Hospital. This was the fourth body scanner for Western Australia. That gave Western Australia exactly the same number of scanners as are operating in the whole of Britain. I wonder whether that kind of situation will continue. As I said earlier, I think to Senator Tate, institutional spending is easier because public servants can administer it easily and apparently there are no hard, controversial areas concerned with it.

Another point-I think all of us in this place ought to consider it-is that for a long time the community has tended to regard the Federal Government-in Canberra-as being responsible for health care. Community attitudes and knowledge of what we are doing change very slowly indeed. I venture to predict that, in view of this conditioning, the public will tend to do that in the future. It will take a long time before most people fully realise that the States became responsible when these measures went forward. If things go very wrong, I suggest that there could still be a backwash of opinion directed at Canberra. This is, in a sense, an argument for general purpose grants. At least, if the money has gone to the States and they have the responsibility for providing health care they have that responsibility squarely and in time the community will realise that. If they get a block grant they can come back and say: 'We bought body scanners and things like that but we do not have enough money. We want more money now'. I think that is a situation which is to be avoided if, indeed, the Government is to persist with this idea that the States are to do it all. If they are to do it all, I think they should accept that responsibility.

Due to the obligation which will now rest on the States to raise hospital bed costs, the costs of health care for Australians throughout this country will rise. I would like now to come to the problem of the single income family. It cannot be stressed sufficiently-I think this is constantly overlooked-that the financial constraints in this area are very real. I am not speaking about just a few Australians. I am speaking about possibly tens of thousands, even hundreds of thousands, of young families. These people cannot claim to be disadvantaged in the terms of these proposals. They have an income and they have jobs but they also have very high commitments, especially if they are renting houses, paying off furniture on hire purchase, paying off a car, buying shoes for the children and doing all the things that young Australians have to do. They may be actually unable to meet medical insurance costs or they may be very severely inclined to give them a lower priority than other things. In other words, they will cut corners and take risks because they simply do not see that they have the money to spare. To the Australian Democrats that seems to be a major fault of these new proposals.

A little earlier tonight Senator Martyr made his maiden speech. He is a Liberal Party senator. I take this opportunity to congratulate him for his first speech in this chamber and I welcome him here. In his maiden speech he made a point about the needs of the family. He said that we need more children in this country and we are below replacement level. If that is so, how can he, as a Liberal Party senator, support these proposals? How can he say that people will not be able to afford to have children? Under these principles they cannot. The Government in these principles is bringing forward a positive disincentive to people to have children. It is one of many positive disincentives. I think it is time the Government realised that it is doing this, whether deliberately or not, to great effect. If, as Senator Martyr says, not enough children are being born in Australia now, I suggest he should look for the beam in his own eye before he looks for the mote in somebody else's. He is a member of the Liberal Party. It is his job to see that something is done about these matters.

Even worse is the situation of people who actually have children. Their children have been born and they have a young family of perhaps three or four young children. These people are Australians of the future. They should be to us the most important people in our society. They are the next generation. They are the perpetuation of this country after we have left it. We have very grave responsibilities to them. Are we now saying that we are going to create a situation in which these young people, who do not ask to be born into this country and who have no political decision-making capacity, will have to take the risk of ill health, some aspects of which could perhaps be carried right through into their adult life? This is because their parents, with the best will in the world and after agonising over the matter, feel that they cannot afford health insurance or, even worse, they have taken the chance of not taking out health insurance? They are now very much caught in a catch-22 situation. It is a desperate situation. As far as the Government is concerned, unless they can prove that they are disadvantaged-provided the father is working-those children will suffer, and will suffer badly. They will get absolutely no help from anybody.

We in the Australian Democrats say that there has to be an escape area. We would go back to our own policy. We say that the best kind of escape area would be for the Government to see some kind of merit in other points of view. I know that in these proposals the Government has said that it believes that private enterprise, fee for service and medicine has to be the whole mainstay of the system. Be that so, surely the Government has sufficient social conscience and awareness to realise that there may be groups who will suffer in this situation. If we are to be very categorical over something we are going to hurt somebody. I would have thought that that was a basic political principle that people should understand. Why then, should then Government not recognise that community health services-community health centres-particularly in suburbs occupied by working people in which there are people with young families, are essential if these measures are to proceed. Then, if a family has a problem it will have at least somewhere to go. The children of that family will not be left to suffer because the Government has not really thought this matter through enough and has not provided an opportunity for a desperate plight to be remedied.

Of course, the Government will say: 'That does not matter. In the future those matters will be for the States. If you want any moves for innovations and improvements in health services it will now be in the arena of State politics'. I suggest that that attitude is not really good enough. If the Government wants to see reasonable health care provided for all Australians-I suggest that that is still very much a part of our responsibility in this place and will be seen by the public as part of our responsibility, which I think is rather important-we have to encourage those health centres and perhaps even pay for them as well. The Government has taken the view, as I said earlier, that there are areas in which it will help. It is to provide funds for the aged and chronically ill so that they are not thrown to the wolves. I say to the Government that it ought also to perceive in this area of young families that are on, below or just above the average income, another area of possible need where some remedial circumstances may be necessary. I hope that the Government will not neglect that area in the interests of many tens of thousands-perhaps hundreds of thousands of young Australians. One can hope, I suppose, that with enlightened State governments, health commissions and health departments there will be a greater accent on preventative medicine and a recognition of the needs of families that are being paid below or not too much beyond the average wage.

There will now be a requirement on the States to provide free hospital services only to eligible pensioners and their dependants and the disadvantaged. Of course the Australian Democrats agree that those categories of people should be taken care of. But we are also concerned at the definition of the disadvantaged as set out on page 17 of the statement, particularly the third definition, which is terribly vague at this stage. It refers merely to 'persons who meet a specified income test'. That does not tell us very much. We do not know what the specified income test is. We would hope that it would not be set too rigidly. In particular, we would ask that very significant variations be made to it in an upwards direction by negotiation with the States to provide for the number of children in a family. I would like to hear from the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Senator Peter Baume) later. I take it that that would probably be a principle which would have to be subscribed to.

TALK.START.PARA: —There will be an opportunity.

—I thank the Minister for the acknowledgement. He concedes that point, I am sure. The mere fact that he has done so will ease the minds of many Australians who are listening to this debate tonight and who are wondering just what is to happen to them and their health problems in the future. There is also an aspect of humiliation in proving low income. I think much will depend on how the test is administered. I do not think it is at all good that we should have a society in which people are compelled by the circumstances of law and necessity to lose their dignity, their self-respect. I think it is vitally important that people should be able to maintain those qualities, whatever else they do. If they are poor-maybe they are poor through no fault of their own-at least they should be allowed to retain their self-respect. We trust that it will be with compassion and discretion that this income test is carried out. I think the Government may have to give some special thought to that matter also, to see that we have no procedures that smack of eighteenth century poor house administration.

SPEECH.PARA: I am trying to speak within the general framework. With all respect to Senator Button, I do not think it is of much use saying to the Government that it is doing everything wrongly. If it is going to do something, let us look at the proposal to see what is the best way of doing it. That is certainly our view. Within the general framework the Government has laid out in this statement, there is provision for a tax deduction for health insurance costs over and above the general rebate. It is to be fixed at 32c in the dollar, so that the wealthy are not advantaged over the battlers, and this is a good thing. We are pleased to see that provision. We hope that it will be maintained.

We also applaud the Government for the provisions described on page 19 of the statement which are 'to increase assistance for the aged and chronically ill through greater support to organisations providing home nursing services'. We agree very much that to help keep aging persons out of institutions, in their own homes, for as long as possible, is a worthy aim. We support it absolutely. We say that on the evidence of the past it has not been subscribed to nearly enough in Australia. In town after town, one finds that domiciliary services have been cut back. I think it is tragic that that has happened. I cannot see that there is any economic gain in it. If we cut out a domiciliary service that might be looking after half a dozen people in their own homes, we then have to put these people in institutions and immediately increase our costs. I believe that that is indeed a crazy way of looking at health care finance. We applaud the Government for that provision. We urge it to take that principle just as far as it can. We believe that the further it takes it, the more it will make people happy and keep health costs down.

There may well be heavy criticism of the Government over these measures-indeed, it has already come from the Opposition-but we in the Australian Democrats believe that there has been a necessity to grasp the nettle and this has been done. We trust and expect that the Commonwealth will watch developments in the future quite closely to see whether this experiment in greater State responsibility is successful and that it will reserve the right to intervene if it is not. I think the Government owes the Australian people at least that much.

The question of the spending of money and the priorities of health care worries me a little. I mentioned the matter of the use of a body scanner in Perth. Recently during the adjournment debate in this place I had occasion to mention the Allandale geriatric hospital at Cessnock in New South Wales. It is the largest geriatric hospital in New South Wales. I saw it recently for myself. As I said in the Senate, it represented a degree of utter misery and total discomfort for the unfortunate elderly people there. It might have come from the pages of a novel by Charles Dickens, so degrading and so terrible was the plight of those people. I may say that I have heard quite recently from the New South Wales Health Minister, Mr Kevin Stewart. He wrote to me telling me that close on $250,000 will now be spent on Allandale to correct the problems about which I wrote to him and which I mentioned here in the adjournment debate. That kind of response from a State health department-it was a prompt, reasonable response to what I had said-is a good one. It is a hopeful augury that greater State control, at least in New South Wales, will work.

All other things being equal, the Australian Democrats believe in devolution of political power. Viewed in the broadest possible way, these measures pass power on to smaller units-the States themselves. It has been said by Opposition spokesmen that less money will be available to the States. But the States will at least have the power stool to ask for money, to lay down their needs and then to spend the money wisely. Surely it is a question of priorities. Allandale is a good case in point. If a fraction of the money that was spent on the body scanner in the West-I know that I am speaking of another State-had been spent on Allandale, 500 old people could have had a reasonable life in their closing days. Instead, that place has been a living hell for years. I do not think it is right that that should happen. It worries me a little that there is not any overall national view of that matter. I think it can be looked at in the light of public opinion to make sure that the States are spending this money wisely. If there are any areas of gross misspending, that could be brought to public attention.

The Australian Democrats ask: What will be the future of the Commonwealth Health Department? Will it continue to function effectively into the future? What will its role be? What will it continue to cost the community? Will that cost be justified because of the reduced responsibilities that it will now bear? I would ask the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Senator Peter Baume) if he speaks, to give us some insight into that matter. I feel it would be of considerable interest to the public to know the answer. We do not want a residual Health Department of large proportions in Canberra which no longer has any responsibilities or much work to do. That is something we have to accept and that the Government ought to accept. It has created this situation. It is up to the Government now to tidy up that aspect as well.

We would ask also for rationalisation of the health funds. This is a matter which I regard as a most important part of Australian Democratic policy. Tax deductibility of health fund premiums will now provide the funds with a huge subsidy at public expense. That really ought to get the health funds on their feet and I believe they ought to give due credit for it. May we now see a situation in which they give real value for money? That means a cutback in their extensive competitive advertising which has cost the consumer vast sums of money-quite unnecessarily and unjustifiably, and a cutback in the costs involved in the duplication of such things as staff and computer equipment.

We hear a lot of talk in this place, especially from honourable senators opposite that there should be fewer trade unions. We agree with this. It is obviously more efficient. Let us then take that principle further. There should perhaps be fewer health funds. Let us have a spirit of competition; but beyond that, let us at least have economically sized units so that the public is not expected to keep this industry going. There is a rather important implication in these proposals-that is, that the Commonwealth Government has now virtually committed itself to supporting these private funds. They have been made an integral part of the health system. They have been given the opportunity of a continued life, a virtual guarantee to print money for themselves. It is up to the Commonwealth Government to see that that money is spent wisely and with greater responsibility than has been shown in that area in the past.

The Australian Democrats believe that the Australian public will not accept another messed up medical health setup. The Government has its last chance in this matter. If it messes up this scheme, or if the scheme turns out to be a mess, I suggest that the backlash from the community will be very considerable, and rightly so. But granted good will and a genuine desire to give service on the part of all the areas concerned, these proposals may work. It is that desire to give service on the part of the areas concerned that is probably far more important than the mechanism we use. I think it has to be understood that a new scheme, a new set of health proposals, will not be a panacea for anything. It will not make up for the doctor and the pathologist who rip off their patients. It will not make up for the doctor who says: 'I am going to induce this birth because I want to play golf this afternoon'. That does happen; I know that it happens fairly frequently. I think the Commonwealth Government might at least provide some kind of continuing mechanism-perhaps this could be a role for the Health Department, if it is to continue at all, and I suppose it will-to consult the community regularly so that these proposals can be modified progressively from now on. We can only regard these proposals as a sort of crude beginning, a new direction. Whether they work will depend very much on the extent to which the community is consulted and the extent to which the proposals can be modified in the future to meet the reasonable requirements of the community. I would suggest to the Government that just to say that it is going to start this machine off and let it run along its rails without any further interference would be a complete and absolute abdication of its responsibility. It is, after all, the Government of this country and I think it has certain responsibilities in the area.

The Australian Democrats support that policy of consultation wholeheartedly. We expect and hope that the Commonwealth Government will provide machinery nationally to see that at long last the people begin to get what they reasonably want and need.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: — This evening we are debating a statement which was brought down in this place by the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Senator Peter Baume). That statement outlines the Government's new health scheme. When my colleague, Senator Button, was speaking, he mentioned that there were no Queensland senators present in the chamber. He was, of course, referring to Queensland senators on the Government benches, and certainly there were none present at that stage. I think I should point out at this stage that there was a Queensland senator from the Australian Labor Party in the chair at the time and there was also one sitting here waiting to speak. At one other stage also a Labor Party senator from Queensland was in the chamber for a short time. Whilst there were no honourable senators from Queensland on the Government benches present to speak on this matter or even to listen to the comments about the statement which was brought down, there were Labor senators from Queensland present. I point out that at the moment there are still no senators from Queensland present in the chamber on the Government benches.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to make some comments tonight about the way this statement that was presented, and the new scheme that is contained in it, will affect the people of Queensland. This point was touched upon by Senator Button, but I should like to go into it in greater depth. This new scheme will not be well received in Queensland. In the next few days, and tomorrow in particular, I can understand that the debate in Queensland will be very much against this new scheme that has been brought in. The debate will continue over the next few days. The reason for this is that for many years Queensland has prided itself on its free hospital system. The previous speaker, Senator Mason, had some disparaging things to say about the free hospital system. He said that there was no such thing. We have had a free hospital system in Queensland since 1944, when it was introduced by a Labor government. It was carried on by that government and it has been carried on by successive National-Liberal governments in Queensland since that time. I could debate the idea of a free hospital system at length. I will not do so, but let me just mention these points. In Queensland, when we send our children to a primary school, we do not send them with fees in their pockets to pay the teachers' salaries. We accept the fact that if a burglar burgles our home and a policeman is called, the policeman is not paid cash when he comes around to investigate. It is the general revenue that pays for those services. This is the same principle that we have used in Queensland with our hospital system. Since 1944 we have had a hospital system in which one can obtain free of charge the best medical care in Australia. Any person who becomes ill or who is involved in an accident does not have to worry about medical charges because of our free hospital system. If a motor cyclist in Brisbane has the misfortune to have an accident and is taken to the Royal Brisbane Hospital, he obtains medical treatment there without charge. He has certainly got enough worries because he came off his motor cycle. He certainly has enough worries because of his injury. But he does not have the financial worry that is attached to his hospitalisation. This is the system that we have had in Queensland for 37 years. If a child becomes ill on Thursday Island, that child is taken to the Thursday Island Hospital. The parents may have some worries about that child's illness, but they do not have the worry about the financial burden that might be placed on them if we did not have that free hospital system. The same system pertains throughout all of Queensland.

I said that this free hospital system was introduced in 1944. It has been a firm commitment under Labor and non-Labor governments. A little while ago Senator Walters asked me whether I agreed with my Premier on this matter. There are very few things that I agree with my Premier on, but she would find that all parties in Queensland-the Labor Party and the National-Liberal coalition-have a commitment to the free hospital system. Whatever party is in power in Queensland, whether it is the current coalition or whether there is a change of government and we have an Australian Labor Party government, one would find that both of those groups of parties would give a high priority to the free hospital system. But in the statement that was given to us today there is direct pressure on the Queensland Government to alter its policy of a free hospital system. I shall quote from pages 13 and 14 of the statement. The statement says in part:

The Government has therefore decided that the funding to be allocated to New South Wales, Victoria, Western Australia, Queensland and the Northern Territory that represents its interest in the provision of health services should be equal to-
This is the first major point-
the sum necessary to maintain in real terms the funding provided in 1980-81 for public hospitals, the general community health program, and the school dental scheme;
And this is the other point-

less a share of the revenue the States could be reasonably expected to raise through the introduction of appropriate in-patient and out-patient charges in 1981-82 and the user pays principle in public hospitals.

Let us go back to that first point. I just wonder how long this sum-and remember, the sum was said to be the sum necessary to maintain in real terms the funding provided in 1980-81 for public hospitals-will be available. We are all aware of the changes that the Government has made in health care in the last 5 1/2 years. When this statement was first issued tonight I admit that I had lost count of how many changes we had had in those 5 1/2 years. Senator Button, in his speech, mentioned that this was the fifth health program that this Government had put foward. But what is the point in knowing that it is the fifth or the fourth or something like that because it is inevitable, if one looks at the history of this Government and its health care programs, that more changes are likely to be on the way. We just know that there has been change after change. How long will this sum, the sum necessary to maintain in real terms the funding provided in 1980-81 for public hospitals, be available? There is a hint in earlier parts of the Minister's speech that we will have such a change. I shall quote part of that speech:
It-
That is, the Government-

agreed with the Commission that the responsibility of the States should be more clearly defined and that they should be required to take up their full responsibilities for the provision of health services.
The statement went on to say:
In reaching this decision the Government has been mindful of the warning of the Commission of Inquiry that one should hasten slowly.
Later on it said:
. . . dramatic changes cannot be made over night.

Later on in the statement there is talk about the initial period of the new arrangements. Those parts of the statement seem to indicate quite clearly that we will have changes, changes that will affect this part of the new arrangements which says that we are going to maintain in real terms the funding provided in 1980-81 for public hospitals. But the real rub, and the real rub for the people of Queensland and for Queensland hospitals, is contained in the second section of those two factors which were outlined, the section which outlines the way in which the Federal Government will allocate funds for public hospitals. I reiterate that the statement says that the funds will be provided:

. . . less a share of the revenue the States could be reasonably expected to raise through the introduction of appropriate in-patient and out-patient charges in 1981-82 and the user pays principles in public hospitals.

What this means is that the Commonwealth will determine an amount that the States should raise through in-patient and out-patient charges and it will take this amount away from the amount that it would otherwise have provided for the hospitals in the States. The Minister for Health (Mr MacKellar) and the Minister representing the Minister for Health, Senator Peter Baume, who introduced this statement in this chamber, know quite clearly that everything possible will be done in Queensland to maintain the free hospital system. They know that if they are going to take funds away from Queensland because Queensland will not impose in-patient and out-patient charges, this is really nothing but a not-too-subtle form of blackmail of the people of Queensland. It is not an approach that will be received well by Queensland residents. How much is the Federal Government going to penalise Queensland for continuing to maintain its free hospital system? At this stage, I do not really know. But let us look at one part of the statement made today, which says:
. . . the States raise the bed day charge in public hospitals from $50 for a shared room and $75 for a private room to a level which more closely approximates to the actual daily bed cost involved.

Of course, in Queensland, if one goes into a public hospital and is there as an in-patient, one does not pay a bed charge. So I just wonder when we look at that $50 and that $74 whether Queensland will be penalised at least $50 per bed per day.

Another figure was introduced here this evening. Senator Button said that his research indicated that it would cost the State Government of Queensland an extra $100m a year if this new system were in operation. Some might say that it was the Leader of the Labor Party in the Senate saying that and perhaps that was exaggerated. Well, if it is exaggerated, the Minister for Health in Queensland, Mr Austin, is exaggerating even more. I would think that the Minister for Health in Queensland would have much better resources at his command so that he could estimate this more precisely than we are able to do here. Mr Austin, the Minister for Health in Queensland, said today that if Queensland were to maintain its free hospital system it would have to find as a minimum an extra $150m a year by the end of 1982. Whether it is $100m a year or $150m a year or even something less than that, say $50m a year, it is a hefty penalty that this present Government is placing on the people of Queensland for their wanting to maintain their free hospital system.

It is not as though Queensland has been generously treated in the past by this Government. When the hospital cost sharing arrangements commenced Queensland started with a low base of hospital funding. Because the allocation of federal finance was based on that low base, the amount that Queensland received was lower than that of the other States and Queensland could not improve its position in relation to the other States. I would like to illustrate that by quoting from volume 2 of the Jamison report. For those who are interested, I am quoting from page 95 of that report. Referring to the relative position of the States, the report states:

The Queensland Department of Health in its submission demonstrated that because budgets are prepared by escalating a base year figure of the actual expenditure during the previous year, by various cost producing factors, a State which starts off from a low base can never improve its position relative to other States. This becomes especially evident if some arbitrary percentage increase is applied in the level of funds allocated from one budget to the next.

Page 96 of the Jamison report quotes the operating costs for the State public hospitals throughout Australia, and I will refer to the 1978-79 figures. The table covers both 1977-78 and 1978-79. These are per capita expenditure figures for the various States; New South Wales was $156.7 and Victoria $134.76. Queensland was the lowest with $127.95. When we look at South Australia, Western Australia and Tasmania, we find that Western Australia has the highest expenditure per capita with $189. That seems to give the lie to the theory that if one has a free hospital system it will be an expensive hospital system. In Queensland we spend less per capita on public hospitals than is spent in any other State, the highest expenditure being in Western Australia, where it is about $60 per capita more than in Queensland. Because we started off with that low base and because the funds provided to Queensland under the hospital cost sharing agreement were on that basis, Queensland was never able to get ahead. I will illustrate that point by indicating the amount that the Commonwealth pays to the States for public hospitals. Again I refer to the Jamison report, Volume 2, page 102, and quote the figures for just one year. Although the table mentions costs for five years, they all show the same picture. Queensland received the lowest amount from the Commonwealth for its public hospitals-$70.54 per capita. The highest amount was received by Western Australia-$101.93. The point is that Queensland has received less money than any other State. It is not as though Queensland has been generously treated in the past by the Commonwealth and now suddenly something must happen and Queensland must bear the extra burden of $100m, according to my leader, or $150m, according to the Health Minister in Queensland. It is not as though Queensland has been treated well. It has not been treated so well as all the other States.

There is a clear indication that one of two things will happen when this new scheme is introduced. Either Queensland taxpayers will foot an additional bill of $100m a year or there will be a severe and drastic cutback in medical services in Queensland. Many statements have been made about the new system the Government is bringing forward, and I will mention one that was made by the Queensland President of the Doctors Reform Society. According to an AAP statement, the President, Dr Bor, condemned the changes as being socially inequitable. He said:
The changes further create two classes of patient, the poor and the wealthy, with the wealthy able to afford full health care insurance and be reimbursed by tax deductions.

He predicted that Queensland will be forced to abandon its free hospital system. That is one of the two consequences that I predicted would happen. Either Queensland will be forced to abandon its free medical services or it will face this extra cost of $100m a year. When the Government introduced this measure this afternoon, I am sure that it forgot that the Senate was part of the Parliament and that it was thinking only of the House of Representatives. The statement that was placed before us in the Parliament this afternoon commenced:
Mr Speaker, the fundamental goal of this Government . . .

One could say that a mistake was made and that instead of putting Mr President somebody put Mr Speaker, but it was quite clear to me that all the Government was thinking about was the House of Representatives. When we go to page 12 of the document that was handed to me it again states:
Mr Speaker, I would draw the House's attention to the fact . . .

This is the statement that was put in front of us. If the Government forgot that it had a Senate, I am sure that it will not forget that it has one when it brings the enabling legislation into the Parliament. That enabling legislation, for the system that was outlined to us today, will have to pass through this chamber. It will have to run the gamut of opposition, not only from this side but also, I presume, from Queensland senators on the other side. No Queensland senator worth his salt will stand idly by and see legislation of this nature, which will take away the free hospital system in Queensland, go through. Only about a fortnight ago I picked up my Courier-Mail after Mr Austin, the Minister for Health, had rung all honourable senators in this place. The Courier-Mail said that all ten Queensland senators will not stand by and see Queensland's free hospital system taken away. When the legislation comes before this place, it will be interesting to see what Queensland senators on the other side will do. There is no doubt that this system will be disastrous for Queensland's free hospital system, a free hospital system that we have had since 1944, a free hospital system which has been upheld by a Labor government and a National-Liberal coalition.

One of the popular myths in Queensland is that profits of the Queensland Golden Casket lottery pay for the Queensland public hospitals. Rather than interrupt the theme I was developing, at this stage I will seek leave to continue my remarks later because I believe that some legislation is to be brought forward.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

Bill (on motion by Senator Chaney) read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to incorporate the second reading speech in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

The Designs Amendment Bill 1981 is a further development in the Australian industrial property system. It introduces the first substantial changes to the designs legislation since federation. Its aim is to encourage innovation and industrial design within the community. To this extent the Bill reflects the Government's continuing commitment to reforming Australia's industrial property system. It seeks to make industrial property more responsive to our needs in developing and exploiting Australia's innovative technology.

Designs are probably the least understood of possessions collectively known as industrial property rights. Most people are only vaguely familiar with the meaning and advantages of patents, registered trade marks and copyright rights. The availability of design protection often surprises manufacturers and importers, distributors and retailers. Yet these are the very people who benefit by being able to suppress unfair competition or who could take steps to avoid infringement of another's design rights. This lack of understanding is particularly unfortunate when a business is founded on a new or improved product as its only real asset.

Designs, in the sense of eye-appealing industrial creations as opposed to mechanical contrivances, can be protected in Australia by a registration procedure which has existed for 75 years. Industrial designs have been created by manufacturers who consciously sought to enhance the sales appeal and competitiveness of their products through ornamentation. Nevertheless, functional considerations have tended to predominate. It is, however, only in comparatively recent times that industrial designing has intensified. It has been encouraged by the need to exploit wider markets; domestic and overseas competition; increased media advertising and display; the discovery of many new processes and materials; and, the higher level of community education.

If good design is to flourish, those responsible for producing it must be protected. To this end, industrial designs have been safeguarded by legislation through registration. Anyone who produces a new or original design may protect it by registering it at the Designs Office. The right given by registering a design is a monopoly and can be infringed without copying taking place. The monopoly conferred by registration is, however, subject to review by the courts, which have the power to declare any design registration invalid. Thus registration is the only prima facie evidence that the design is valid. This Bill recognises that in this country changes to designs legislation can greatly improve the incentives for innovative design.

In 1970 the Government set up the Designs Law Review Committee to determine what changes would be appropriate to Australian conditions. It advocated the inclusion of new provisions in the designs legislation. The report has been widely circulated and received support from those using the design system in Australia. Under the new legislation designs will be registered initially for one year. This period can be extended so as to give the owner of a design a maximum of 16 years protection. This will apply provided the Registrar is not made aware, either from members of the community or in any other way, of any matter affecting the registration's validity. This Bill introduces a specific provision empowering the Registrar to undertake searches to establish the newness or originality of the design for which registration is being sought.

Another significant change is the abolition of the present requirement to register according to a class system. The abolition of this system will give wider protection to designs without affecting the test of novelty or originality.

The legislation also incorporates a new definition of design which is coupled with a new provision. The combined effect is to make it clear that design features serving a functional purpose should not be taken into account by the courts in determining whether the design is valid. This will allow registration of shapes which enable an article to perform a particular function. The function itself will not be registered, but merely the shape or feature needed to achieve the function.

I should stress that the benefits provided by the Designs Act apply only to designs registered under the provisions. Whilst the benefits of registration outweight those of non-registration, the Act clearly requires that a design must be new or original and unpublished in Australia before a registration application is made. In return for satisfying those conditions the owner obtains a monopoly for up to 16 years.

Australian industry, as well as overseas industry, favours the system of Australian design registration. This is apparent when one considers the wide range of articles registered as designs by Australian industry. Design registrations being sought and obtained ranged from air conditioners, barbecues, boat hulls, chairs and display cabinets to roof tiles, toys, wash-basins and yo-yos. This Government is seeking to encourage Australian innovative effort in every possible way. Since 1975 the rate of design lodgments in Australia has increased by 50 per cent. Approximately 70 per cent of all applications for design registration have come from Australians. This indicates a greater awareness of the need for, and the benefits of, statutory protection for industrial property rights. The Government is well aware of this. This Bill is another of the measures introduced in the last three years to provide a more conducive climate for innovation in the Australian community. I commend the Bill to the Senate.
