PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Ordered that the Bill may be taken through all its stages without delay.
Bill (on motion by Senator Chaney) read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to incorporate the second reading speech in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

This Bill corrects inadequacies in procedures for obtaining a patent for an invention. Although the procedures are technical and sometimes complex, the principles behind them are basic to industrial property protection. In particular this applies to provisions of the Bill concerning time limits for certain actions necessary while a patent application is pending. The main purpose of a patent system is to stimulate industrial invention and innovation by granting limited monopoly rights to inventors, and by increasing public availability of information on new technology. Patent procedures must achieve a balance among competing interests while remaining administratively workable.

The primary purpose of time limits is to enable industrial competitors to operate with some certainty about whether they are impinging on someone else's patent rights. A set time limit ensures that third parties can act in the sure knowledge that an applicant has obtained or has foregone his rights. Time limits should not, however, be inviolate. An applicant who fails to observe them may incur the loss of all or part of his potential rights to a patent.

Provisions already in the Patents Act allow the Commissioner of Patents, under certain conditions, to extend the times laid down. The most important of these is section 160, which allows time extensions in circumstances beyond control or through an error or omission by the person concerned, or his agent or attorney. It was a long-standing Patent Office practice to grant liberal section 160 time extensions. Recently this liberal approach has been challenged, resulting in the inadequacies becoming apparent in three areas. The first area relates to the time within which the Commissioner may accept a patent application. Acceptance marks the stage when the Commissioner grants an application. The problem is that no explicit provision allows section 160 to extend that time.

The second relates to the Convention period which is derived from the Paris Convention and concerns the priority dating of patents lodged in Australia but which originated from other member countries. Again no express provision allows section 160 to extend that period. The third area relates to extending the 12-month period for lodging what is called a 'complete-after-provisional' application. It arises where an applicant lodges a patent application with only a provisional specification. This is in order to retain a priority date corresponding to the filing date of the provisional specification. There is no express provision in section 160 to extend the 12-month period.

Recent decisions by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal and the Deputy Commissioner of Patents mean extensions of the Convention period or the acceptance period cannot now be granted. There is also doubt about the validity of 'complete-after-provisional' extensions. The seriousness of the problem became apparent in mid-1979 when an industrial dispute at the Redfern Mail Exchange delayed a large number of patent application documents in transit. As well processing delays could often mean that the time limit for accepting applications has passed. Under these circumstances patents would be irretriev- ably precluded from being granted. The Government decided on remedial legislation, and this Bill ensures extensions of time in appropriate circumstances. The Bill now provides specific sections to supplement the inadequately worded section 160. Apart from time extensions, provisions also allow for protecting third parties adversely affected by extensions. Additionally, there is the opportunity for opposition to extensions exceeding three months. The Bill also contains a catch-all provision to cope with late lodgments of documents attributable to postal delays.

Another problem arises from the findings that some extensions were invalid. The Attorney-General's Department advises that a patent granted after an invalid extension of the acceptance period is itself invalid. In the case of the Convention period, an invalid extension means that the Convention priority date is lost.

The Bill therefore includes provisions retrospectively validating extensions of time purported to have been granted in the past and which are now held, or might be held, to be invalid. All consequences flowing from such extensions are also validated. The only exceptions are those extensions which have been questioned in proceedings under the principal Act. It would be unjust to legislate retrospectively to remove arbitrarily rights established in those proceedings. As far as extensions of the acceptance period and of the time for lodging the 'complete-after-provisional' specifications are concerned, grounds for seeking an extension are the same as those in section 160. However, divergent views exist about the availability of extensions to the Convention period. Because of these conflicting considerations, the Industrial Property Advisory Committee was asked whether the Patents Act should provide for extending the Convention period. The Committee recommended and the Government accepted that: Firstly, extensions be granted where the applicant can show he intended filing within the 12-month Convention priority period; secondly, the failure to do so was beyond the control of the applicant, his agent or his attorney; and, thirdly, under no circumstances should the extension exceed three months.

Other points covered by the Bill include easing the restrictions imposed by time limits for lodging divisional applications, inclusion of more wide-ranging regulations on professional conduct of patent attorneys, and provisions which enable Australia to carry out its obligations under the International Patents Co-operations Treaty.

In conclusion this Bill aims to resolve a procedural defect which has been uncovered in the patent system. That defect has not only put obstacles in the way of obtaining a patent, but has also rendered many existing patents defective, and even void. This Bill corrects those defects. The rights of applicants and patentees, and also of competitors in industry, are now safeguarded. I commend the Bill to the Senate.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Ordered that the Bill may be taken through all its stages without delay.
Bill (on motion by Senator Chaney) read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to incorporate the second reading speech in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

This Bill is concerned with one of the ways in which the registered proprietor of a trade mark can protect his rights. In particular, it relates to section 103 of the Trade Marks Act 1955 which, in some circumstances, prohibits the import into Australia of goods bearing a registered trade mark. The Government, through the operation of the Trade Marks Office, is committed to the promotion of orderly development of trade industry and commerce by the protection of trade marks, whether they be for goods or services. This Bill seeks to give effect to that commitment in the area of importing of goods bearing a registered trade mark.

A trade mark indicates that goods or services bearing the mark come from a particular trade source. It is a kind of property, able to be bought and sold. It is part of the family of intellectual property which also includes patents, industrial designs and copyright. Since a trade mark is a kind of property, it carries a principal feature of property, the right to exclude others from using it.

This right to exclude others may be enforced in different ways. First, there is the common law remedy known as 'passing-off'. In appropriate circumstances the courts will protect a trader who has built up a reputation in a trade mark, usually by long, extensive, continuous and exclusive use. The basic idea behind this is to protect the public against deception. However, the 'passing-off' remedy is cumbersome and expensive, since the trader has to prove his reputation by calling witnesses into court. Therefore provisions were included in the trade marks legislation to solve this problem. The Trade Marks Act provides quick proof and quick machinery for enforcing trade mark rights through a system of trade mark registration. A trader may apply to the Registrar of Trade Marks for registration. If the Registrar considers the trade mark is one which the Act says he can or must register he will 'accept' the mark. The trade mark will be placed on the Register after the public has been given the opportunity to object. The registered trade mark can then be protected by an 'infringement' action for which production of the registration certificate is sufficient proof of ownership of the trade mark. The remedy of infringement proceedings under the Trade Marks Act is the second way a trade mark owner can protect his rights.

A third protective remedy is section 103 of the Act. This allows for the prohibition, under some circumstances, of imported goods manufactured outside Australia which bear a trade mark registered in Australia. The registered proprietor or registered user of the trade mark can notify Customs that he objects to goods bearing the mark being imported. This objection enables Customs to seize such goods. It is not hard, for example, to see the value of this remedy where 'pirate' goods bear forged or falsely applied trade marks. Section 103 effectively protects the proprietor or registered user against encroachment on his rights by unscrupulous overseas manufacturers. However, the use of section 103 to prevent the import of genuinely marked goods has caused concern. This includes cases where the trade mark was applied overseas by the same company which is the registered proprietor in Australia.

Many object to this use of the section, saying it goes too far beyond the ideas behind protecting trade marks and abuses the purpose behind protecting trade marks by registration. The use of section 103 in relation to importation of goods was therefore referred to the Industrial Property Advisory Committee for review. That Committee's recommendations have generally been accepted by the Government. This Bill is designed to amend section 103 to implement the report. The Committee's key recommendation is that the provisions for seizure and forfeiture of goods under section 103 should be confined to those cases where importation infringes a registered trade mark.

Section 103 will no longer be available to prevent the import of goods bearing a genuine trade mark applied overseas by the Australian registered proprietor. It would still protect against pirate goods, provided that the import of those goods constituted an infringement of the registered trade mark. This brings section 103 into line with the philosophy of the rest of the Trade Marks Act, providing a convenient and effective means of enforcing the same civil rights protect- able under infringement proceedings. Section 103 will therefore apply only in situations where the trader's reputation might suffer and where the public might be deceived.

The Bill gives effect to the Committee's recommendation that the mechanism of notifying Customs be retained. Section 103 is available to any registered proprietor of a trade mark registered in Australia, and also to registered users. Procedures laid down are consistent with tying section 103 to the test of infringement. This Bill ensures the rights of the registered proprietor and the consuming public are adequately protected against the import of goods infringing trade marks. At the same time the Bill eliminates undesirable practices which have grown up under the current provisions. I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Robertson) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: HEALTH CARE SERVICES HEALTH INSURANCE CONTRIBUTIONS

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before my speech was interrupted to allow for the introduction of three Bills I was developing the argument that one of the popular myths in Queensland is that the profits from the Golden Casket-Queensland's lottery, as it would be known in other States-pays for Queensland's public hospitals. In fact, when I was reading about the Queensland hospital system in preparation for my speech in this debate I happened to pick up a document entitled 'Australian Health Services'. That document states: 'The State lottery-the Golden Casket-makes substantial contributions to the financing of public hospital services.' It was referring to Queensland. So it is a popular myth not only within Queensland but also within literature. I would just like to indicate that it is a myth. I am not quite sure how much it costs to run the Queensland hospital system but a rough estimate would be about $350m a year. I arrived at that rough estimate by having a look at and calculating figures in the Budget Papers. About $350m for recurrent costs would be what we would have to pay in Queensland for our public hospital system. In the last year for which information is available, 1979-80, the Queensland Golden Casket made a profit of $7.7m. If we put the $7.7m against the $350m we will see that it is nothing but a drop in the bucket. Those people in Queensland who are under the impression that the Golden Casket does pay for the hospital system should realise just how small the profit of the Golden Casket is in relation to total hospital costs in Queensland. This $7.7m will go no way towards overcoming the problem that faces Queensland because of the decisions announced today by the Federal Government in the statement which suggested to me that the Government was thinking only of the House of Representatives. When the legislation does come into this chamber it will be a testing time for the Government because when it brings forth its new temporary health scheme it will have to run the gamut of the debate from this side and, I should imagine, the debate from Queensland senators on the other side of the chamber.

SPEECH.PARA: Debate (on motion by Senator Chaney) adjourned.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I would like to mention one thing which the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney) may be able to take back to his leader or whoever makes the decisions on the matter that I am about to discuss.
—The full Cabinet, I would think.

—If he would not mind taking it back to the full Cabinet, I would appreciate it. Next Monday two of the Estimates committees are due to sit. Next Monday is a public holiday in Queensland. Most of us do not mind working on public holidays because most of us--
—You want a health scheme around Queensland and now you want Estimates around Queensland. Dear God!

—As I said, most of us do not mind working on public holidays because most of us do work on public holidays. Some of the hardest work we do is probably done on public holidays. Most of us work on Saturdays and Sundays and we do not mind. I do not mind working on public holidays. But I point out that next Monday is a public holiday in Queensland and it is a holiday of special significance to the people on this side of the chamber because next Monday is Labour Day. On Labour Day in Queensland I find that it is really my duty to be in Queensland to represent the Australian Labor Party. Most of us, when there is a sitting of the Parliament, would acknowledge that the place where we should be is in the Parliament, but this is one of the special days for the Australian Labor Party when I find it my duty to be not in the Parliament but in Queensland. What will happen next Monday is that I will miss my Estimates Committee meeting. I could not answer Senator Walters' interjection earlier because I wanted to develop that argument. But I think she would understand that I am not asking for the Parliament to be centred around public holidays in Queensland. What I am pointing out is that this is an important public holiday that some of us must observe.
—I recognise the distinction between an ordinary public holiday and that one.

—Thank you. I am not asking for next Monday's Estimates committees to be rescheduled, but what I am asking is that next time we schedule Estimates committees we look to see whether there are any public holidays in the States. After all, we are all State-based and it may be that if that matter is looked at, this situation will not occur again.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I shall very quickly respond to Senator Colston. I think the point which he has raised is one which the Government would wish to take cognisance of. He would understand the difficulties as there is a very large number of public holidays around Australia and the States celebrate even Labour Day, I think, on different days. Last Monday when Estimates committees sat, uniquely to Western Australia, there was a public holiday. It happened to be an additional public holiday granted for Anzac Day. So on that occasion Western Australian senators had a public holiday but the Estimates committees were sitting. Admittedly, it was a public holiday with a different type of significance to the example raised by Senator Colston. I undertake to take what he said back to the Government, and I can assure him that when setting these dates we will try to take into account the sorts of commitments which he has mentioned. It is the desire of the Government to meet the convenience of honourable senators as much as possible.

It has been the practice for each State Government to make available sufficient intern training positions to enable those completing medical school courses in that State to satisfy registration requirements. From that Table the number of intern positions in 1980 would be 1331 and the projected numbers for 1981 and 1982 would be 1391 and 1416 respectively.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 3 December 1980:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many failures of 15 minutes duration or longer occurred in major telephone exchanges throughout Australia from 1 January 1980 to 3 December 1980.
(2) What were the effects, or presumed effects, on local and subscriber trunk dialling calls. What caused the failures and how long did they last.
(3) To what extent were the manual assistance operators at the centres affected able to complete their outgoing calls.
(4) To what extent were manual assistance operators at other centres able to complete calls into or via the centre at which the failure occurred.
(5) In which cases were subscribers unable to reach their manual assistance operators, and why.

(6) At manual assistance centres equipped with older switchboards and their own 'transit' lines, which largely by-pass the STD systems, is it true that during network congestion or disruption the operators can still handle approximately their normal daily number of calls to centres to which STD is affected, and that this represents approximately 5% of normal daily total trunk calls including STD.

(7) At centres where the operators have only the newest type of manual assistance exchange, connected with the computerised STD equipment, will failure of the computer not only disrupt the STD but also make it impossible for callers to reach their manual assistance operator.

(8) Is it intended that, with the exception of some remote localities, like Darwin and Kalgoorlie, all manual assistance will be handled at switching centres of this new type within a very few years, and that these will be located at approximately ten major centres, with calls from most provincial cities having to traverse the STD network to reach the manual assistance switching centre.

(9) In which locations is it intended that part of the older equipment will be retained for emergency service in the event of failure of the STD computer and its associated manual assistance facility.

(10) In those locations, will the capacity of the emergency facility be sufficient to handle, say, 5% of the normal daily trunk traffic (including STD) from all areas served by that centre, and will it have the necessary facilities to enable its operators to by-pass STD problem areas, as the 'traditional' trunk exchanges do; if not, what is the likely percentage of that centre's daily trunk traffic which could be assisted in the event of an STD failure.

(11) If there will be cases in which the operators will not be able to give substantially the same level of assistance to the community in such events, what is the justification for this planned decrease in the reliability of the telephone system.

(12) Is the survivability of the nation's communication network not seen as sufficiently important or is the requirement to operate the system at rates and charges as low as practicable seen as more fundamental than the need to ensure that the system will be able to perform reasonably well in any foreseeable circumstances.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Communications has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: 1. Eight.

(2) The failures would have had no serious effects on local calls. Most STD calls which were in progress prior to the occurrence of the fault would have continued uninterrupted. However, the majority of subsequent calls could not be connected without difficulty until the fault cleared. The failures were due to faults of a technical nature and had an average duration of 35 minutes.
3. Operators could not connect calls during the failures.
4. Some difficulties, requiring repeat attempts, would have been encountered due to increased congestion in the network served by the affected exchange.
5. All failures had the effect of preventing subscribers reaching manual assistance operators.
6. Yes for New South Wales. No for other States.
7. Yes.
8. As a general rule, all manual assistance centres within 800 kilometres of the capital city will handle traffic through the new equipment.

9. & 10. For technical and operational reasons, old equipment is usually replaced as soon as sufficient positions of the new type have been installed and any initial teething troubles have been overcome. STD and manual assistance security and back-up facilities are being progressively incorporated in the national trunk network. This is a much more effective and efficient means of ensuring security than the retention of largely obsolescent equipment.

11. & 12. The design and manufacturing specifications for all new manual assistance equipment demand a high degree of reliability. This fact, coupled with the provision of increased security within the trunk network will ensure that past high standards of manual assistance are maintained.

(3) Are individuals or companies undertaking Draize tests in Australia required to notify the Department of Health, or anybody responsible to the Minister for Health if they undertake such tests.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Health has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

(2) My Department was notified through the National Health and Medical Research Council (NH & MRC) that Draize tests were carried out on rabbits using A-200 pyrinate following reports from the Royal Australian College of Ophthalmologists of corneal scarring in children treated with the product for pediculosis.
