QUESTION.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 3 March 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the Minister for Transport as well as the Prime Minister expressed full support for Qantas in the current industrial dispute it is experiencing.
(2) Is this 'support', in fact, direct instructions on the dispute.
(3) What has been the cost of this dispute to date.
(4) What would have been the cost of agreeing to the Flight Stewards Association's compromise proposal.
(5) What has been the extra rates of pay and/or allowances that non-union flight crews have been paid to perform the duties of flight stewards and other unionist duties.
(6) What training of flight safety procedures have the non-union crews received. How does this compare with the training received by the flight stewards.
(7) Have these non-union crews received training in in-flight medical attention procedures.
(8) Are the safety equipment and procedures normally required for flights in Arctic areas being adhered to in Qantas flights over the North Pole.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Transport has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes.
(2) The Minister was in regular contact with the Board and Management of Qantas throughout the dispute and in full support of the way they were handling the situation.

(3) It is not possible at this stage to quantify the total cost of the dispute. The TWU fuel bans were responsible for the majority of the additional expenditure. Cargo was embargoed to permit the carriage of large quantities of expensive fuel from off-shore ports. The impact on revenue, however, is not easily measured-especially the impact on the company's forward booking situation.

(4) There were in fact a number of proposals and counter-proposals made by both the company and the Flight Stewards' Association. The cost associated with any of the proposals or counter-proposals is hypothetical in light of the fact that the Flight Stewards' Association finally agreed to refer the matter to the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission for conciliation. This position was reached before members of Qantas ground unions walked off the job.

(5) All the volunteer staff labour who kept the airline flying during the dispute are either members of a union or are eligible to be. Those operating as flight crews received standard allowances to reimburse them for costs of travel and meals incurred whilst overseas. No extra pay or special allowances were paid.

(6) The emergency procedures training given to volunteer staff crews was the same as that given to flight stewards. The examination they were given at the conclusion of their training was the same as is given to flight stewards and is approved by Department of Transport, under the appropriate Air Navigation Order.

(7) Yes. The volunteer staff crews attended lectures in aviation medicine given by a doctor qualified in this area and were separately instructed by a trained nursing sister on the subject of in-flight medical procedures in accordance with the appropriate Air Navigation Order.

(8) Qantas flights were not operated over the North Pole and utilised normal airline sub-arctic routings. The safety equipment carried and procedures employed were in accordance with International and Australian regulatory requirements.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for National Development and Energy, upon notice, on 4 March 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is there a recognised need for more adequate social planning in affected areas before the onset of resources development.
(2) Is the Minister aware of a report in The Age of the problems developing at Portland, Victoria, where Alcoa is to build a one thousand million dollar almuninium smelter.

(3) Will Portland become yet another deprived community unless prompt action is taken because of (a) problems of housing with an increase of 50 per cent already in property values and rents, (b) the lack of job opportunities for young people and women, (c) services being provided by the Social Security Department on only two days a week, and (d) an anticipation by police of a sharp increase in juvenile crime and vandalism.

(4) What action will the Government take, either using its good offices with the Victorian Government or on its own behalf, to ensure that Portland's difficulties are resolved effectively and that other affected communities, like Gladstone in Queensland and the Latrobe Valley in Victoria, are given urgent assistance with their mounting social problems.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for National Development and Energy has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Responsibility for ensuring that adequate social planning and provision of community services and facilities accompanying resource development rests primarily with the States and local government. The Commonwealth believes that the States have the capacity through their own resources, to ensure that problems related to resource development can be resolved effectively.
(2) Yes.

(3) and (4) The Victorian Government has introduced a range of measures designed to ensure that the development needs of Portland are met. In addition, the Commonwealth is involved, through its direct responsibilities, in a number of initiatives related to social planning in Portland, including

representation by the Department of Social Security on the Portland Co-ordinating Social Welfare Group. The Department has also been invited to participate in the work of the Social Monitoring Advisory Group to be established by the Victorian Government;
appointment of additional Commonwealth Employment Service staff and upgraded systems to enable wider distribution of job vacancy reports. New premises are also planned;

consultation between the Department of Employment and Youth Affairs, the State and Alcoa. The Department is represented on the industrial training sub-committee of the Ministerial Council set up to investigate industrial training needs and training capacity. The Victorian Government has commenced a study on labour and training and the Department of Employment and Youth Affairs will hold further discussions with Victorian officials once the results are available;

close liaison between Telecom and Alcoa. Action is being taken by Telecom to reduce existing service backlogs in Portland. The exchange facility has been extended at a cost of $18 000, and extensive new cabling is being undertaken in the region.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment, upon notice, on 4 March 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Will the Minister ensure that the proprietors of the Honeymoon uranium project abide by all the requirements of the Environmental Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act 1974, and that they revise their unsatisfactory draft environmental impact statement accordingly.
(2) Will the Minister ensure that the proprietors meet their obligation under Section 4.1 (d) of the Administrative Regulations, and indicate the consequences of not taking the proposed action.

(3) Will the Minister require the proprietors to provide an adequate account of the serious groundwater contamination which will be the result of the in-situ leaching method adopted for the proposed Honeymoon project.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Home Affairs and Environment has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) In accordance with the provisions of paragraph 8.1 of the Administrative Procedures under the Environment Protection (Impact of proposals) Act 1974, the proponent of the Honeymoon Project, Mines Administration Pty Ltd is currently revising the draft environmental impact statement (EIS) to take account of comments received during the public review period.

(2) Paragraph 4.1 of the Administrative Procedures provides that an EIS include the matters listed . . . 'to the extent appropriate in the circumstances of the case'. My Department's report to me on whether the proponent has satisfied the object of the Act will take account of the proponent's obligations under paragraph 4.1 of the Administrative Procedures.

(3) I am advised that additional information concerning the impact of the mining operations on groundwater is to be included in the final EIS. In the event that this information is not adequate to undertake a proper assessment of the proposal, paragraph 9.2 of the Administrative Procedures makes provision for me to seek additional information from the proponent to enable the final EIS to be examined.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Attorney-General the following question, upon notice, on 10 March 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How much has the Australian Government paid to the firm of Arent, Fox, Kintner, Plotkin and Kahn of Washington DC for (a) retainer, (b) fees and (c) disbursements in respect of advice and representation in relation to the international uranium cartel litigation?
(2) What amount for (a) retainer, (b) fees and (c) disbursements has been incurred and is unpaid?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The firm of Arent, Fox, Kintner Plotkin and Kahn was engaged by my predecessor on 15 August 1977 to provide legal advice, to the Australian Government on antitrust matters. It was not paid any retainer. Messrs Joelson and Griffin of that firm provided the advice until 31 July 1980 when they ceased to be partners in that firm. On 1 August 1980 they entered into partnership with Wald Harkader & Ross and the Australian Government then engaged that firm to provide advice.
In relation to uranium cartel matter the payments made for services rendered between 15 August 1977 and 31 December 1980 were:
(a) no retainer paid;
(2) Account has been received but is not paid for January 1981. No account has yet been received for February and March 1981. The amount unpaid is:
Uranium cartel-
(a) no retainer payable;

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 11 March 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How did the Minister for Communications invite submissions to the current review of aspects of the Broadcasting and Television Act 1942.
(2) Were there any advertisements in the media inviting submissions, if so, (a) in what terms were the advertisements; and (b) in what media outlets did they appear.

(3) Were individual interested people and groups contacted directly; if so, (a) what people and what groups were directly contacted; and (b) on what dates was each person or group mentioned first contacted concerning the review.
(4) Were any groups who might be regarded as public interest groups contacted other than justice in broadcasting; if so, which groups were contacted.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Communications has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Submissions to the review of aspects of the Broadcasting and Television Act 1942 were invited directly by letter, and through statements made by myself to the media.
(2) No paid advertisements were placed in the media.

(3) A full list of persons contacted directly by letter is provided in my response to the honourable senator's Question on Notice No. 398 of 4 March 1981. More than 200 letters were sent out, on 8, 9 or 10 December 1980. However, my general invitation for public comment was given substantial media coverage from 5 December 1980.
(4) Letters were sent to the following public interest groups:
Australian Council for Children's Films and Television;
Australian Children's Television Action Committee;
Justice in Broadcasting.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Mulvihill Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs, upon notice, on 11 March, 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did the investigation conducted by the Official Receiver into the bankrupt estate of David Roy Hughes of Foley Street, East Sydney, disclose hidden assets not revealed at the initial investigation of his assets; if so, what was the sum of money which David Roy Hughes sought to hide?
(2) Did the subsequent investigation indicate that the sum of money in question was related to Nugan Hand banking operations; if not, what was the source of the hidden assets?
(3) Was David Roy Hughes' close associate Mr V. Murphy of 25 Berwick Lane, East Sydney, questioned about his role in this irregular financial transaction?
(4) Has any penalty been imposed upon David Roy Hughes, if so, what penalty?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Investigations conducted by the Official Receiver into the bankruptcy of David Roy hughes revealed an interest in a home unit known as 34/7 Elizabeth Street, Sydney, that was not disclosed on the statement of affairs filed by Hughes. The unit was sold by the Official Receiver in January 1981 for $43,500 and the creditors in the bankruptcy were paid in full. The investigations did not reveal any evidence of a hidden sum of money.
(2) Investigations by the Official Receiver did not reveal any connection between David Roy Hughes and Nugan Hand banking operations.
(3) No. The Official Receiver does not know of a Mr V. Murphy of 25 Berwick Lane, East Sydney.

(4) No. The failure by David Roy Hughes to disclose an asset on the statement of affairs has been referred to the Australian Federal Police for an inquiry to establish whether it constitutes an offence against the Bankruptcy Act 1966.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Kilgariff Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, upon notice, on 11 March 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What social or other facilities are available for the use and enjoyment of merchant seamen who served in the various theatres of World War II.
(2) Are any merchant seamen recipients of service pensions; if so, how many.
(3) Are any merchant seamen entitled to any repatriation services.
(4) What are the similar entitlements of Aboriginal people who served, or were employed by the Australian services, in areas declared as war zones in World War II.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Merchant seamen are eligible for payment of pension and provision of medical treatment, under the Seamen's War Pensions and Allowances Act 1940, in respect of injuries directly associated with enemy action or in consequence of capture or detention by the enemy. Merchant seamen entitled to benefits under this Act may use the facilities of the Department of Veterans' Affairs in the same way as any eligible veteran but my Department does not provide social facilities for veterans.

(2) Although the Seamen's War Pensions and Allowances Act 1940 does not provide for payment of the service pension, certain merchant seamen may receive the service pension under the Repatriation Act 1920, if they served under T124X or T124T Agreements. Service under the terms of these Agreements is considered analogous to that of members of the Forces and those who served under such Agreements may be conceded full rights under the Repatriation Act 1920. Merchant seamen in receipt of the service pension are treated as members of the Forces and are not separately identified. It is, therefore, not practicable to specify the number of merchant seamen who are recipients of the service pension.

(4) The entitlements of Aborigines who served in the Australian Forces during World War II are the same as those of other members of the Forces. In respect of those who were not actually members of the Forces it is necessary to consider each case on its individual merits. In any case in which eligibility is conceded, the entitlements of the person concerned are the same as those of a member of the Forces.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 12 March 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Who publishes the Parliamentary Diary.
(2) Are the lists of senators and members in the Parliamentary Diary accurate; it not, what type of errors are there in the lists.
(3) Are members of the Australian Capital Territory House of Assembly listed in the Parliamentary Diary: if not, why not .
(4) Is it mandatory for the Parliamentary Diary to have an International Standard Book Number (ISBN); if so (a) what is this number; and (b) is it properly displayed in the Parliamentary Diary.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Prime Minister has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) I am advised that the Parliamentary Diary is published by Hillier Allan Publications Pty Ltd of Botany, New South Wales.
(2), (3) The Government is not responsible for authorisation or publication of the Parliamentary Diary. Any matters regarding content of the Diary would need to be taken up with the publishers.

(4) I am advised that issue of International Standard Book Numbers in Australia is a matter for the National Libary of Australia and the question has been referred to the National Library for attention.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 12 March 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What assistance goes to women's refuges under the Homeless Persons Act.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: No organisations operating women's refuges, as such, are funded under the Homeless Persons' Assistance Act. I am informed that these types of refuges are funded through the Community Health Program, administered by my colleague, the Minister for Health.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 24 March 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: Does the Department of Social Security regularly evaluate the use which is made of statistics which the department releases in relation to recipients of pensions, benefits and family allowances in postcode districts and electoral divisions; if so, what have been the conclusions reached as a result of those investigations.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: No, but the continued high demand for the information suggests that many find it useful. Postcode data can be used to prepare broad estimates of the number of pensioners or beneficiaries in any geographical area of Australia.

The Department initially prepared statistics on the number of recipients of pensions, benefits and family allowances in postcode districts and electoral divisions primarily to meet a large number of requests for such information from members of the House of Representatives and the Senate. A copy of the relevant State volume is now provided to each Member and Senator for information.

In addition, these statistics are distributed within the Department of Social Security, where they are used mainly for planning and reference purposes. The State offices of the Department use these statistics to plan the location of regional offices and to answer the many queries they receive from local government bodies, welfare service organisations, community groups, and other organisations and individuals in relation to the number of clients of this Department in local areas. These statistics are also distributed to some Commonwealth Departments, and to a small number of organisations including community groups and tertiary institutions.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Department of Social Security: Form P50a

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 24 March 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: Should Department of Social Security Form P50a be used when the Department requires a copy of an income tax return (but no other information) from a claimant for a benefit; if so, should the remainder of the questions on the Form P50a be deleted to avoid confusion and are Departmental officers aware of this requirement; and if not, what is the correct procedure and are Departmental officers aware of this procedure.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: It is not essential that a Form P50a should be used to request a copy of an income tax return. It is not used in any other state but Queensland where it is seen to be an aid as a stock letter.
As a matter of departmental practice, officers are instructed that irrelevant or unnecessary questions should be avoided. Officers preparing Forms P50a are expected to observe this requirement.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 24 March 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How are the guidelines for the accreditation of sheltered workshops to be formulated.
(2) What are the consultation processes involved, and with whom.
(3) Are consumers being consulted; if so, how are they chosen.
(4) Are public meetings of consumers called.
(5) Are these closed meetings, if so, why.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: As a prelude to the specific questions asked, I should indicate that in January 1981 a grant of $27,000 was approved to the Australian Council for Rehabilitation of Disabled (ACROD) to conduct a study into the feasibility of introducing into Australia a national, voluntary accreditation scheme for services for handicapped people. The Government believes that the interest being shown in standards of operation by the providers of services for the handicapped is indeed a healthy sign, and was pleased to be in a position to support this initiative.
Concerning the specific questions asked, I am advised as follows:
(1) A special Sub-Committee of the Association of Sheltered Workshops of New South Wales is currently formulating accreditation guidelines for consideration by its member organisations.

These guidelines are being formulated both by reference to accreditation practices in operation in the United States of America as well as by seeking a consensus amongst member organisations as to best practice in sheltered workshops and activity therapy centres in New South Wales.
The work of this Sub-committee is not binding on organisations or facilities outside the membership of the Association of Sheltered Workshops of New South Wales.
Although ACROD is working closely with the Sub-committee, no decisions will be taken about formulation of guidelines on a national basis until the outcome of the feasibility study is known.
The result of the feasibility study will not be available before July 1981.

(2) and (3) ACROD is determining the consultation process but is conscious of the need to consult with as wide a cross section of interested parties as possible, including consumers, voluntary organisations, Government authorities, etc.
(4) Yes.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 24 March 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: Is the claimant paid while being assessed for another benefit following the termination of or refusal of a claim for an invalid pension; if not, will arrears of benefit be paid from the termination of the invalid pension after the benefit has been granted.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: Where a medical review indicates that an invalid pensioner is no longer permanently incapacitated for work to the extent of at least 85 per cent, pension continues to be paid for a period of three months.

If a claim for invalid pension lodged by a person in receipt of another social security benefit is rejected he will continue to receive that benefit for as long as he continues to meet the eligibility conditions.

If the person is not in receipt of a benefit but claims sickness benefit following the rejection of his claim for invalid pension, arrears may be paid from the date of lodgement of the claim for invalid pension, subject to his meeting the required eligibility conditions for sickness benefit for the period in question.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 24 March 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Why are there no rehabilitation services in Hamilton, Victoria.
(2) Where are rehabilitation cases in the Hamilton area directed.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) It will be appreciated that basic medical rehabilitation services are the responsibility of the State Health Authorities. With regard to the provision of social and vocational rehabilitation, the Commonwealth Rehabilitation Service (CRS) is actively pursuing a policy of decentralising its services, as resources permit, mainly through the location of regional rehabilitation multi-disciplinary casework teams in major provincial towns and cities.

The Hamilton area is presently serviced by the CRS team located in Ballarat. People seeking rehabilitation assistance in the district are generally seen by the team when it visits their home town. Arrangements are made to purchase services locally where possible. Severely disabled people requiring a fully comprehensive rehabilitation program are referred to a CRS centre in Melbourne.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 24 March 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) When will the proposed tribunal which will be investigating pharmacists' remuneration begin its investigation.
(2) How many people will the tribunal be composed of and what organisations will they represent.

(3) Will a date be set, by which the tribunal must make recommendations to Parliament; if so, what will that date be; and if not, when does the Minister for Health estimate that the recommendations will be presented to Parliament.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Health has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The necessary amendments to the National Health Act to establish the Pharmaceutical Benefits Remuneration Tribunal will be introduced into Parliament at the earliest practical opportunity during the current Sittings. The Tribunal will begin its investigation as soon as it is established.

(2) It is envisaged that the Tribunal will consist of a chairman, appointed by the Governor-General, and up to two other members. The chairman will be a deputy President of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. The other members will be appointed by the Minister and will not represent any specific organisation but will desirably have business and accounting skills to contribute to the proceedings of the Tribunal.
(3) It is intended that the initial review of the Tribunal will be completed by 1 July 1981.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Science and Technology, upon notice, on 26 March 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: Will the Minister for Science and Technology give assurances that the tenders for building the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO) oceanographic vessel go to an Australian firm; if not, will the Minister ensure that the project contain as much Australian Industry participation as possible.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Science and Technology has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: CSIRO is at present examining tenders submitted in response to a call for bids from Australia and overseas for the construction of an oceanographic research vessel. These tenders will be considered against the background of the Commonwealth Government's purchasing policy. The notional bounty that would apply under the provisions of the Bounty (Ships) Act 1980, to an Australian shipyard, will also be taken into account in evaluating tenders.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment, upon notice, on 25 March 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment asked for an Environmental Impact Statement to be made regarding the proposal to discharge sewage into Magela Creek from Jabiru in the Northern Territory under the Environment (Impact of Proposals) Act; if not, why not.
(2) Is the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment aware that this is within the Kakadu National Park.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Home Affairs and Environment has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) No environmental impact statement has been sought in relation to development proposals within Jabiru town in the Northern Territory. On 4 October 1979, the former Minister for Science and the Environment exempted under paragraph 11 of the Administrative Procedures under the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act:

(a) all proposed actions or classes of proposed actions concerning or relating to the planning, establishment development and operation of access to and supply of services to, the proposed Jabiru town in Kakadu National Park in the Northern Territory; and

(b) all proposed actions or classes of proposed actions concerning or relating to the exercise by the Director of National Parks and Wildlife of his statutory powers relating to proposed actions or classes of proposed actions described in paragraph (a) hereof.
The reasons given by the Minister for granting this exemption were that, in view of
(a) the terms of the National Parks and Wildlife Conservation Act, 1975,
(b) the actions being taken or to be taken by the Director of National Parks and Wildlife under powers conferred by Section 8D of the National Parks and Wildlife Conservation Act 1975,

(c) the fact that, in so far as the exemption applies to proposed actions which will not be subject to licences under the said Section 8D, these actions will be governed by the provisions of the Plan of Management being prepared in respect of Kakadu National Park, and

(d) the consideration given to the environmental significance of establishing and developing the proposed township at Jabiru by the Commission of Inquiry called the Ranger Uranium Environmental Enquiry,

matters affecting the environment to a significant extent with respect to the proposed action and clases of proposed actions the subject of the exemption would be fully examined and taken into account, notwithstanding that the exemption is granted and in the Minister's view it was contrary to the public interest that in these circumstances the said Administrative Procedures should continue to apply to the said proposed actions and classes of proposed actions.
(2) Yes. In the Plan of Management for Kakadu National Park, requirements are set out in relation to the discharge of sewage from Jabiru.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services, upon notice, on 26 March 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Since 11 November 1975 how many contracts have been let with Task Quantum or Morgan Gallup for research into community attitudes and/or for advertising campaigns.
(2) What has been the cost to the government on each of these contracts, and the total cost overall.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Administrative Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) There is no central record of contracts let by Commonwealth departments and instrumentalities to research companies. Comprehensive information on this subject could only be obtained from individual Ministers.

The Australian Government Advertising Service of my Department is however aware that a managment consultancy firm and an advertising agency working on the 'Project Australia' campaign did use the services of a company called Quantum Market Research to help them to pre-evaluate advertising being prepared for that campaign. I am also informed that three relatively minor research tasks on behalf of other departments were assigned after competitive selection processes to the Roy Morgan Research Centre since 11 November 1975.

(2) The cost to the Government of the research tasks which have been identified as having been assigned to the Roy Morgan Research Centre since 11 November 1975 has been $11,805 made up of incremental payments commencing in March 1979 of $2,720, $522, $1,568, $2,130, $1,890, $500 and $2,475.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services, upon notice, on 26 March 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What was the amount spent by government departments and instrumentalities on advertising in 1979-80 and what is the amount projected to be spent in 1980-81.
(2) How does that total expenditure figure 'break down' amongst individual government departments and instrumentalities.
(3) What was the total amount spent on advertising by government departments and instrumentalities in 1973-74 and 1974-75.
(4) How do those total expenditure figures 'break down' amongst individual government departments.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Administrative Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The amount spend by government departments and instrumentalities for advertising arranged through the Australian Government Advertising Service (AGAS) in 1979-80 was $15,691,509. There is no accurate way by which amounts likely to be spent for advertising in 1980-81 can be projected before June because funding for advertising comes from many separate departmental appropriations and AGAS does not have advance notice of all commitments.

My Department holds no record of expenditure for advertising which has not been arranged through AGAS. This information would need to be sought from each Minister in respect of instrumentalities within his portfolio.

(2) and (4) Because records held centrally of accounts presented to departments for advertising arranged through my Department are 'broken-down' by specific accounting points and are not categorised in terms of departments or Ministerial Portfolios; and because accounts from seven different advertising agencies covering 36 separate months and up to 220 accounting points would need to be analysed for the three fiscal years referred to in the question, the use of staff time to provide a detailed answer to these two sections of the question would be too great to be justifiable.
(3) The amounts spent by government departments and instrumentalities for advertising arranged through AGAS in 1973-74 and 1974-75 were:
It should be noted that between early 1974-75 and late 1979-80 rates charged by media to Commonwealth Government for advertising space, time or rentals increased by more than 60 per cent.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 26 March 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did the Minister for Communications say on 13 March 1981 that 'the extent to which standards can be maintained, technical progress facilitated and customers protected . . . is a matter of very close consideration by the Government'; if so, what are the details of the consideration which the Government is giving to the introduction of new technologies.

(2) Will the Government develop informed and national policies in this area, to prevent a haphazard development of the new technologies by private interests without any guiding regulation in the public interest.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Communications has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The honourable senator refers to a passage from a speech which I made to the Australian Telecommunications Users Group (ATUG) in Sydney on 13 March 1981, where I discussed the provision of telecommunications terminal equipment. The Department of Communications is looking into ways in which domestic production and private sector goods and services can be used to extend the range of benefits of telecommunications available to the public.
(2) The Government's policy will ensure that equipment to be connected to the network is safe, that it properly performs its intended functions, and that it will not cause harm to the network.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 26 March 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did the National Health and Medical Research Council, some time ago, decide to increase the permitted level of cancer causing aflatoxins in peanut butter, following pressure from the peanut industry and processors after a bad year in which the aflatoxin level rose above that permitted in an earlier National Health and Medical Research Council ruling.
(2) Will the Government make the labelling standards for human food required by law stricter so that people are aware of what they are eating and the nutritional value it contains.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Health has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The general policy of the National Health and Medical Research Council (NH & MRC) is to advise that levels of contaminants in food be reduced to the minimum. In October 1976 the NH & MRC recommended that the maximum permitted level of aflatoxins in food should not exceed 5 micrograms per kilogram, which is the limit of detectability of modern analytical methods, and extremely stringent.

NH & MRC reconsidered this matter when it became apparent that it was not possible at the time to achieve the levels recommended and therefore suggested to States and Territories that they delay the introduction of the 5 micrograms per kilogram level.
Council recommended the following interim levels:
nut and nut products-15 micrograms per kilogram
other foods-5 micrograms per kilogram.

This matter is still under review by the NH & MRC. I would also point out that the level of 15 micrograms per kilogram is below the maximum level in the United States which is 25. The United Kingdom and Canada do not specify a level.

Evidence of association of aflatoxins in the diet with cancer has been suggested only at levels higher than the levels recommended in the United States and Australian recommendations are much lower again.

(2) The NH & MRC is continuously reviewing labelling requirements for foods and for example has recently recommended provisions concerning ingredient labelling, lot identification and date marking of packaged foods. The NH & MRC is currently reviewing the Standard for Labelling and has proposed that where claims of a nutritional nature are made, such claims should be substantiated by nutritional information such as energy, fat, carbohydrate and protein content.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 26 March 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: What further work has been undertaken regarding the installation of tidal gauge telemetry equipment to increase navigational safety in the Torres Strait as suggested by the Minister for Transport in response to Question on Notice No. 1820 dated 23 August 1979.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Transport has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: An order was placed in April 1980 for the supply of tide monitoring and telemetry equipment. This equipment was delivered in March 1981 and is about to be tested.

Plans are being finalised for the installation of this equipment to monitor the tide height at Turtle Head, Hammond Island. It is expected that the installation will be completed before the end of this year.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 26 March 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: Did the Minister for National Development and Energy, in response to Question on Notice No. 2103 regarding the tax liabilities of certain individuals named in Woodward Royal Commission of 18 October 1979 state: 'I have no doubt, however, that his officers would be taking appropriate action to ensure that the requirements of the income tax law are kept'; if so: (a) what action has been taken; and (b) have any results been achieved from this action.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: The statement quoted was part of the answer provided to Question on Notice No. 2103 in November 1979. The secrecy provisions of the income tax law prevent the Commissioner for Taxation from supplying the information requested in the latter part of the honourable senator's question.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 1 April 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Will supplementary licences be granted before provision has been made for 'Pay-TV' to be introduced.
(2) Will legislation be introduced to permit the operation of subscription 'Pay-TV' before, or at the same time as, legislation for supplementary licences is introduced.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Communications has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Legislation providing for supplementary licences will be introduced into Parliament in the current sittings. The Government has yet to consider a policy for the introduction of subscription television (the radiated form of 'Pay-TV') services in Australia. Whether supplementary licence holders should be able to provide subscription television as part of their overall service is currently under consideration. 'Pay-TV' on cable distribution systems is to be considered by the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal as part of its inquiry into cable television.
(2) See response to (1).

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 1 April 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did the Australian Postal Commission decide in mid-1980 to provide long service awards to staff with more than 40 years service.

(2) Did some serving officers with more than 40 years service retire after the date of the announcement and before the first awards were made in January 1981; if so, how many such officers at Headquarters and in the various States were deprived of the award by the deferral of the implementation date.
(3) What are the names and years of service of all such officers and what is the cost of including these officers in the scheme even at this late stage.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Communications has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) In July 1980, the Australian Postal Commission decided to initiate a two-tiered scheme under which service awards would be presented to staff completing periods of satisfactory service of 25 years and 40 years.
(2) Yes, some officers with 40 years of service did retire between July 1980 and Jauary 1981.
However, the implementation date for the scheme was determined as 1 January 1981. There was no deferral of implementation and no eligibility for an award existed prior to January 1981.
(3) Not applicable. See (2) above.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: McLaren Sen G.T.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services, upon notice, on 7 April 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What is the name of the advertising agency engaged by the Government to prepare the advertisements opposing the introduction of a shorter working week.
(2) What is the amount paid to the agency for its services.
(3) What sections of the media have been used to carry the advertisements.
(4) What is the amount paid to each section.
(5) What is the total overall cost of the advertising campaign.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Administrative Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The wording of press and radio advertisements opposing the introduction of a shorter working week was prepared and authorised by Ministers not by an advertising agency. The technical services of two advertising agencies in Sydney were used to prepare advertising material from which the approved copy could be printed or broadcast in the media:
Neville Jeffress Advertising Pty Ltd-for newspaper advertisements,
John Clemenger New South Wales Pty Ltd-for commercial radio advertisments.

(2) No amount is paid by the Government to those agencies for those services. The agencies claim remuneration for their time costs associated with the provision of technical services from the funds of the Australian Government Advertising Advisory Council. Because the funds of that Council (derived from media commissions and service fees associated with all Government advertising arranged through the Australian Government Advertising Service) become private funds of that Council, details of payments from them to agencies have previously been considered to be private information.
(3) and (4) Gross costs for firm advertising commitments made to each media section will be:
Daily newspapers-$87,700
Commercial radio stations-$48,400.
(5) As the campaign is not concluded total costs are not yet known. An amount of $145,690 was committed to 20 April 1981 including costs of media space and time and material production.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 7 April 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: What would be the cost of providing an extra payment of $20 at Christmas for:
(a) all social security pensioners and beneficiaries;
(b) those social security pensioners and beneficiaries who are receiving the maximum pension or benefit; and
(c) those pensioners and beneficiaries who are receiving supplementary assistance.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The cost to the Government of providing an additional payment of $20 at Christmas 1981 is estimated to be:
(a) some $50m for all social security pensioners and beneficiaries (including wives of beneficiaries);
(b) some $40m for those social security pensioners and beneficiaries (including wives of beneficiaries) who are receiving the maximum pension or benefit; and
(c) some $10m for those social security pensioners and beneficiaries who are receiving supplementary assistance or allowance.
These costs are based on estimated numbers of pensioners at December 1981, and estimated average numbers of beneficiaries for 1981-82.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 8 April 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the Minister for Communications had discussions with bodies including the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal, major television networks, and Telecom Australia regarding the issue of close captioning systems to aid the television viewing of deaf or hearing-impaired people.

(2) Was a decision made to introduce a single close captioning system as a result of such discussions; if not, what steps will be taken to ensure a uniform system so that deaf people are not involved in purchasing a number of expensive decoding devices.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Communications has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Officers of the Department of Communications have discussed the issue of providing closed captioned television services for the hearing impaired with representatives of all the broadcasting sectors, Government departments and authorities and other interested parties including the Australian Deafness Council and the Australian Centre for Visual Television.

(2) The Government has a particular interest in television services for the hearing impaired and in any plans by the broadcasting industry for the provision of captioned programs. With industry involvement, the Government is currently investigating several possibilities for closed captioning including the introduction of a special system specifically available for the hearing impaired or of a closed captioning facility which would be compatible with any data broadcasting service which may become established within Australia.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services, upon notice, on 8 April 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: What are the 'obvious reasons' for which the Minister for Administrative Services does not propose to make available details of the replies received in those cases in which the Australian Electoral Office has declined to prosecute. (See Senate Hansard, page 1120, dated 2 April 1981-answer to Question No. 317).

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Administrative Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: The provision of the information sought in the second part of part (2) of Question No. 317 would jeopardise and unduly interfere with, the future administration and enforcement of the authorisation provisions of the Commonwealth Electoral Act. The publication, even in general form, of replies received in those cases would be tantamount to publishing a list of acceptable reasons or excuses.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 2 December 1980 (Hansard, page 214) Senator Mulvihill asked me as Minister representing the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs the following questions concerning the death of several kangaroos at a zoo in Rio de Janeiro:

ANSWER.PARA: Will the documents which gave the animals a clear bill of health and stated that the animals were fit to travel be presented to the Senate.
Under what conditions were the animals sent to the zoo.
Will the Minister produce the customs authorisation.
Will an officer from our Embassy visit the zoo and look at the conditions there.
In the interim will the export ban again be applied.
The Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs has provided the following answers to the honourable senator's questions:
Approval for the exportation of four grey kangaroos, two male and two female, by air on 24 September 1980 was granted following advice from the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service.

The exportation was in accordance with the policy of successive Governments that exportation of Australian fauna be restricted to exports for scientific purposes or on a zoo to zoo basis provided the recipient zoo has the facilities for housing and caring for the particular fauna.

The Rio de Janeiro Zoological Garden was inspected on 1 August 1980 in accordance with established procedures by an officer of the Australian Consulate General in Rio de Janeiro and was deemed to have the facilities and expertise necessary to adequately care for Australian kangaroos.
The animals were supplied from legal captive stock of Lone Pine Koala Sanctuary, Brisbane and the exportation was made by the Queensland National Parks and Wildlife Service.

Post mortem examination shows that the kangaroos died as a result of ingesting fresh paint applied to their enclosure at the Rio de Janeiro Zoo. A small Joey offspring of one of the females died from respiratory problems and dehydration following loss of mother's milk.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 3 December 1980 (Hansard, page 264) Senator Missen asked the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: I refer the Attorney-General to his joint statement with the Minister for Foreign Affairs of 5 August 1980 announcing that Australia would ratify the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights and would establish a human rights bureau to help to implement its policy on human rights. The Attorney-General, in making this announcement, stated:
There have been a number of changes in law and practice to bring Australia into conformity with the Covenant (for example, by taking steps to improve the civil rights of prisoners).

Will the Attorney-General inform the Senate of what steps Australia has already taken in law and in practice to conform with the Covenant, including those relating to the civil rights of prisoners? Will the Attorney-General also inform the Senate of what further action will be taken by the Government to reaffirm Australia's standing as a country known internationally for its active commitment to the promotion and protection of human rights?
The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:
I undertook to obtain for him details of the steps Australia has already taken in law and practice to conform with the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights.

Prior to ratification, Australian law and practice was in substantial conformity with the provisions of the Covenant. Between signature in 1972 and ratification last year a number of pieces of legislation were passed which had the effect of assisting Australia to conform with the Covenant.
I am not in a position to give a complete list of all legislation and administration practices throughout Australia; however some examples are:
Public Assemblies Act 1972 (SA)
Death Penalty Abolition Act 1973 (Commonwealth)
Criminal Law Consolidation Ordinance 1973 (NT)
Criminal Law Consolidation Ordinance 1974 (NT)
Status of Children legislation (several States)
Crimes (Capital Offences) Act 1975 (Vic.)
Domicile Act (several States)
Law Reform Commission Amendment Act 1979 (Tas.)

I also had in mind amendments to the Migration Act then in preparation which have since become the Migration Amendment Act (No. 2) 1980. These amendments extend the application of the Migration Act to the Territory of Christmas Island and remove the requirement for entry permits for persons travelling from Christmas Island to Australia.

It is also worthwhile mentioning that, as regards the civil rights of prisoners, at the time of ratification, several States were giving active consideration, and still are, to the need for amendments to their laws to remove the civil disabilities suffered by persons convicted of capital offences.

In addition, the Law Reform Commission Act 1973 (Commonwealth) provides that the Commission is to perform its functions in reviewing laws and considering proposals with a view to ensuring, as far as practicable, consistency with the Articles of the Covenant. The references to the Commission on Privacy, Defamation and Sentencing all refer in particular to the Covenant.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 26 February 1981 (Hansard, page 148) Senator McIntosh asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Communications, the following question, without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: Can the Minister representing the Minister for Communications inform me of the policy adopted by Telecom Australia when a subscriber's telephone is being checked for faults? If a subscriber's phone is being monitored as part of a fault finding program is it policy or is it mandatory for Telecom Australia to inform the subscriber that his or her telephone is being monitored, or in other words, tapped.
The Minister for Communications has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

In a major telephone network of some 5 million services it is essential that Telecom staff be able to check and observe lines for faults and other operational matters. There are quite a number of technical testing devices utilised in the location of faults on subscribers' lines and apparatuses, depending on the nature of the fault. Occasionally, listening across a subscriber's line is unavoidable particularly if the fault is of an intermittent nature.

It would not be practicable to inform all subscribers each time Telecom staff needed to check a line. This aspect is recognised in legislation, for example, section 7 (2) (a) (i) of the Telecommunications (Interception) Act 1979 which exempts from the Interception Act an act or thing done by an officer of the Commission in the course of his duties or in connection with installations of a line or equipment or the operation and maintenance of a telecommunications system. However, section 7 (4) of that Act prescribes heavy penalties for disclosure by officers of Telecom of information obtained by intercepting a communication.
In practice, the need for a subscriber to be informed that Telecom is monitoring a line is left to the discretion of the officer handling the particular fault.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 5 March 1981 (Hansard, page 319) Senator Lewis asked me, as Minister representing the Prime Minister, a supplementary question, without notice, as to whether the Government would consider the withdrawal of the Soviet Ambassador's accreditation to Australia. The Prime Minister has supplied the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: The accreditation of the Soviet Ambassador to Australia is not under consideration by the Government.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 5 March 1981 (Hansard, page 35) Senator Sibraa asked me, as the Minister representing the Minister for Transport, without notice, if domestic air fares are to rise again, and if the Minister would undertake to ensure that the recommendations of the Holcroft inquiry are carefully considered before any new fare increases are approved.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Transport has provided me with the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

In March, the Government deferred consideration of tariff increases sought by the airlines until it completed its initial review of the inquiry's recommendations. Following this initial review increases in fares were approved on 1 April 1981 using a new formula which meets the thrust of the inquiry's recommendations. However, as foreshadowed by the inquiry considerable further work is being undertaken to achieve greater refinements and the most appropriate fare setting formula based on current costs. To further delay approval of the increase in an attempt to achieve these greater refinements would have been inappropriate as the lost revenue would ultimately have had to have been recouped from higher fares.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 10 March 1981 (Hansard, page 413) Senator Townley asked me a question, without notice, concerning the number of trunk routes specified by the present and new airlines agreements. The Minister for Transport has provided the following information in response to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: The present Airlines Agreement includes no definition of a trunk route and this has been a cause for criticism from time to time as the Agreement effectively applies to every route in Australia, not just trunk routes. The new Airlines Agreement defines a trunk route as a route linking any two of eighteen specified centres. Those centres are those served by the jet services of Ansett Airlines of Australia and Trans-Australia Airlines at 1 July 1980.

The new Agreement provided that operators other than Ansett and TAA may serve prescribed routes. A route may be both a trunk and a prescribed route under the Agreement. This would occur if, for example, an operator other than Ansett or TAA served a trunk route at 1 July 1980; or if following a request by the Minister the airlines did not provide a satisfactory service within a reasonable time over a trunk route.

The new Agreement therefore specifically provides that where an operator other than TAA or Ansett served a trunk route at 1 July 1980 that route is defined as a prescribed route. Also the Agreement clarifies the extent to which operators other than Ansett and TAA may extend their networks to include trunk routes. Certainly, nothing in the Agreement threatens the viability of East-West Airlines. The new Agreement does not preclude East-West from continuing to provide services over its network.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 11 March 1981, (Hansard, page 492) Senator Walsh asked me a question, without notice, concerning a report in the Sydney Sun that day about proposals by Ansett Airlines of Australia on the sale of Trans-Australia Airlines and the setting of air fares.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Transport has provided the following information in response to the honourable senator's question:

An article in The Sun of 11 March 1981, reported that Ansett had urged the sale of TAA or that fares profitability for the major airlines be tied to TAA's. I responded to the Ansett proposals that were raised in the context of the Airline Agreement negotiations in a letter of 3 March 1981, to Sir Peter Abeles. I have indicated that I would have no objection to tabling relevant correspondence should the other parties agree.

Since that time the Government has decided that TAA should be established as a public company. The decision was announced to the Parliament on 1 April 1981. The most appropriate means of implementing this decision is currently being considered and an announcement will be made as soon as possible.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 12 March 1981 (Hansard, page 559) Senator Mulvihill asked me a question, without notice, in my capacity as Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs in the Senate. The question concerned Australian citizenship for members of the Australian National Soccer team and for Miss Robyn Shaw.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Immigration and Ethinic Affairs has supplied the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

The matter of citizenship for the World Cup soccer team contenders Ken Boden and John Yzendoorn has been finalised, with both players having become residentially qualified for citizenship. Mr Boden was granted Australian citizenship on 27 March 1981 and Mr Yzendoorn on 1 April 1981. I issued a News Release on this subject on 26 March 1981. You also raised the question of the acquisition of Australian citizenship by Robyn Shaw. The child referred to is Miss Dionesia Hanwith-Horden. Her mother, Ms Jeanette Robinshaw, had sought to have the child's name included in the Certificate of Australian Citizenship granted to her. The Australian Citizenship Act 1948 provides for the name of any child under the age of sixteen years to be included in the Certificate of Australian Citizenship granted to the responsible parent or guardian of the child. The responsible parent is defined as the father unless the mother has been given custody in a court of law.

Consideration is presently being given to the amendment of a number of Sections of the Australian Citizenship Act 1948 and included amongst them is the use of the term responsible parent and its definition.

Dionesia is a child of Mrs Robinshaw's previous marriage and was born in Zambia. As Mrs Robinshaw did not have a court order giving her custody of the child it was not possible to include Dionesia in her Certificate of Citizenship.
As an alternative, however, approval was given for the grant of a Certificate of Citizenship to Dionesia in her own right. That Certificate was issued to her on 13 March 1981.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 24 March 1981 (Hansard page 665) Senator Hearn asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Communications, the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: In view of the $127m profit made by Telecom Australia for the six months ended December 1980, will the Minister give consideration to the free installation of telephones for pensioners as an aid to home care? Will the Minister consider this as a matter of urgency?
The Minister for Communications has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

Telecom is required to operate as a commercial business undertaking and generally relates its changes to the cost of providing and maintaining its services. The whole of the profit is ploughed back each year to help provide the capital required to expand the network and provide new services. In the current financial year, Telecom has a capital works program involving some $1,000 million.

The present one-third concession on telephone rental available to eligible pensioners is funded by the Government and now applies to over 666,000 of the 3.4 million non-business services currently in operation. The total value of the concession, amounting to around $19 million annually, is paid by the Departments of Social Security and Veterans' Affairs to Telecom Australia.

The question of extending the present telephone rental concession scheme for pensioners to include free installation charges is therefore one which would need to be considered by the Government in the context of the Government's overall social security program. In this context it falls primarily within the area of responsibility of my colleague the Minister for Social Security.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 26 March 1981 (Hansard, page 780) Senator Jessop asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: Is it a fact that a Mr Abraham Ordia, the Nigerian who is President of the Supreme Council for Sport in Africa, is in Australia at present as a paid guest of the Government? Has the Minister's attention been drawn to the fact that, before addressing the National Press Club in Canberra last week, Mr Ordia distributed copies of a printed extract from a speech made by John Vorster in the South African Parliament in April 1967 dealing with the South African Government's sports policies at that time? Will the Minister verify, firstly, that there is racial integration in South African sport at all levels, for example, South Africa's national soccer team consists of blacks and whites; secondly, that a non-white gentleman heads the South African cricket union; and, thirdly, that for more than 10 years athletics in South Africa have been racially integrated?
The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

The President of the Supreme Council for Sport in Africa, Mr Abraham Ordia, visited Australia from 17 to 28 March as an official guest. The purpose of such visits is to introduce prominent men and women to Australia, thereby to build up understanding overseas of Australia's policies and institutions, to remove misconceptions about Australia's attitudes and to make better known its growth, achievements and potential.

Mr Ordia's program included visits to Canberra, Sydney, Melbourne and Brisbane for discussions with Australian sportsmen and sporting administrators including the organisers of the 1982 Brisbane Commonwealth Games. Mr Ordia's program also included discussions with Foreign Affairs, Home Affairs and Aboriginal Affairs officials, and calls on the Governor-General, Prime Minister and myself. He also attended the First International Assembly of National Confederations of Sport.

Mr Ordia did not address the National Press Club, but he gave a luncheon address at the Australian Institute for International Affairs and a press conference at the Lakeside Hotel at which I understand he distributed an extract from a speech made by Mr Vorster.

Senator Jessop asked for verification that there is racial integration in South African sport at all levels. The Government, through our Embassy in South Africa, as well as through our contacts with Australian and international sporting organisations, monitors constantly and closely developments in sport in South Africa. We are aware that there are differences of approach to multi-racial participation in sport between different sports and sporting organisations in various parts of the country and that a number of organisations have moved some distance toward achieving multi-racial sport, although more so at the level of senior representative teams than at club level and practically not at all amongst schools. Soccer, athletics and cricket are all sports where some progress towards integration has been made. Such progress is encouraging, but it falls well short of the full scale racial integration in sport. Genuine racial integration involves equal access to all available facilities (including coaching and training facilities) by sportsmen of different races, access to membership and facilities of all sporting clubs, the opportunity to participate fully in local and international sporting events and equal access by spectators. Club membership, participation in competition and the use of facilities continue to be determined largely on the basis of race.

I emphasise, moreover, the Government's view that developments in sport in South Africa cannot be viewed in isolation. The discriminatory legislation which constitutes the basic framework of apartheid effects every aspect of the lives of non-white members of the community. Legislation such as the Group Areas Act, the Liquor Licensing Act and legislation dealing with the pass laws and the homelands impose fundamental restrictions on all black and coloured persons. Unless and until genuine efforts are made to remove those restrictions, the goal of eliminating racially discriminatory practices at all levels of South African society, whether in sport, employment, education or any other sphere of activity, will remain unattainable.

Senator Jessop mentioned specifically progress which had been achieved in soccer, cricket and athletics. Soccer is more advanced than most sports in the direction of intergration but the players are still subject to basic apartheid laws. I am advised that the Johannesburg and Pretoria municipalities recently barred soccer teams from using two main stadiums. I note also that in South Africa soccer is a sport which many more blacks than whites play and watch. I understand that some progress has also been made towards bringing about racial integration in athletics but, again, the access to the sport by black and coloured sportsmen is governed by the basic laws of apartheid. I confirm that the head of the South African Cricket Union, Mr Varrachia is non-white.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 26 March 1981 (Hansard, page 784) Senator Kilgariff asked me a question, without notice, in my capacity as Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs in the Senate. The question concerned the entry of Filipino girls from Baguio wishing to study nursing in Australia.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs has supplied the following answer to the honourable senator's question:
Approval was given by my predecessor the Honourable M. J. R. MacKellar for the entry of these girls and so far 90 girls have come to Australia.

The Australian Embassy, Manila, considers applications which are sent to it from the Mother Superior of the Good Shepherd Convent in Baguio. Prospective students are considered on an individual basis subject to meeting certain temporary entry requirements including academic qualifications equivalent to those required of Australian girls seeking to enter training institutions.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 26 March 1981 (Hansard, page 781) Senator Watson asked me a question, without notice, in my capacity as Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs in the Senate. The question concerned literature for migrants.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs has supplied the following answer to the honourable senator's question:
You have drawn attention to a basic problem of communication-the need to relate a message to the level of comprehension of the receiver.

In the light of the Migrants' Information Needs Survey which I tabled on 28 August 1980, the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs is reducing its dependence on written material, whether in English or another language and is encouraging other information-deliverers to the same course. It is now realised that a variety of approaches, ranging from face-to-face counselling to audio-visual aids, are required to supplement printed materials.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 2 April 1981 (Hansard, page 1034) Senator Gietzelt asked me a question, without notice, concerning a Press report attributing to Sir Robert Law-Smith's remarks concerning the implications for Trans-Australia Airlines' F27 services of the establishment of TAA as a public company.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Transport has provided the following information in response to the honourable senator's question:
I am aware of a report in the Press of 2 April 1981 attributing to Sir Robert Law-Smith's comments in relation to TAA's F27 services.

It is well known that the F27 services of TAA and Ansett Airlines of Australia are frequently unprofitable. No doubt TAA's profitability would improve if it ceased F27 operations. However, as a public company, TAA would be subject to decisions of the company's shareholders and the terms of the renegotiated Airlines Agreement. This agreement will include provisions relating to the maintenance of air services to rural areas. Under these provisions the airlines may not withdraw airline services while revenue exceeds direct operating costs and, in any event, will not withdraw services except after prior consultation with a view to providing replacement services.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 2 April 1981 (Hansard, page 1033) Senator Button asked me a question without notice concerning the establishment of Trans-Australia Airlines as a public company.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Transport has provided the following information in response to the honourable senator's question:
It has recently been announced that the Government has taken an in-principle decision to establish TAA as a public company.

This involves setting up TAA to operate as a company established under the Companies Act of a State or Territory in a manner that meets the requirements relating to public companies. It does not, however, require that the equity in that company is wholly or partly held by the private sector.

The Government is considering such matters as the question of the extent, if any, of the equity in that company that might be offered to the private sector. Several options are being examined. It has already been stated that no action will be taken which could lead to the development of a monopoly situation in the provision of Australia's airline services.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 2 April 1981 (Hansard, page 1035) Senator Ryan asked me a question, without notice, concerning the possible sale of Trans-Australia Airlines.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Transport has provided me with the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

None of the recommendations of the Holcroft Independent Public Inquiry into Domestic Airfares concerned the sale of Trans-Australia Airlines. At this stage the Government has decided in principle to establish TAA as a public company. The Government still has under consideration the nature and structure of such a company.

(2) Can the Minister state: (a) how many tenders have been made; (b) how many have been made by overseas companies and from which countries; (c) how many Australian companies, if any, have tendered; (d) what requirements, if any, have been laid down for Australian participation in the supply and construction stage of the satellite system.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Communications has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1), (2) (a), (b) and (c) The Request for Tender (RFT) for the Australian national communications satellite system was issued on 30 October 1980 by the Overseas Telecommunications Commission (Australia). As the closing date for tenders is 4 May 1981, it is not possible at this time to advise the number or country of origin of the tenderers.
The closing date for tenders was extended from 2 March 1981 to 4 May 1981 at the request of local and overseas tenderers to allow them to better research and formulate their proposals.

(2) (d) The Government has stated on a number of occasions its intention that Australian industry involvement in the satellite project be maximised.
