QUESTION.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 4 March 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: What are the detailed guidelines for the funding of youth accommodation under the Youth Services Program.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The guidelines for the operation of the Youth Services Scheme were distributed to all State and Territory Social Welfare Ministers in December 1979. The statement which follows reproduces the guidelines subject to minor amendments, particularly to Section 4.0 (Evaluation), which take account of subsequent developments.
GUIDELINES
1.0 Essential components of scheme

1.1 Definition: A youth shelter scheme with support services to be focused on youth aged to 18 years. At the discretion of sponsoring agencies, youth aged over 18 years may be assisted through the Scheme, when appropriate.
1.2 Emergency accommodation: This can be provided in:

A. Residential units offering short-term emergency accommodation for periods ranging from overnight to 3 months, as well as providing for youth in exceptional circumstances requiring accommodation over longer periods or on an intermittent basis. It is not intended that this scheme provide long-term accommodation, however.

B. Subsidised accommodation through 'contract of bed space' by various means for periods ranging from overnight to 3 months. This form of assistance allows for an approved household to be paid by an agency or scheme to reserve a bed. Such provision-
increases the amount of available accommodation for emergency placements and transition purposes, etc.
increases flexibility within the Scheme.
1.3 Support services. These include:
counselling and information services for children and their parents;
supervision of young people in accommodation;
rent/lease guarantees to landlords, and subsidies.

1.4 Sponsoring organisations. In general, grants are made to community agencies. State Government or local government sponsorship of projects is permissible where no suitable community agency is available to sponsor a project.

1.5 Recognition of existing programs. The Youth Services Scheme is not limited to new projects. Existing youth refuge services will be considered for funding on the basis of the eligibility criteria specified in the guidelines.
1.6 Youth who are a State/Territory responsibility. The Youth Services Scheme does not provide for children for whom States/Territories have statutory responsibilities (eg State wards and parolees).
2.0 Proposed administrative arrangements
2.1 Funding. Funding is for specific projects rather than on a block grant basis. There are joint Commonwealth/State or Territory ministerial announcements of projects approved.

2.2 Grants are provided mainly for recurrent funding of projects. Capital grants for new buildings are not available, although the cost of reasonable modifications to existing facilities may be considered for funding.

2.3 Administration. Joint Commonwealth/State and Territory administrative committees have been set up in each State or Territory and include representatives from the voluntary sector. Arrangements have been made for consultation with the Homeless Persons Advisory Committee in each State. Recommendations made by these administrative committees are still submitted to the Minister for Social Security and State or Territory Welfare Ministers for final approval.
3.0 Administrative costs

3.1 State/Territory administrative costs are not a part of the matching funding arrangement, as these would absorb an unduly large proportion of grants for services. The Commonwealth and State/Territory departments are responsible for their respective administrative costs incurred in evaluation.
4.0 Evaluation

4.1 A committee is responsible for evaluation of the Scheme. The committee comprises Departmental nominees from Victoria, New South Wales, and the Commonwealth Departments of Social Security and Employment and Youth Affairs. The Committee is known as the National Committee for Evaluation.

4.2 The committee has developed an evaluation strategy now endorsed by State/Territory departments responsible for the Scheme. The Minister for Social Security has endorsed this strategy and has sought the endorsement of all the State Ministers involved.

4.3 An evaluation report will be provided to Welfare Ministers of all States/Territories participating in the scheme and to the Minister for Social Security and will be considered by the Council of Social Welfare Ministers, and the Standing Committee of Social Welfare Administrators.
4.4 Costs for evaluation (excluding administrative costs) may be met from 1 per cent of the matched grants.
5.0 Contract for services

5.1 As part of their management function State welfare departments will contract with the service agency to ensure the availability of health and counselling services and the provision of statistics required for evaluation purposes. Letters of contract will be exchanged specifying terms and conditions (including the fixed-term character) of the grants.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs, upon notice, on 11 March 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Does the government acknowledge the need for some thorough examination of the possible effects of the new technology in retailing, with particular reference to the practice of including on the labels of consumer goods bar codes which disclose inter alia the nature of the product and its price, making possible a number of labour saving management techniques which may have effects not only on the employment of shop attendants but on the employment of those at a number of levels in the manufacturing, wholesale and retail industries.
(2) Would such an examination arrive at a fully informed and rational government policy with regard to this matter.
(3) Is such an examination under way or proposed; if not why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's questions:

ANSWER.PARA: (1), (2) and (3) In November 1980 a national working party was established by Commonwealth, State and Territory Ministers for Consumer Affairs to examine policy and technical questions associated with bar codes on products and electronic checkout systems used in retail stores.

The working party comprises the Commonwealth Department of Business and Consumer Affairs, the National Standards Commission and consumer affairs agencies in South Australia, New South Wales and Victoria.
The terms of reference of the working party are as follows:

1. To identify the benefits and difficulties associated with the introduction and continued operation of electronic checkout systems particularly in relation to individual item pricing as opposed to other methods of price disclosure, from retailer and consumer viewpoints.
2. To consider whether, in the interests of both retailers and consumers, it is necessary to provide any safeguards to streamline the introduction of electronic checkout systems.
3. To assess the feasibility of any safeguards considered necessary, from a technical, legal and enforcement viewpoint and to assess the costs to the community of those safeguards.
4. To consider the implications of the future introduction of extensions to this new retail technology.

The working party will not duplicate the work of the Committee of Inquiry into Technological Change in Australia (CITCA) under the Chairmanship of Professor Rupert Myers. This Committee assessed, interalia, the impact of new technology on employment including employment in the retail trade. The Prime Minister tabled the CITCA Report on 19 August 1980. The Minister for Industry and Commerce, the Right Honourable Sir Phillip Lynch, K.C.M.G., M.P., made a statement to the Parliament on the report on 18 September 1980 and set out the Government's response to CITCA's recommendations dealing with the impact of technology upon employment and I draw the honourable senator's attention to that statement.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Australian Retired Persons Association Friendly Society

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister rep- resenting the Treasurer, upon notice, on 31 March 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: Is the Treasurer aware of a retirement plan advertised by the Australian Retired Persons Association Friendly Society in which it is claimed that regular periodical bonuses paid by the plan 'are not regarded as income by the Taxation Office and that they are excluded from the income test applied by the Social Security Department for the age, invalid and widows' pensions, et cetera'; if so, (a) is this advertisement factual; (b) how can such payments be excluded from consideration as taxation or as part of the income test applied by the Social Security Department; and (c) are similar benefits from other organisations excluded in this way.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: The Commissioner of Taxation has stated that some friendly societies provide policies of life assurance as a service to their members. Bonuses are credited to such policies from time to time, usually on a yearly basis. On maturity of a policy the amounts received by the policy holder including bonuses credited are not subject to income tax. This is also the position where a policy is surrendered either in full or in part at any time prior to its maturity.

The treatment of such payments for the purposes of determining entitlement to the age, invalid and widows' pensions, et cetera, has been explained by the Minister for Social Security in reply to another question-Question No. 574-asked by the honourable senator.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 7 April 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: Are profits made from the sale of import quotas, for the purpose of assessing taxation liability regarded as income or capital gains and at what rate, if any, are they taxed.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: The Commissioner of Taxation has advised that, while the question whether a particular receipt is one of income or capital ultimately depends upon the particular facts of a given case, he is of the view that in most cases profits from the sale of import quotas would be assessable income.

This would clearly be so where the vendor was in the business of trading in import quotas, where a quota had been acquired for the purpose of making a profit by its subsequent sale or where a quota was purchased and sold within twelve months at a profit. In the generality of cases, however, it seems that an importer would acquire import quotas with the intention of using them in whatever way would be most advantageous. In these circumstances the sale of the quotas would be an incident of the business activities from which assessable income is derived and the profits from their sale therefore part of the assessable proceeds of the business.

There would, however, be some cases in which the proper conclusion would be that a profit from the sale of an import quota is of a capital nature, e.g. where a quota is sold as part of the assets of a business being disposed of.
Profits from the sale of import quotas included in assessable income would be taxed at the rate applicable to the vendor's taxable income.

ANSWER.TO.QWN.TITLE: Hercules Aircraft: Transport of Processed Uranium

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 2 April 1981 (Hansard, page 1042) Senator Melzer asked me, as the Minister representing the Minister for Trade and Resources, without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: Has Queensland Mines Ltd asked the Federal Government to make available a Hercules aircraft to fly processed uranium out of Australia? To what destination is the material to be flown? Has the Government made a decision on this matter? If it has not, when will this decision be taken?
The Minister for Trade and Resources has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

Queensland Mines has not asked the Federal Government to make available a Hercules aircraft to fly processed uranium out of Australia. Queensland Mines has advised me that the Seamen's Union and the Waterside Workers Federation have informed the company that they will no longer handle export shipments of uranium. Previous shipments under existing contracts have been handled by both unions. Consequently, the company is at this time being frustrated from fulfilling its existing contracts and is reviewing its position.
